text: Chemical sensing is the oldest evolutionary adaptation and is used by almost all motile species from bacteria to mammals. Bacteria and other simple organisms use chemical gradients to move toward a desired area (chemotaxis). Larger animals such as fruitflies trying to find some nice rotting fruit or dogs tracking a scent trail use olfactory (and other cues like wind direction) to locate the desired source.  In this talk, I will present some recent work that we have been doing olfactory navigation, specifically, the problem of trail following and odor location.  I will start with a very simplistic model based on the assumption of a smooth gradient and show that even this problem leads to some very interesting mathematics. I then show some examples of the real world of odor distribution and why this is a really hard problem.  I will discuss several different approaches in this but the real work is just beginning.
title: Scent and Sensibility: Navigating a Chemical Trail

text: Action video game players outperform their non-action-game playing peers on various sensory, attentional and cognitive tasks. A training regimen whose benefits are so broad is rather unprecedented and provides a unique opportunity to identify factors that underlie generalization of learning and principles of brain plasticity. We propose that a common mechanism is at the source of this wide range of skill improvement. In particular, improvement in performance following action video game play results from greater learning to learn abilities. We will see that behavioral and neural markers of attentional control are enhanced in gamers, allowing them to better focus on the task at hand and ignore distractors or sources of noise. Such focus on task-relevant statistics appears to allow for not only more informed decision making but also faster learning and greater transfer. Practical applications from education to rehabilitation will be discussed.
title: Learning and transfer: Lessons from action video games

text: The primate "form" processing pathway culminates in inferotemporal cortex, where objects are represented in a manner that allows their identity to be extracted invariant to details such as the particular position, size and background context with which they appear.  We have investigated the means by which these IT object-based representations intermingle with the more abstract rule-based representations required to solve two object-based tasks: finding a sought object and remembering whether an object has previously been encountered. Both tasks can be envisioned as a two-way classification of the task solution invariant to image and object identity (i.e., Is my target in view or not? Is the object in view novel or familiar?).  Within IT, we find that the identities of different objects are largely reflected as differences in the pattern of spikes across the population.  In contrast, rule-based representations are largely reflected in IT by changes in the overall numbers of spikes.  This type of configuration has the benefit of minimizing the interaction of IT object-based and rule-based representations.  However, this type of rule-based representation has the drawback that it can be easily confounded with changes in other parameters that impact the overall numbers of spikes across the IT population, such as image contrast, under the assumption of a simple, linear read-out.  In experiments designed to assess whether potential neural confusions between task rule and image contrast lead to behavioral confusions, we find that they do not, thus suggesting that rule-based information is read-out of IT using a read-out that is more sophisticated than a simple linear classifier.
title: The superposition of object-based and rule-based representations in inferotemporal (IT) cortex

text: Natural stimuli hold the key to understanding how advanced signal processing, such as that which makes it possible for us to recognize specific people and events, occurs in the brain.  At present there is only a cursory understanding of how detailed signal representations are transformed into the invariant forms of selectivity observed deep inside the brain in both the visual and auditory systems. Towards this goal, I will describe a set of statistical methods that can be used in conjunction with natural stimuli to probe and characterize the feature selectivity and invariance of neurons deep inside the sensory circuits. I will present new insights that these methods have elucidated about the responses of mid-level visual and auditory neurons.
title: How invariant feature selectivity is achieved in cortex

affiliations.department: Department of Psychology and Neuroscience and the Institute of Cognitive Science

text: A legacy of neuropsychology research is the tendency to associate a psychological process with a small number of brain areas necessary and sufficient for that process. However, most human psychological processes—even those as basic and evolutionarily conserved as the experience of physical pain—are more likely to emerge from complex network dynamics that span multiple large-scale brain systems. When this is the case, predictive models of processes and behaviors that span multiple systems will outperform single-region based models, both in terms of predicting future behavior and understanding the underlying representations. In this talk, I show that this is the case for basic affective processes, including pain, negative emotion, and the vicarious ‘pain’ of observing others’ suffering. Distributed predictive models dramatically outperform single region-models, and characterizing interactions across multiple systems is both necessary and sufficient to capture these forms of affective experience. In addition, such models are ‘research products’ that can be used, shared, and tested across laboratories. Doing so will accelerate the development of a cumulative neuroscience of human experience and behavior. In addition, testing brain models across many cognitive and affective conditions provides a way to validate psychological constructs in terms of their underlying neurophysiology.
title: Large-scale predictive modeling: Principles and examples from affective neuroscience

text: Homeostatic mechanisms stabilize neural circuit function by keeping firing rates (FRs) within a set-point range, but whether individual neocortical neurons regulate firing around a cell-autonomous set-point, and whether this process is restricted to certain behavioral states such as sleep or wake, is unknown. I will start by discussing the mechanisms of synaptic scaling, a form of cell-autonomous homeostatic plasticity, and the role of this plasticity in generating firing rate set-points in vivo. I will then discuss new work in which we follow the process of FR homeostasis in individual visual cortical neurons in freely behaving rodents as they cycled between sleep and wake states. When FRs are perturbed by visual deprivation, over time they returned precisely to a cell-autonomous set-point, and this restoration of firing occurred selectively during periods of active waking and was suppressed by sleep.  Longer natural waking periods result in more FR homeostasis, as does artificially extending the length of waking. This exclusion of FR homeostasis from sleep raises the possibility that memory consolidation or some other sleep-dependent process is vulnerable to interference from homeostatic plasticity mechanisms.
title: Firing rate homeostasis in freely behaving rodents

text: I will argue that Bayesian statistics is the result of convergence of learning onto a good solution. Nothing inherently Bayesian. Just the right solution. Which happens to be Bayesian.
title: We are all statisticians. Faking it until we make it

affiliations.department: Tilburg Center for Logic and Philosophy of Science (TiLPS)

text: It is often claimed that the greatest value of the Bayesian framework in the cognitive sciences consists in its unifying power. After distinguishing different ways in which Bayesian statistics matters to our understanding of mind, I shall explore whether and how Bayesian statistics can unify the sciences of mind.
title: Bayes, the brain, and the future of cognitive science

text: Bayesian models are now routinely used to describe perception, learning, and cognition. In this talk I will show that the same principles can also be used to derive several properties of neural circuits, from the sub-cellular (synaptic and dendritic nonlinearities), through the cellular (spike timing responses), to the network level (population variability and dynamics). This is because the requirement to efficiently integrate information from several sources that are each unreliable to varying degrees is relevant at the biophysical as much as at the behavioural level.
title: Bayesian principles underlying the organisation of neural circuits

text: Our brains analyze high-dimensional datasets streamed by our sensory organs by solving tasks like dimensionality reduction, sparse feature discovery and clustering. To model neural computations implementing these tasks we propose a new family of objective functions based on the principle of similarity matching. From these objective functions we derive online distributed algorithms that can be implemented by biological neural networks resembling cortical circuits. Our networks can adapt to changes in the number of latent dimensions or the number of clusters in the input dataset. Furthermore, we formulate minimax optimization problems from which we derive online algorithms with two classes of neurons identified with principal neurons and interneurons in biological circuits.
title: Derivation of neural circuits from the similarity matching principle

text: Human thought is driven by well-controlled dynamic interactions between large-scale neural circuits or networks, enabling a broad set of human behaviors.  In this talk, I will discuss recent work using new network-analysis algorithms to test the recruitment and integration of large-scale functional neural circuitry during human skill learning.  Our results show that learning induces an autonomy of sensorimotor systems and that the release of cognitive control hubs in frontal and cingulate cortices predicts individual differences in the rate of learning on other days of practice.  These data motivate a discussion of the fact that fundamental principles constraining the control of these dynamic network processes have remained elusive. In the second part of the talk, I will discuss recent work based on diffusion spectrum imaging data to estimate hard-wired pathways connecting different areas of the human brain. Using the mathematical foundation of network control theory, we show that structural network differences between subgraphs in the brain dictate their distinct roles in controlling brain function. More generally, our results support the view that macroscale structural design underlies basic cognitive control processes via the fundamental mechanism of network controllability.
title: Network Reconfiguration: Functional Role and Structural Predictors

text: Retinal ganglion cells are thought to come in a number of discrete types, each of which is the output of a distinct visual computation. The catalog of types remains incomplete despite a century of research. We undertook a comprehensive classification based on reconstructions of all ganglion cells in electron microscopic images of a small patch of mouse retina. The unbiased sample of almost 400 neurons was classified into cell types, based chiefly on depth of dendritic stratification. We clustered the cells into more than 40 distinct types, almost all of which “tile” the retinal patch with little overlap between dendritic arbors. Our anatomical catalog suggests that the parallel effort to genetically define types is less than half done. We used the types to systematically test heuristic rules for using structural features to predict visual response properties like direction selectivity, On vs. Off, and sustained vs. transient.
title: Comprehensive anatomical classification of retinal ganglion cells

text: My talk will explore the impact of scientific advances on human history and how the Establishment has tried to block the most profound and important.  Building on my own experience in pharmacology and brain research with psychedelic drugs I will explain why we now need a new Enlightenment to fully develop our understanding of how the brain works.
title: Why scientists should also be revolutionaries

text: Neuro-enhancement is gaining attention in the sciences, humanities, as well as in public debates. People are excited and worried about the use of prescription medication by healthy persons for the purpose of augmenting “normal“ cognitive or affective function, i.e. aiming to influence brain function in individuals without recognized dysfunction. However, boundaries between therapy in sickness and enhancement in wellness are often imprecise in practice. Perspectives about disease and health evolve along a continuum of historical, cultural, and economic contexts. In this talk, I will sketch current possibilities to enhance brain function. I will then focus on the ethical and social questions on the practices, the motivations, and goals to enhance throughout life, from childhood to high age: Why do people even strive for neuro-enhancement? What are the chances and risks, individually and socially? The old question “should we do what we can do?“ needs to be asked again by discussing which values we want to pursue in the context of further developments towards self-optimisation.
title: Self-shaping throughout life – Neuro-enhancement from childhood to high age

reasonForTalk: The notion of feature map pertains to most “low-level” sensory structures. By showing that a single type tiling the visual space can multiplex several features, we shed light on the unexpected computing power of the retina.
text:
The classical view of the retina is that each subtype of ganglion cell extracts one feature from the visual scene, and that the population constituting a subtype provides a feature map to the brain. 
To test this idea, we recorded a large population of ganglion cells from a single cell type (fast OFF) using large multi-electrode arrays in the rat retina responding to randomly moving bars. 
When only one bar was displayed, even cells whose receptive field was far from the bar responded reliably to motion. While the cells whose receptive field was in overlap with the bar could be well predicted by a linear (LNP) model, these distant cells responded in a non-linear manner. We found that a cascade model composed of two stages of linear-non-linear processing (LNLN) could predict the responses of these cells. Using this model, we demonstrate that, while the cells close to the stimulus were highly sensitive to the position of the stimulus, distant cells were largely invariant to this position and mostly coded for change in the speed of the bar. Therefore, within a homogeneous population of ganglion cells of the same subtype, two radically different computations were performed on the stimulus. 
Furthermore, the response of distant cells to motion outside the receptive field was strongly suppressed as soon as another bar was displayed inside their receptive field. When the second bar was added, most of these distant cells actively suppressed their response to the first bar, and coded the position of the second bar instead.
We found that combining our previous cascade model with a global gain control could account for the linear central response, the non-linear distant response and its suppression. Our results suggest that the retina is able to reallocate its neuronal resources in different regimes: the ganglion cells can actively respond to distant stimuli when their receptive field is not stimulated, but switch to a linear, position sensitive computation when their receptive field is stimulated. 
These two computations might be useful to extract different features of the visual scene during saccadic vs fixational eye movements.
title: A flexible code : retinal ganglion cells dynamically switch between two computations

reasonForTalk: This work presents a concerted effort going back and forth between chronic recordings of population activity, quantitative analysis and theoretical modelling. The approach and the results are appealing to a broad computational and experimental audience.
text:
In visual cortex, local networks of co-tuned neurons manifest in a columnar
organization, but also form distributed circuits with distant, but similarly co-tuned
neurons several millimeters away. It has been hypothesized that co-tuning
between neurons  might be dynamically established using patterns
of spontaneous activity, however, experimental evidence supporting this scenario
is scarce. Here we combined chronic epifluorescence and 2-photon imaging with
quantitative analysis and modeling to dissect the organization of spontaneous
activity in the early ferret visual cortex in relation to the developing networks of
orientation selective domains which become apparent upon eye opening.
We find that by ten days prior to eye opening, cortical activity is already spatially
coherent on a columnar scale. The local activity correlation structure resembles a
Mexican-hat profile, an organization consistent with models for the activity
dependent development of orientation domains. Remarkably, strong correlations
were present between cortical domains several millimeters apart, even at a
stage in development when horizontal connections of layer 2/3 pyramidal cells
remain primarily local. To understand how long-range correlations could arise
from purely local connectivity, we generated a circuit model of rate units receiving weakly modulated random input drive with connectivity reflecting the experimentally observed Mexican-hat structure. This model produced modular activity patterns with long-range spatial correlations, arising through multi-synaptic heterogeneous recurrent feedback loops.
Although activity correlations in the model vary smoothly across the
cortex, they are systematically punctuated by abrupt discontinuities.
Notably, we also observed such ‘correlation fractures’ in the structure of
spontaneous activity in vivo, where they tend to co-align with pinwheel locations
in the orientation preference map after eye-opening. Further, we find that several
days prior to eye opening, long-range correlations in spontaneous activity were
predictive of future tuning similarity in the mature orientation map, providing
additional evidence for a developmental relationship between spontaneous
activity and co-tuned networks. We conclude that primitive circuits of the early
cortex robustly generate both local and long-ranging structured correlations in
spontaneous activity, which might form the basis for the development of co-tuned
spatially distributed cortical networks.
title: Local circuits form long-ranging spontaneous correlations to build distributed sensory representations in the early developing visual cortex

text:
The primary visual cortex contains a detailed map of the visual scene, which is represented according to multiple stimulus dimensions including spatial location, ocular dominance and stimulus orientation. While it is known that the maps for spatial location and ocular dominance arise from the spatial arrangement of thalamic afferent axons in the cortex, the origin of the orientation map remain unclear. A possible anatomical substrate for orientation maps could be the axonal arrangement of ON and OFF thalamic afferents in the cortex just as the substrate for ocular dominance maps is the arrangement of thalamic afferents from the contralateral and ipsilateral eyes. To test this hypothesis we introduced 32-channel multielectrode arrays (Neuronexus) horizontally into the cat primary visual cortex (V1). We measured ON and OFF retinotopy with light and dark stimuli and orientation tuning with moving bars. 

Our results [1] show that the cortical maps for orientation, direction and retinal disparity in the cat are all strongly related to the organization of the map for spatial location of light (ON) and dark (OFF) stimuli (Fig. 1a). We show that this organization is OFF-dominated and OFF-centric, i.e. OFF retinotopy is more precise than ON retinotopy and OFF acts as the anchor of the cortical retinotopic map [1, 2] (Fig. 1b). These unexpected results have now also been shown in tree shrew visual cortex [3], seem to be present in primate [1] and therefore are likely a common design principle in species with orientation maps. In this OFF-dominated and OFF-centric topography, changes in orientation and direction preference are determined by changes in ON/OFF retinotopy (Fig. 1c). Further, the cortical organization for ON/OFF runs orthogonal to the ocular dominance columns (Fig. 1d) and ON/OFF retinotopy is well matched at the ocular dominance border. This binocular match of ON/OFF retinotopy can explain why orientation preference shows a tendency to remain constant across the border of ocular dominance columns. Because the ON/OFF organization originates from clustering of ON and OFF thalamic afferents in the cat visual cortex [4] (Fig. 1e), we conclude that all main features of visual cortical topography, including orientation, direction and retinal disparity, follow a common organizing principle that arranges thalamic axons with similar retinotopy and ON–OFF polarity in neighboring cortical regions.
title: Principles underlying sensory map topography in primary visual cortex

text:
Dendritic spines are the postsynaptic substrate of excitatory synapses in the adult neocortex. Typically neurons form synaptic connections through multiple synaptic contacts [1, 2] (dendritic spines) each of which is prone to stochastic transmission failures [3]. The size of individual spines changes on time-scales ranging from seconds to weeks, and is strongly correlated to the synaptic efficacy [4]. Through a process called synaptic turnover, small spines can be removed and new ones may form [4]. Importantly, despite continuous turnover, the density of spines in the tissue is preserved over time [4] and, while some transient spines disappear within a few days after formation, others are observed to persist for weeks or even months [4]. It is thus an important question how stable synaptic connections can be formed despite continuous dendritic spine plasticity and turnover.

Here we present a model of the joint plasticity of multi-contact synaptic connections (Fig. 1). We propose a local spike timing dependent plasticity (STDP) rule that describes the dynamics of individual synaptic contacts (dendritic spines). The dependence on spike timing makes our model sensitive to correlations of neuronal activity, leading to cooperation of synaptic contacts within a synaptic connection, and competition across synaptic connections.

In network simulations we show that our model reproduces the experimentally observed distributions of synaptic contact numbers [1], dendritic spine turnover ratio [4] and the emergence of long-term stable contacts [4]. Thereby, multiple contacts are crucial for long-term stability of synaptic connections, because (a) the contacts cooperate by increasing pre-post correlations [5] and (b) they increase the signal to noise ratio of synaptic transmission by averaging out stochastic transmission failures. In simulated input deprivation experiments we confirm that in the weeks following deprivation, the fraction of newly formed persistent contacts is elevated relative to the control condition [4], as the network rewires to compensate for the change of input.
title: A spike timing dependent model of dendritic spine plasticity and turnover

reasonForTalk: This contribution presents a new computational imaging approach for imaging many neurons, leverages new statistical approaches and cloud computing to scale to terabyte-scale data, and benefits significantly from being shown with embedded 3D movies.
text: Recording and modeling the coordinated activity of cellular events through volumes of intact mammalian tissue is a major challenge in biology that has inspired significant technological innovation. Despite this, scanless measurement of the high-speed activity of individual neurons across three dimensions in scattering tissue remains an open problem. Here we develop and validate a computational imaging approach (SWIFT) that integrates high-dimensional, structured statistics with light field microscopy [1] to allow the synchronous acquisition of single-neuron resolution activity throughout intact tissue volumes as fast as a camera can capture images (currently up to 100 Hz at full camera resolution). We demonstrate that this large field-of-view, single-snapshot volume acquisition method---which requires only a simple and inexpensive modification to a standard fluorescence microscope---enables scanless capture of sparse but coordinated activity patterns throughout mammalian cortical volumes both in vitro and in vivo. Further, the volumetric nature of SWIFT also allows fast in vivo imaging, motion correction, and cell identification throughout curved subcortical structures like the dorsal hippocampus, where cellular-resolution dynamics spanning hippocampal subfields CA1, CA2, and CA3 can be simultaneously observed during a virtual context learning task in a behaving animal. In addition, because SWIFT is minimally damaging and effective in scattering tissue, it can be safely applied to the rapid cellular-resolution functional imaging and modeling of neural population dynamics in human cortical tissue. SWIFT’s ability to rapidly and easily record from volumes of many cells cortically and subcortically opens the door to widespread identification of dynamical motifs and timing dependencies among coordinated cell assemblies during adaptive, modulated, or maladaptive physiological processes in rodent and human neural systems.
title: Recording and modeling cellular-activity timing relationships spanning brain volumes in mouse and human

text:
In the neocortex, the trial-to-trial variability of the single neuron spike count is considerably high under spontaneous conditions. This can be strongly reduced by stimulus presentation or during movement execution  [1,2]. In single unit recordings from Macaque motor cortex during a delayed reaching task [2,3] we analyse the time resolved spike count and inter-spike-interval statistics. While across-trial variability measured by the Fano factor (FF) is clearly temporally modulated, interval variability quantified by different measures (squared coefficient of variation CV$^2$, local CV2 and local variation LV) shows only weak modulations (Fig. 1, upper panel).

Recently, a series of studies have shown that the stimulus induced reduction in FF can be captured by balanced network models of integrate and fire neurons with clusters of stronger connectivity in the excitatory population [4,5,6]. In these networks, individual clusters cycle between states of high and low activity. This introduces firing rate variations, which increase the FF to values above unity. When a constant current stimulus is applied to one or several of the clusters, these clusters are clamped to the high activity state and others are suppressed through lateral inhibition. This mechanism quenches the rate variations and the FF is reduced. In these clustered networks, neurons in the active clusters fire at very high rates and may produce highly regular spike trains. Such high rate, regular spiking, is however inconsistent with findings in physiological recordings from the neocortex. 

Using a mean field description of networks of binary neurons [7], we analyse the stable rate configurations of networks with clustered connectivity and show that the firing rates in the active states can be reduced by the additional introduction of inhibitory clusters. We then show that this result can be transferred to networks of spiking leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF) neurons where the inhibitory clusters preserve the balance of excitatory and inhibitory input currents in the high activity states. This leads to spike trains of constant irregularity at moderate firing rates also during the stimulation induced reduction of the FF (Fig. 1, lower panel) in good qualitative and quantitative agreement with our findings in the motor-cortical data set. The range of parameters over which cycling between clusters is achieved is thereby greatly increased, reducing the need for fine tuning of network parameters.
title: Balanced networks with excitatory and inhibitory clusters reproduce cortical variability dynamics in vivo

reasonForTalk: We examine two forms of adaptation in a single neuron and how they interact. Combining electrophysiology with modeling, we provide insights into how different computations are organized in a single neuron to support efficient neural representations

text:
Adaptation is ubiquitous in sensory neurons and improves stimulus representations. Adaptation to various properties of the stimulus distribution, e.g. its mean or variance, coexist within the same sensory pathway, yet the interaction between different types of adaptation is rarely examined.
We address this issue in the context of courtship song recognition in the fruit fly. During courtship, the male produces a song, the features of which inform the female’s mating decision. Song is perceived using the arista, a feathery extension on the antenna and properties of this sound receiver pose challenges for encoding the song pattern: 1) Due to the high directionality of the sound receiver, changes in distance and angle between male and female induce strong fluctuations in sound intensity. 2) Gravity or wind also move the receiver and add a slowly varying offset to the antennal position.
Sound intensity and the antennal offset interfere with an efficient representation of song and the auditory system should hence correct for them through adaptation. Sound intensity and offset correspond to the variance and the mean of the antennal position; the auditory system should thus perform mean and variance adaptation.
Using electrophysiology and modeling, we examine adaptation in the fly’s auditory receptors – Johnston’s organ neurons (JON). Previous studies have demonstrated mean adaptation in JON [1][2], which is subtractive and arises in the subthreshold currents. We here show that JON also adapt to sound intensity. Intensity adaptation is divisive and produces near intensity-invariant sound responses. It arises in the subthreshold responses of JON just like the mean adaptation. That two distinct forms of adaptation are implemented in the same cellular compartment raises the issue of how they interact: Antennal offset– and hence mean adaptation – should not affect sound sensitivity. By independently controlling the mean and variance of antennal position during JON recordings, we find a unidirectional interaction: mean adaptation does not affect sound sensitivity (as desired) but intensity adaptation reduces responses to antennal offset.
Using modeling we examine the implementation of adaptation in JON. Only a serial arrangement in which mean adaptation precedes variance adaptation reproduces our data. In addition, rectification is essential for variance adaptation. This parallels findings in the retina, where variance adaptation also requires rectification [3].
title: The organization of adaptation in auditory receptor neurons of Drosophila

text: Determination of the direction of an acoustic source, or sound localization, is a fundamental function of the auditory system. Interaural time and level differences (ITD/ILD) are major cues for binaural sound localization. Neurons in the lateral superior olive (LSO) located at the mammalian auditory brainstem receive excitatory and inhibitory synaptic inputs that are driven by ipsi- and contralateral sound stimuli, respectively. In order to encode ILDs and envelope ITDs, LSO neurons act as anti-coincidence detectors of these inputs [1]. Previous anatomical studies found age-dependent loss of inhibitory inputs along the auditory system, whereas electrophysiological recordings reported relatively minor functional changes in aged LSO. In this study, we used a biologically plausible model of LSO and examined how inhibition loss may affect ITD and ILD coding. Excitatory and inhibitory inputs to the LSO were modeled as Poisson processes, whose intensity function was either temporally uniform (for ILD) or periodic (for ITD). Membrane and synaptic parameters were tuned to reproduce known LSO responses measured in vivo and in vitro. Simulated output spike rates of the model smoothly decreased with increasing contralateral sound intensity, resembling empirical ILD tuning. For low frequency envelopes, simulated spike rates periodically changed with the phase difference of binaural inputs, similar to ITD coding in the LSO. Reduction of the number of inhibitory inputs, which mimicked age-related inhibition loss, resulted in increased overall spike rates and decreased modulation depths (defined as the difference between maximum and minimum spike rates). These effects were considerably weakened when the reduced number of inhibitory inputs was compensated by an increased strength of each inhibitory input. These results suggest that age-related loss of inhibition could potentially be counteracted by activity-dependent plasticity, and may explain the discrepancy between previous anatomical and physiological findings in the aged LSO.
title: Modeling Age-dependent Inhibition Loss and Recovery in the Auditory Brainstem

text:
Perception can be viewed as a combination of two information streams, one responsible to predict the sensory consequences of actions, and a second providing actual sensory observations. In order to compensate for the noise and uncertainty inherent in sensory information, the two streams are integrated to extract an internal model that predicts the sensory consequences of motor actions [1]. In both biological and technical systems such a model provides a belief of their state and is adjusted proportional to the uncertainty in the predictions [2].
Inspired by developmental processes known to occur in cortex, we propose a learning mechanism capable of representing such an internal model of sensorimotor space and the cross-sensory relations, by exploiting regularities in the sensorimotor streams [3]. As sensory and motor streams are not linked via some static mapping, such internal model predictions are biased affecting generalization to new tasks.
By exploiting regularities in sensorimotor mappings, structural learning is able to extract invariants between such mappings by learning the general rules that govern a set of tasks, enhancing adaptation and learning [4]. In this work we propose combining distributed representations, learning mechanisms, and structural learning in a generic computational framework targeting neuro-robotic systems. We believe that such a framework has potential to enhance the capabilities of today's robotic systems in handling complex dynamical operation scenarios.
title: Neuromorphic models of sensorimotor adaptation and learning

text:
One approach to model human strategies of obtaining reliable decisions under uncertainty considers the brain to act as a Bayesian Observer, integrating information from different modalities and previous knowledge. Responses are determined from a posterior distribution after fusion of noisy measurements with an internal prior distribution. The challenge for the creation of new models relates to both specifying the characteristics of independent measurements and priors involved (e.g. their modality specificity and learning ability), as well as to details of the integration process. It has been shown that Maximum Likelihood Estimation is well suited to describe multimodal integration of haptic and visual sensory input given different levels of background noise [1]. Recently, our group [2] compared a model fusing the measurement of a linear and angular displacement with a fixed prior to one in which the prior distribution is updated dynamically by a discrete Kalman filtering process after each trial. Both fusion and updating fully rely on the amount of measurement noise in the system. Our results showed that the dynamic model was able to predict regression to the mean, range effects and scalar variability. 
In the present study, we aimed to extend the previous model to multimodal conditions. To this end, we compared the reproduction of perceived angular displacement under visual-only (optokinetic drum), vestibular-only (rotating chair) and bimodal conditions. Since according to our model regression to the mean is closely linked to the amount of measurement noise, we assumed that regression effects should be reduced in the bimodal as compared to the unimodal condition. Indeed, on average the slopes of reproduced vs. perceived displacement were significantly larger for the bimodal condition, corresponding to a decreased weight of the prior. We further investigated, whether bimodal responses can be predicted from weight estimates calculated from the unimodal conditions and tested this using models with amodal or modality specific priors and different varieties of fusion. In several subjects, assuming modality-specific priors yielded better model fits, suggesting that displacement of the environment is treated differently than self-displacement. While these preliminary results suggest that the visual-vestibular fusion process is suboptimal on average, one explanation for this finding are the observed between-subject differences in fusion strategies.
title: Modelling distance reproduction by Bayesian integration of multisensory cues

text:
Visual processing already begins at the first synapse of the visual system. In the mouse retina, three different types of photoreceptors (M-cones, S-cones and rods) provide input to 14 bipolar cell types (reviewed by Euler et al., 2014). The precise pattern of connectivity between them determines which signals are available to downstream circuits and therefore the entire visual system. While it has been shown that cone bipolar cell type 1 contacts M-cones and type 9 contacts S-cones selectively, most bipolar cell types are thought to contact all cones within their dendritic field (Haverkamp et al., 2005; Breuninger et al., 2011). ON bipolar cells would contact cones exclusively via so-called invaginating synapses, while OFF bipolar cells would form basal synapses.
By mining publically available electron microscopy data published by Helmstaedter et al. (2013), we confirm that there are no additional M- or S-cone selective bipolar cell types in the mouse retina; however, we found interesting violations of the established rules of outer retinal connectivity: Cone bipolar cell type X contacted only ~20% of the cones in its dendritic field and made mostly atypical non-invaginating contacts with cones. Types 5T, 5O and 8 also contacted fewer cones than expected from the extent of their dendritic field. In addition, we provide anatomical evidence that rod and cone pathways are interconnected in both directions: Not only OFF-types 3A, 3B and 4 get direct input from rods but also rod bipolar cells from cones. Together, this suggests that the organization of the outer plexiform layer is less straightforward than classically thought.
title: Connectivity map of bipolar cells and photoreceptors in the mouse retina

text:
In their natural environment, animals sense and evaluate olfactory cues of time­-varying composition and concentration. Their olfactory pathways are adapted to the natural stimulus  statistics, thus it is not surprising that odor processing is fast. Honey bees, for example, learn to discriminate odors presented for as short as 200 ms [5]. How is the insect olfactory system optimized to reliably estimate spatial and temporal aspects of the olfactory environment and what are the mechanisms behind rapid odor processing?

To understand the underlying mechanisms behind sensory processing we investigate odor  representations in two principal stages of the insect olfactory system. In the antennal lobe (AL) odor representations are dense and dynamic. In the Mushroom Body (MB) representations are sparse. Odor representations emerge within 50ms after stimulus onset and changes dynamically during and after stimulation[1,2]. We present a comprehensive spiking neural network model of the insect olfactory pathway that reproduces experimentally observed spatial and temporal patterns of the odor code in the AL and the MB [1, 3].

We investigate how odor responses at the AL and the MB are shaped by two mechanisms: (1) uniform lateral inhibition within the AL, and (2) cell intrinsic spike-­frequency adaptation. Together, both mechanisms underly dynamic odor representation in the AL and account for spatial and temporal sparseness in the KC population. We show that odor correlations are retained in the AL and reduced in the MB.

In addition, decoding classification of temporal odor representations reveals optimal decoding performance during stimulus on­ and offset. Interestingly, at the AL level odor identity can also be decoded during and well beyond stimulation. In contrast, at the MB level KC spikes establish a rapid but transient odor code, whereas a prolonged stimulus trace is found in intrinsic adaptation currents. Our approach allows us to investigate dynamical changes in odor representations and predicts odor after images.
title: Odor Representations in a Spiking Model of the Insect Olfactory System are Optimized by Lateral Inhibition and Cellular Adaptation

text:
In the primate brain, area MT is largely responsible for the processing and perception of motion in
visual scenes. MT neurons are tuned for the direction and the speed of moving stimuli and they
respond with pronounced firing rate transients upon a change in visual stimulation. These transients
increase the neurons' sensitivity and they are directly related to behavioural performances.
Therefore, to gain a better understanding of the processing of dynamic visual scenes it is important
to understand the neural processes that shape the transients in MT responses. We present a
dynamical model of MT cells that takes the cells’ speed and direction tuning into account and that is
able to reproduce their experimentally observed transients. In its simplest version, the model
consists of only two coupled differential equations, representing an excitatory and an inhibitory
population that make up a single direction column. Both populations receive the same external input
and additionally the inhibitory population provides divisive inhibition to the excitatory one. Using a
simple optimization procedure, we fit the model to find close to perfect fits for the sustained and
transient phases in MT single cell responses. Based on the fit for each cell, the model reproduces
and predicts neuronal responses to arbitrary accelerations and decelerations of a moving stimulus
starting from both low and high base speeds, including experimentally observed deviations of the
actual transient as compared to the expected firing rate change as deduced solely from a neuron's
speed tuning profile. We also investigated the possible effects of spatial and feature-directed
attention in our model and reproduced psychophysical reaction time distributions under different
attentional conditions. In particular, we found increasing relative firing rate differences during the
transients the stronger the attentional modulation was prior to a stimulus change. This effect
reversed in the sustained phase of the neurons' response, where relative activation decreased with
increasing attentional modulation. Our finding provides a mechanistic explanation for the shaping
and attentional modulation of neuronal response transients, and underlines the importance of this
dynamical mechanism for change detection.
title: Modelling transient dynamics and attentional modulation in MT cells in a structurally simple model

text: When interacting with natural environments, we continuously face multiple opportunities for detecting/discriminating distinct sensory objects.  Presumably, actual perceptions reflect a continuous evaluation of alternatives, as they become available, and a constant rebalancing of persisting in a current perception, or switching to a different one [1]. Here we show that detailed measurements of binocular rivalry - a well-studied instance of perceptual bistability - reveal a hierarchical organization of the underlying neuronal substrate that seems ideally suited for balancing ‘exploitation' and ‘exploration' [2] in ecological sensory situations.  Specifically, we show that the $\mathit{stationary}$ statistics of rivalry reversals (Gamma-shaped densities), as a function of two input contrasts ('Levelt's propositions', and 'scaling property' [3]), uniquely constrains the strengths of excitatory and inhibitory interactions between 'integration pools' and 'decision pools'.  Following [3], we model all pools as a finite number of discrete units, each expressing the spontaneous bistable dynamics of an attractor assembly (e.g., a cortical column or cluster of columns).  The mechanism exhibits unexpected $\mathit{non-stationary}$ behaviours, which are corroborated by additional observations. Functionally, it continuously accumulates and discards sensory information.  Specifically, it comprehensively and losslessly accumulates evidence for alternative perceptions, until one exceeds a differential threshold.  Subsequently, it reverses evidence accumulation selectively for the winning percept, shifting the balance more and more in favour of alternative percepts.  The perceptual threshold changes inversely with evidence flux.  When compared to optimal statistical inference, the performance of this observation-derived dynamical mechanism balances 'excitation' and 'exploitation' nearly optimally for ecological object frequencies.  In addition to providing a simple and generic solution for inference during continuous detection/discrimination, the same mechanism also reproduces puzzling neural correlates of episodic choice discrimination [4].
title: Binocular rivalry reveals the hierarchical organization of visual inference

text: Understanding sensory processing in the visual system results from accurate predictions of its neural responses to any kind of stimulus. Although great effort has been devoted to the task, we still lack a full characterization of primary visual cortex (V$1$) computations and their role in higher cognitive functional tasks (e.g. object recognition) in response to naturalistic stimuli. While previous goal-driven deep learning models have provided unprecedented performance on visual ventral stream predictions and revealed hierarchical correspondence, no study has used the representations learned by those models to predict single cell spike counts in V$1$. We introduce a novel model (Fig. $1$A) that leverages these learned representations to build a linearized model with Poisson noise. We separately use the representations of each convolutional layer of a near-state of the art convolutional neural network (CNN) trained on object recognition to fit a model that predicts V$1$ responses to naturalistic stimuli. When fitted to data collected from neurons across cortical layers in V$1$ from an awake, fixating monkey, we found that, as we expected, intermediate early layers in the CNN provided better performance on held out data (Fig. $1$B). Additionally we show that, using the best predictive layers, our model significantly outperforms classical and current state-of-the-art methods on V$1$ identification (Fig. $1$C). When exploring the properties of the best predictive layers in the CNN, we found striking similarities with known V$1$ computation. Our model is not only interpretable, but also interpolates between recent subunit-based hierarchical models and goal-driven deep learning models leading to results that argue in favor of shared representations in the brain.
title: A goal-driven deep learning approach for V1 system identification

text:
Signals recorded from the primate brain, either using macro-electrodes placed on the scalp or micro-electrodes inserted in the cortex often show oscillations at different frequencies. One such oscillation is the Gamma rhythm, which has a center frequency that lies between 30Hz and 80 Hz, and is induced in the primary visual cortex by visual stimulation. Fries et al. (2007) suggested that Gamma rhythm supplies a temporal reference frame to the spiking activity, for which it should have a stable frequency and consistent phase across time. However, Xing et al., (2012) showed that the Gamma rhythm occurs in short bursts and is too noisy to act as a stable reference frame. They used continuous Gabor transform (short-time Fourier transform (STFT) with a Gaussian window) to estimate the time-support of the Gamma rhythm. However, the time-frequency spectral estimate obtained using the spectrogram is noisy and has high variability (it follows an exponential distribution; (Brillinger, 1972)), which masks out the variability in the biological signal. In particular, because the power at any frequency follows an exponential distribution, it always appears bursty (few large values interspersed between many small values). Consequently, the method used by Xing et al produces very short estimates of gamma, even when the actual gamma signal is longer, as we show by simulating brain signals with known Gamma durations. Further, the Gamma rhythm duration estimated using this method also depends upon the window length of the STFT (Fig 1A).

We propose a matching pursuit (MP) (Mallat and Zhang, 1993; Durka et al., 2001; Chandran KS et al., 2016) based algorithm to estimate the duration of the Gamma rhythm. MP is a greedy algorithm that decomposes a time-domain signal into a linear combination of elementary waveforms called atoms. Typically, an over complete dictionary of such atoms, with both long and short durations, are available, such that the temporal support of the chosen atom depends on the structure of the signal itself: if a stable rhythm is present in the signal, an atom with a long temporal support is chosen for representation. Therefore, the statistics of the selected atoms provide a robust estimate of the duration of the rhythm, as shown through simulations (Fig 1A). We then apply this algorithm to the real brain signals and show that the median length of gamma is ~300 ms (for a visual stimulation time of 2 sec), too short to act like a reference signal (Fig 1B).
title: Duration Analysis of the Gamma Rhythm – Too Short to be a Reference!

text: Skilled behavior often displays signatures of Bayesian inference. In order for the brain to implement the required computations, neuronal activity must carry accurate information about the certainty of sensory inputs. Two major approaches have been proposed to study neuronal representations of certainty. The first searches for specific properties of neuronal activity (such as tuning-curve width and maximum firing-rate) that encode certainty [1-3]. The second aims at decoding the stimulus distribution from population activity using Bayes rule [4-6]. Currently, little is understood about how these approaches compare to one another. We introduced a new model of the processing of the Interaural Time Difference (ITD) cue for stimulus location, which matches both behavioral and electrophysiological data, and makes testable experimental predictions, while closely approximating the Bayes-optimal solution to the localization task. We found that different features of neuronal activity correlated with certainty, but they did not provide an accurate estimate of certainty, indicating such neuronal correlates of certainty might not play a major role in encoding it. In contrast, the full probability distribution over ITD could be accurately reconstructed with Bayes rule from population activity, and used to estimate certainty on a trial-by-trial basis. These results suggest that uncertainty is unlikely to be encoded in a single feature of neuronal activity.
title: Representing uncertainty in neuronal circuits: auditory localization as a test case

text:
Comparing different models of behavior allows us to test different hypotheses regarding the computational basis of perception and action. One difficulty in comparing models is that it requires testing stimuli in which the models create different predictions. Typically, stimuli selection is done non-adaptively using a predetermined fixed set of stimuli or by sampling stimuli randomly over a large range of values. Both methods have limitations; a predetermined set may not have enough stimuli to dissociate different models and using random sampling can be inefficient. 

To overcome these limitations we derived a method to dissociate psychophysical models using adaptive stimuli selection. Formally, our method selects stimuli which maximize the expected cross entropy between the current posterior probability of the different models and the posterior after the next stimuli is presented. Intuitively, this method selects stimuli so that the change in the posterior distribution is as large as possible - which is achieved by probing stimuli where the models make distinct predictions. 

To test our method we considered a common model comparison used in psychophysics; a comparison of different sensory noise models. We simulated multiple ideal observers with different sensory noise models and parameters performing a 2-AFC task. The stimuli were either selected randomly or using our adaptive method. We found the number of trials required to converge to the correct model with the adaptive method was significantly lower than random sampling (requiring under half as many trials).

Our technique is general and the formal basis applies to the dissociation of all Bayesian models. However, our implementation used discretized  parameter spaces and pre-computed likelihoods and is therefore particularly suited to psychophysics where the responses are binary and parameter dimensions are low. One use for our algorithm is validating sensory noise components used in more complex perception and action models. For example, consider reproducing a time interval. We can infer the most likely sensory noise model given the reproduced intervals. Our algorithm provides an efficient way to validate this inference using a psychophysical task.
title: The Psi-Model method: an adaptive method for dissociation of psychophysical models

references.text: Strange, B.A., Duggins, A., Penny, W., Dolan, R.J., and Friston, K.J. (2005a). Information theory, novelty and hippocampal responses: unpredicted or unpredictable? Neural Netw. 18, 225–230.

text:
Introduction: 
Predictability is an important determinant for efficient coding of sensory input. We used three types of videos, which differed concerning their spatial and temporal entropies, used as measure of predictability, but also concerning their meaningfulness, to examine the contributions of different regions in processing dynamic visual information. Hippocampus, being associated with statistical extractions from the input stream (Strange et al., 2005b), could be associated with processing of predictability.

Method:
Experiment: 27 participants (mean age 25.6±3.8 years, 14 females), were shown the different gray-scale videos (movements through a virtual tunnel, corresponding phase-scrambled and pixel-scrambled, i.e., white noise videos) inside the fMRI scanner and were asked to detect the occurrence of a near-threshold color cue presented briefly on the videos.

Entropy calculations: To account for the temporal unfolding of the stimulus, for all the videos spatial and spatiotemporal pixel-wise and word-wise entropies were computed by dividing the videos into sliding blocks of n*n size (n*n*n for spatiotemporal entropy), where n was the word length, and computing the probabilities of each block on the frame/s.

Results: 
Univariate general linear model (p<0.05 FDR corrected): We found stronger BOLD activity in hippocampus for white noise videos (low spatial-temporal predictability) when compared to the more predictable tunnel or phase-scrambled videos. In the parahippocampus higher activity was found in response to tunnel videos as compared to noise or phase-scrambled videos. The dorsal stream also showed stronger activity for tunnel videos as compared to noise or phase-scrambled videos. 

Multivariate result: Partial-Least-Squares (PLS) correlations were used to examine the relationship between brain activity and entropy of the videos. The entropy timeline for each run was created and then compared with the preprocessed voxel-wise brain recordings over time for each subject. Multivariate PLS analysis showed strong positive weights bilaterally in the hippocampus for higher values of entropy (p<0.001, n = 27, T=5.6). 

Discussion:
Predictability of the visual input stream is reflected in cortical activity, and these regions, that react vigorously to it, could be associated with prediction error. Hippocampus is sensitive to probabilistic context of visual stream and hence can modulate the balancing of top-down and bottom-up sensory cortical hierarchy.
title: Cortical and hippocampal activations in response to visual spatial-temporal uncertainties

text: Synapses of cortical neurons display ongoing changes, even in the absence of an explicit learning paradigm (e.g. [1]). How does this volatility in structural connections affect the functional properties of cortical circuits? Here, we address this question in a model of population activity in mouse auditory cortex, to interpret ongoing parallel experiments employing chronic two-photon imaging in the auditory cortex of awake mice. Previous experiments found that neural population responses to brief complex sounds often cluster into a discrete set of activity patterns, which were predictive of discrimination performance and spontaneous categorization of sounds in behaving mice [2]. Such discrete representations could provide a high degree of robustness against fluctuations in synaptic strengths. Here, we use a circuit model to study the emergence of activity cluster states and their structural stability in the presence of synaptic turnover. We show that the model displays basic response properties of population activity in mouse auditory cortex, including a skewed distribution of neural firing rates and a clustering of broad sound categories into non-linear population responses. This holds over a parameter regime where recurrent connections are sufficiently heterogeneous and the network is dominated by inhibition. We use this model to study systematically the impact of synaptic turnover on collective response properties. We find that a similar response stability as observed in experiment requires changes of inhibitory synapses to be orders of magnitude slower than changes of excitatory synapses. Furthermore we find that gradual changes in the circuitry result in plateaus of stable collective response modes with abrupt transitions between them. Our model suggests that synaptic volatility may affect sensory representations in a highly nonlinear fashion.
title: Stability of sensory representations in the presence of synaptic turnover

text:
We propose a prototype of a wearable device which aims to assist the visually impaired orienting and avoiding objects by optically finding obstacles in the nearby environment and creating acoustic warning signals. Instead of conventional cameras, the system employs two dynamic vision sensors (DVS, [1]) for visual input. DVS are biologically inspired sensors which work in a way analogous to mammal eyes: the pixels operate independently from each other and trigger so called events whenever they sense a change in brightness. This asynchronous mode of operation results in a low latency visual information (about 10 us) as well as in a low data rate: only pixels that undergo an illumination change produce data, whereas no data is generated in areas where nothing happens.
These properties of the DVS allow the deployment of a precise real-time depth extraction and obstacle detection algorithm which uses the combined event streams of two DVS in a stereo setup. 
The depth information is then translated into a spatial sound at the position of each obstacle using personalized head-related transfer functions. Using such individual sounds a 3D-soundscape is generated that acoustically represents the environment to the user in an easy to interpret way [2].
The system requires only light-weight computation which is supposed to be ultimately done completely on-board the mobile device [3]. The envisioned assistant will allow hands-free navigation and independent orientation.
title: A wearable mobility assistant to help the blind navigate autonomously

text:
Recent experimental progress have made it possible to record from large populations of neurons in sensory structures. However, the high number of neurons raises a major challenge to understand how a neural network processes sensory information. A classical characterization of each single neuron only gives a fragmented view of the network processing. Probing the statistical relationship between stimuli and population responses thus requires new tools suited for the analysis of large populations of neurons.

Here we developed a new method to characterize the sensitivity of a population of sensory neurons to the stimulus, and applied it to the retina. We recorded large populations of retinal output neurons (200 neurons) in rats, while presenting a randomly moving object as a visual stimulus [Field 2010, Marre 2012]. To assess the sensitivity of population coding to changes in the trajectory, we tested the impact of different stimulus perturbations on the retinal response, and searched actively for the perturbation sizes well discriminated by the retina, during the time course of the experiment (online). During these closed-loop experiments, the stimulus was modified in real time as a function of the recorded response to find the smallest perturbations that were effective at changing the population response. 

To assess the discrimination capacity of the neural population from these data, we estimated the Fisher Information Matrix [Brunel 1997]. This matrix quantifies the change in the neural activity in response to stimulus perturbations. So it quantifies the network sensitivity of the neural population along any direction in the stimulus space, and it determines how strong a perturbation should be in order to be distinguished from the reference stimulus. 

Our results show an unexpected network sensitivity of the retinal population to high temporal frequencies of the stimulus. We are currently investigating how this network sensitivity is built up from the selectivity of individual neurons. 

Moreover, as can be shown by Bayesian Inversion Theorem, the network sensitivity lower-bounds the error of any stimulus decoder based on the ganglion cells response, thus allowing the evaluation of the decoder performance. As an example, we show that linear decoder [Warland 1997, Marre 2015] is not an optimal way to retrieve information about the stimulus.
title: Characterizing the retina's sensitivity to stimulus perturbations using closed-loop experiments and Fisher information.

text: Perception highly benefits from multisensory combination in the human brain. Bayesian Decision Theory has bestowed a revolutionary methodology to model the underlying process of multisensory and sensorimotor combination in a wide range of perceptual decision tasks [1]. Given the partially reliable sensory signals caused by a single source, a Bayesian observer estimates the state of the environment by minimizing a cost function (e.g. Mean Square Error) over the trials, and fusing noisy signals into a single estimate. But in the real world we are constantly surrounded by multiple objects and therefore by multiple sources of information. Thus besides sensor fusion, segregating information conveyed by separate sources plays a vital role in perception. For instance we never combine the sound of mewing with the picture of a dog. Taking into account all possible existing hypotheses in the environment and the problem of whether to fuse information or not involves a probabilistic process called Causal Inference [2]. It is not yet fully understood where and through which mechanism Causal Inference emerges in the brain [3]. A recent fMRI study on human performing audio-visual localization has shed some light on this problem and shows that a hierarchical distributed circuit along parietal and early sensory cortices likely performs the whole process [4]. To validate this hypothesis by using a probabilistic neural approach, we propose a distributed hierarchical circuit that can perform probabilistic Causal Inference. The proposed model can successfully reproduce human psychophysical data in audio-visual perceptual decision. When auditory and visual stimuli are largely spatially inconsistent, the fusion pathway is inhibited with higher probability, implying the fact that signals are likely caused by separate sources. The model also predicts the role of sensory likelihood, spatial discrepancy, and importantly the prior probability of the causal structure, in the spatial binding window. Basically, less uncertainty in sensory likelihood shrinks the binding window or equally sensitizes the subject to discriminate common-source or separate-sources hypothesis. In this poster, we first present an optimal neural solution for fusion and probabilistic decision. The proposed model for Causal inference basically instantiates these circuits in a parallel hierarchy. Finally we simulate and compare the behavior of the overall model with statistical generative model of human subjects.
title: Probabilistic Causal Inference in Multisensory Perception, a distributed hierarchical model

text:
For many people, the first indication they might have a hearing problem comes from difficulties they experience following conversations in background noise. Often, however, their audiogram – the ‘gold-standard’ test of hearing function – indicates normal or near-normal hearing thresholds. Recently, hearing problems not evident in the audiogram have been linked to cochlear synaptopathy, a form of damage to the synaptic contact between the hair cells in the cochlea and the auditory nerve fibres (ANFs). Synaptopathy through noise exposure and ageing effectively disconnects a substantial fraction of ANFs from the hair cells (Kujawa and Liberman, 2009; Sergeyenko et al., 2013), and high-threshold ANFs – fibres activated only by relatively loud sounds – appear particularly vulnerable (Furman et al., 2013). Referred to colloquially as ‘hidden hearing loss’ (HHL), the detrimental effects of peripheral synaptopathy could contribute to tinnitus (Schaette and McAlpine, 2011) and impact on complex listening tasks such as processing speech in background noise.

Here, we demonstrate in the midbrain of gerbils exposed to a single, controlled noise insult, and in human listeners, evidence of increased neural gain in the central auditory pathways, indicative of damage to high-threshold ANFs. In noise-exposed gerbils, we found that neural responses recorded from the inferior colliculus were higher than in control animals for speech stimuli at 60, but not at 75 dB SPL. Moreover, in the noise-exposed animals, discrimination performance for 60-dB SPL ‘vowel-consonant-vowel’ stimuli (VCVs) in background noise (speech-shaped, +12 to -12 dB signal-to-noise ratio) was higher than for 75 dB SPL VCVs, whereas in control animals the opposite relation was observed, with better performance at 75 dB SPL. A similar pattern was evident in human listeners, where a marker for HHL in the auditory brainstem response (ratio of wave V (generated by the midbrain) to wave I (generated by the auditory nerve)) showed a significant negative correlation to the change in listening performance when the intensity of the background noise was increased from 60 to 80 dB SPL. The data are consistent with the hypothesis that reduced neural output from the cochlea at higher sound levels increases central gain through homeostatic mechanisms that seek to normalize neural activity, which could explain differences in listening performance in different levels of background noise.
title: Quiet is the new loud: Insights into the effects of hidden hearing loss on listening performance in noise

text:
Hippocampal place cells fire at a particular location within an animal's environment (place field) and are therefore thought to be crucial for successful spatial orientation and navigation. Information from multiple sensory modalities is integrated by the hippocampus in order to form an unambiguous representation of space. How exactly sensory inputs contribute to form such a neuronal place map is however unclear.

To investigate the relative contribution of visual and locotomotor inputs on place cell activity, we recorded extracellularly from the hippocampus of behaving Mongolian gerbils (Meriones unguiculatus). Recordings were done in a virtual reality setup, while animals ran on a virtual linear corridor by rotating an air-suspended sphere. By altering the gain factor between the movement of the sphere and the speed of the visual projection on a single trial basis, we could decouple visually perceived movement from the animal's locomotion. Place cells in CA3 responded differentially to such closed loop manipulation.  One subset of place cells formed its field based on visual information within the virtual environment, independent of the distance travelled by the animal. Such visually driven place fields predominantly occur at visual texture changes within the virtual corridor.  A second subset of place cells relied predominantly on locomotor inputs, as place fields remain at the same running distance on a single trial basis, independent of the visual scene. A third subset of cells exhibited two place fields, where in most cases each field was driven by one of the two different modalities.

As a population both types of place cells formed modality-specific maps that were simultaneously represented in the hippocampus. This notion is corroborated by the fact that place field firing was adjusted on a single trial basis without adaptive processes required. Our results therefore indicate that the hippocampus preserves information from distinct processing streams to form coexisting space representations. These coexisting sensory maps could then be linked on a population level in order to form a multisensory association of spatial location or other information important to the animal.
title: Simultaneous representations of space for two different sensory modalities in hippocampal CA3

text: The estimation of physical magnitudes, including temporal intervals, induces characteristic errors that likely result from an error minimization strategy. Such an effort to optimize estimates should take into account both external and internal influences. External factors are, for example, the range of stimulus magnitudes and stimulus modality; internal factors are, for instance, determined by an individual's discrimination abilities. To evaluate both contributions we developed a computational model that formulates magnitude estimation as two stages of noisy integration that are linked by a reference memory. This reference is iteratively built up and thereby estimates the moments of the stimulus distribution. The model reproduces characteristic properties of magnitude estimation. Most importantly, it identifies the regression effect as a means of minimizing estimation errors. With help of the model we tackle the question in how far rodents and humans use an optimal strategy to estimate temporal intervals. We performed interval timing experiments with Mongolian gerbils (Meriones unguiculatus) and humans and tested timing of intervals lasting several seconds. Stimuli were chosen from different ranges to modulate external influences. Based on this experimental data, we investigate in detail the dependence of interval timing on stimulus statistics and an individual's discrimination abilities.
title: Do rodents and humans optimally estimate temporal intervals?

text:
Neural processing of temporal information underlies many of our cognitive abilities. Recent studies report neuronal activity correlated with interval timing in brain areas such as hippocampus, striatum, prefrontal cortex, and parietal cortex. Single neurons in those areas display a multitude of activity profiles across a stimulus interval from transiently active to monotonically increasing, or decreasing [1], and scale with changes in stimulus duration [2]. Collectively, the neurons provide a population signal encoding temporal stimuli [3]. Timing in those experiments is typically investigated with tasks that only test for specific intervals or for discrimination between two groups of intervals. Estimation on a continuum of intervals has rarely been investigated (see Ref. 4 for a study in monkeys).
We recorded neural activity in the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) of Mongolian gerbils (Meriones unguiculatus) while the animals measured and reproduced temporal stimuli that were randomly chosen between 3 and 10 seconds. The animals were trained to measure the duration of a visual stimulus, and reproduce it by running for the same duration in a virtual reality. Single neurons responded differently during measurement and reproduction. While some were strongly active in only one of the task phases, others responded during both. In both task phases, the cells exhibited diverse firing patterns. Similar to previous studies we found neurons that were transiently active, or monotonically decreased or increased their firing. Responses were adapted to the particular interval presented in the current trial. 
Our findings provide the first description of how single neurons in the rodent brain contribute to measuring and reproducing temporal intervals. How these cells act together as a population will be investigated by more detailed analyses.
title: Correlates of measurement and reproduction of temporal intervals in rodent prefrontal cortex

text:
Working memory [1] storage is widely distributed across the neocortex. [2–7] Executive control of working memory storage, however, is thought to be clearly localized in lateral prefrontal cortex. [8] Here, we tested this assumption by using MVPA to trace selection-specific activity patterns which are fundamental components of control processing. In each trial, subjects successively memorized an orientation and the pitch of a tone. A retro-cue later instructed the subjects which stimulus to keep memorizing for an upcoming task. For control, each trial also included an irrelevant pseudo-cue. Importantly, we used multiple cue stimuli to instruct each possible selection (e.g. ‘A’ and ‘1’ for ‘keep memorizing the first stimulus’) to investigate memory control independently of the cue stimulus.

Activity time-courses for trials with early and late selection cues and different cued modalities clearly show that selection cues are affecting sensory stores. A univariate comparison between neural responses to selection cues versus pseudo-cues, however, reveals a wide-spread pattern of activation and deactivation with a marked exclusion of the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex. Multivariate pattern analyses (MVPA [9–11]) furthermore show that selection-specific activity patterns that indicates which item is selected are localized to left superior temporal cortex and not the prefrontal cortex. The prefrontal cortex does however retain the order of stimulus presentation (e.g. ‘visual first’). Our results suggest that selection of a memorized item is controlled in a decentralized fashion while the prefrontal cortex provides necessary temporal order information.

text: The simulation of large-scale spiking neural networks to investigate models of the brain is an ongoing challenge, as models get more and more complex and increase in size. To address this problem several neural simulators were developed, some of them being suitable for simulation of spiking neural networks on GPUs, for instance GeNN [1], CARLSim3 [2] and NCS 6 [3], showing high speedups for hundreds of thousands of neurons compared to a single-threaded CPU. ANNarchy [4] offers an equation based interface for the definition of spiking and rate-coded neural networks in Python, the latter one already supported on GPUs. ANNarchy uses a full code generation  approach, so the implementation codes can be optimized for individual models or detected hardware. In particular it is important to address load-balancing problems, e.g. due to varying amount of synaptic events. In the work presented here we show GPU-based code generation for the fast simulation of spiking neural networks in ANNarchy. We show the achieved speedups on typical benchmarks, such as the COBA [5] network and pulse-coupled networks using Izhikevich neurons using different network sizes and address limits of GPU computations.
title: ANNarchy: spiking neural networks on GPUs
