text: Transcranial brain stimulation and evidence of ephaptic coupling have recently sparked strong interests in understanding the effects of weak electric fields on the dynamics of brain networks and of coupled populations of neurons (Reato et al. 2010 , Anastassiou et al. 2011). The collective dynamics of large neuronal populations can be efficiently studied using single-compartment (point) model neurons of the integrate-and-fire (IF) type as their elements. These models, however, lack the dendritic morphology required to biophysically describe the effect of an extracellular electric field on the neuronal membrane voltage. Here, we extend the IF point neuron models to accurately reflect morphology dependent electric field effects extracted from a canonical spatial ``ball-and-stick'' (BS) neuron model. Even in the absence of an extracellular field, neuronal morphology by itself strongly affects the cellular response properties (Ostojic et al 2015). We, therefore, derive additional components for leaky and nonlinear IF neuron models to reproduce the subthreshold voltage and spiking dynamics of the BS model exposed to both fluctuating somatic and dendritic inputs and an extracellular electric field. We show that an oscillatory electric field causes spike rate resonance, or equivalently, pronounced spike to field coherence. Its resonance frequency depends on the location of the synaptic background inputs. For somatic inputs the resonance appears in the beta and gamma frequency range, whereas for distal dendritic inputs it is shifted to even higher frequencies. Irrespective of an external electric field, the presence of a dendritic cable attenuates the subthreshold response at the soma to slowly-varying somatic inputs while implementing a low-pass filter for distal dendritic inputs. Our point neuron model extension is straightforward to implement and is computationally much more efficient compared to the original BS model. It is well suited for studying the dynamics of large populations of neurons with heterogeneous dendritic morphology with (and without) the influence of weak external electric fields.
title: Extending integrate-and-fire model neurons to account for the effects of weak electric fields and input filtering mediated by the dendrite

text:
Normal neural population activity and information encoding in the hippocampus can be modeled with ring attractors dynamics[1], but this representation has not yet been linked to pathological hippocampus activity such as temporal lobe epileptic seizures.
In this study, we wanted to investigate under which conditions these dynamic models can develop oscillatory activities characteristic of the temporal lobe epilepsy. In particular, we focused on the influence of the synaptic connectivity[2][3]. We performed the analysis of networks consisting in one or two rings of excitatory or inhibitory rate model neurons with piece-wise linear activation functions and spatially symmetric synaptic connections. We evaluated their stability under constant input current considering either the role of the real/complex eigenvalues of the system or the role of the switches dues to the nonlinearity of its activation functions. 
Our main results are that : (1) single-ring networks cannot oscillate, neither due to their eigenvalues nor due the nonlinearity of their activation functions, and (2) two-ring networks have more complex dynamics that enable them to exhibit either normal or pathological activity, depending on their connectivity. In particular, switches proveoked by the nonllinear activation functions can cause these systems to present a limit cycle.  
We then verified our predictions using network simulations, for different synaptic connection range and different input levels. In the case of two-ring networks, we observed that networks with only short-range synaptic connections were stable for all inputs, thus describing  healthy hippocampus activity, whereas networks with unbalanced connections could oscillate for certain input levels, while remaining stable for others, thus representing plausible epileptic networks.
title: Oscillation analysis of ring networks : application on epileptic hippocampus

text:
By means of which 'code' do neuronal networks represent and propagate information accumulated about prior inputs? We investigated necessary and sufficient conditions for the self-organized emergence of rank-order-based coding schemes, such that input information is encoded in the spike order of a certain subset of privileged neurons. Such schemes provide a natural way to concisely represent and readily propagate information within and between networks.
As a sufficient condition, we present an unstructured network of leaky integrate-and-fire units, sparsely and randomly connected by dynamical conductance synapses. Such a recurrent network expresses privileged neurons ('pioneer neurons'), whose discharge order represents up to 90 % of the input information received prior to a spontaneous synchronization event (‘network spike’). As a necessary condition, we identify a certain degree of heterogeneity of (random) connectivity. Fully homogeneous random (Erdös-Rényi) networks express only few ‘pioneer neurons’. We demonstrate this by analytically predicting spike latencies in arbitrary recurrent networks, given only connection topology and neuron and synapse parameters. This in turn determines the number of ‘pioneer neurons’ and the amount of information represented prior to a synchronization event. Our results underline the functional importance of network heterogeneity, complementing other properties that have received more attention in the literature (small-worldness, scale-freeness, or hub-richness).
Further studies of modular networks with heterogeneous modules demonstrate that the information encoded by ‘pioneer neurons’ is readily propagated between modules.
title: Unstructured Network Topology Begets Privileged Neurons and Rank-order Representation

text:
The spiking behavior and subthreshold dynamics of single neurons is successfully reproduced by the adaptive exponential integrate-and-fire (aEIF) model [1]. It describes the fast dynamics of the neuronal membrane voltage influenced by slowly decaying potassium currents which cause spike-rate adaptation. Assuming that the timescales of these two dynamics are separable, an infinitely large population of aEIF neurons subject to fluctuating synaptic inputs can be described deterministically in terms of the time-varying probability density of its membrane voltage using the Fokker-Planck equation complemented by a non-standard reinjection mechanism [2,3]. In order to capture dynamical features exclusively present in populations of (realistic) finite size, so called finite-size effects, this approach needs to be extended.
In this work, we first present a numerical scheme based on a finite volume method that efficiently solves the Fokker-Planck equation for infinitely large populations. Subsequently, in order to model finite-size effects, the equation is extended by a stochastic source term which acts on the reinjection mechanism [4].  Finally, the reproduction accuracy of the developed method is evaluated using Monte-Carlo simulations, showing that it is able to reproduce spike-rate distributions and non-trivial patterns in the power-spectra of spike-rate time series. We further discuss how the method can give valuable insights into the role of finite-size noise for the switching behavior between different stable network states.
title: A stochastic Fokker-Planck equation for the dynamics of finite-sized neuronal populations

text:
The stimulation of a single cell in the barrel cortex can influence the behavior of an awake rat [1]. This experimental finding is highly surprising and is theoretically unexplained. 

We investigate the effects of single-cell stimulation on a realistically-sized random network of integrate-and-fire neurons [2] in which the synaptic weights are exponentially distributed [3]. We propose a simple scheme for the network readout that is able to detect the occurrence of single-cell stimulation with a reliability comparable to the experimental results.  These findings are obtained by simulations and analytical estimates and are robust for a wide range of values of the recurrent coupling strength.
title: Detectability of single-cell stimulation in large spiking neural networks

text: Dendritic trees are easily identified by eye, but the precise set of features that make them so recognisable is generally not quite so obvious. The analysis of branching statistics has  been developed to quantify the complex morphology of a dendritic tree and permit categorisation [1]. Previous studies have found extensive correlations between different branching parameters; but have often been constrained by relatively sparse data, limited to a few classes of cell. In addition, it is not at all clear which parameters are most important across the full range of cell classes. We take a new approach, using the insights gained from generative models of synthetic dendrites [2] to analytically develop new branching metrics and catalogue their relationships and dependencies. We are able to investigate how much dendritic structure arises as a function of connectivity, finding that the majority of morphological characteristics are related closely to a cell’s inputs. A large number of neuronal classes can therefore be defined by the volume that their dendrites span, with geometrically regular areas approximating these well. This work, alongside the new tools presented in parallel that allow easy manipulation of the entire NeuroMorpho.org database [3], will enable us to rigorously define a new framework to discuss dendritic morphology.
title: Geometrical and topological features of dendritic branching: Analytical results

text:
Spikes in sensory neurons results from the integration of a time-ordered stimulus and the contribution of pre-synaptic neurons in the network. These spikes are conveyed collectively to the cortex using correlated  (in space and time) patterns of spikes that constitute the “neural code”. Since spikes patterns occur irregularly, but highly structured, both within and over repeated trials of stimuli, it is appropriate to characterize them using probabilistic descriptions or statistical models. To analyze the spike train statistics, there has been two mayor approaches: The maximum entropy principle (MaxEnt) and Neuronal network modeling.

MaxEnt models have been extensively used to try and explain statistics of spike trains in experimental data. Although they are usually constrained by the hypothesis of stationarity and usually limited to synchronous pairwise interactions, far more general extensions exist under the name of Gibbs distributions. Gibbs distributions afford time-delayed interactions (i.e. they allow to handle memory and causality) [1,2], non stationarity, n-neurons interactions; they even allow conditioning upon the future (closely related to the notion of anticipation). However, the classical formulation of Gibbs distribution with a potential summing all possible interactions leads rapidly to an exponentially increasing number of terms, intractable on numerical and practical grounds. In this poster we show that this approach, relying upon statistical physics and thermodynamics wisdom is not optimal. On the opposite, as we show, classical neuronal networks model, such the leaky-integrate and fire with a time dependent stimulus, exhibit a closed form potential, which is an explicit non linear function of synaptic weights and stimulus [3].  This potential can be expressed in the usual form of a sum of n-neurons interactions, but, as we show, the corresponding  coefficients are non linear functions of the synaptic weights and stimulus. Thus, the classical sumation of interactions, on which MaxEnt model is grounded, leads to a plethora of redundant terms and a huge and artificial spread of dimensionality. Moreover, e.g. pairwise interactions are not easily related to synaptic interactions, as they also depend on the stimulus [4]. Additionally, it allows to anticipate the effects of slight variations in the stimulus (which can be time dependent) on the spike correlations, using linear response theory.
title: Spike train description and Gibbs distributions

text:
The use of whole-brain networks for understanding the dynamics of the interaction between brain regions has experienced a rise in popularity in the last few years. Here, we calibrate a whole-brain network model to human resting state data, and use it to explore the effects of weak electric fields on the network dynamics.

The structural connectivity of the brain network is extracted from parcellated brain scans using an atlas with 68 regions (Desikan et al., 2006) and DTI tractography of long-range axons to estimate coupling strengths and delays between regions averaged over 48 individuals (Ritter et al. 2013, Schirner et al. 2015). The mean activity of each brain region is described by a mean-field population model of EIF neurons (Ladenbauer, 2015). After fitting local parameters such as recurrent coupling strengths and delays and the global parameters coupling strength, axonal signal transmission speed and external noise intensity, our model can produce simulated BOLD functional connectivity (FC) with high Pearson correlation (mean .55, max/min .78/.25) to the empirical 20 minute resting state BOLD FC of these individuals. A local model with a limit cycle at gamma frequencies and a bistability with a low and a high-activity fixed point was found to produce good fits.

A range of global parameters can produce good grand average FC fits. However, the FC in the resting state is not stationary. To capture the brain's dynamical properties in the resting state, the FC fit is complemented by a fit of the FCD matrix (Hansen et al, 2015). We show that the simulated FCD matrix is well comparable to empirical data (Kolmogorov distance around 0.1) on several timescales. Clustering of the power spectra of the local nodes shows that nodes of the brain graph can be divided into two sets with dominant alpha and gamma frequencies respectively and that contralateral regions end up in the same cluster.

Lastly, we present results of modeling the effect of external tACS-like brain stimulation on the global network activity. By modifying the dynamics of a subset of nodes, the global dynamics of the brain network can be shaped. We stimulate the bilateral entorhinal cortices, the main interface of the cortex to Hippocampus. We show that on the global network level, transitions from a DOWN state to an UP state tend to lock on the onset of oscillatory stimulation and relate these results to experimental findings in the rat brain conducted in Ref. (Battaglia et al, 2004).
title: Simulating large-scale human brain networks using a mean-field model of EIF neurons: exploring resting state FC and stimulation with electric fields

text: Slow rhythms of activity (~1 Hz) are a universal hallmark of slow-wave sleep and deep anesthesia across many animal species. A remarkably reproducible default mode with a low degree of complexity which opens a window on the brain multiscale organization, on top of which cognitive functions emerge during wakefulness. Understanding how such transition takes place starting from the characterization of a stereotyped state like the slow-wave activity [1], might shade light on the emergence of the rich repertoire of neuronal dynamics underlying brain computation. Sleep-wake transition is a widely studied phenomenon [2], however it is still debated how brain state changes occur. Here we show from intracortical recordings in anesthetized rats, that sleep-like rhythms fade out when wakefulness is approached giving rise to an alternation between slow Up/Down oscillations and awake-like activity periods. This phase of activity pattern bistability is captured by a mean-field rate-based model of a cortical column, in which for a transient range of anesthesia levels the coexistence of two metastable attractor states emerges. Alternation between these two states is granted by the ongoing competition of local features and exogenous modulations governing both the excitability and the fatigue level of the modeled column. Our results highlight a brain state transition which is not a continuous smooth change but rather a progressive modulation of the stability of two coexistent activity regimes, which in turn leave different fingerprints across cortical columns. Guided by this mean-field model, spiking neuron networks are devised to reproduce the electrophysiological changes displayed during the transition.
title: Multistable attractor dynamics in columnar cortical networks transitioning from deep anesthesia to wakefulness.

text:
Spontaneous activity in visual cortex has been found to resemble the spatially organized responses to oriented stimuli [1]. We wondered if and how this finding can be reconciled with the hypothesis that cortex mainly performs optimal inference [2-4]. The latter is based on the idea that the brain organizes sensory information into an efficient representation of the outside world: neurons receive noisy and unreliable inputs, accumulate evidence over time and compete with each other to build sparse representations of the stimuli.
This would be equivalent to inferring the most probable features of the stimulus that may cause an input from sensory neurons, while minimizing a sparsity measure. Models of visual cortex developed within this framework [3, 4] use features that are localized in space. As a consequence, they are not able to account for the spatial correlations and high-order statistics of natural images.
We propose a spiking network that extends the architecture of these models, by combining it with a term that links different locations of the visual space in an associative manner. In our model each hyper-column implements a sparse coding module [2] that alone would produce an optimal local representation of the stimulus. These representations are then interacting with all other hyper-columns via long range connections. In particular, similar orientations are positively coupled so that evidence of a cause in one location provides evidence of the same cause in others. The model maintains its optimal inference property, building robust representations of visual scenes from the information contained in localized image patches, thereby exploiting prior knowledge about spatial correlations in natural scenes.
Without external input and driven only with noise, the system exhibits a spontaneous dynamics highly structured in space and time. Activity patterns that closely resemble orientation maps emerge, as observed in [1]: when a cortical state occurs, it spans different hyper-columns and switching between states is continuous, i.e. activity patterns close in time correspond to similar orientations. While reproducing the experimental findings, the network maintains low firing rates and large variability typical of spontaneous activity.
In the future, this will allows us to explore and quantify the impact of electrical stimulation (e.g. for visual cortex prosthesis) on a cortical network and to investigate its interaction with information processing.
title: Ongoing activity in a spiking network of visual cortical columns representing local optimal inference modules

text:
Synaptic interactions fundamentally underly the dynamics and function of neural circuits. Advances in multi-unit and multi-neuron monitoring technologies stimulated the development of frameworks to infer connectivity from recordings of spiking activity. Yet, existing frameworks either identify functional or causal interactions among neurons [1, 2] that often disagree with synaptic connections, or rely on assumptions on the underlying nonlinear dynamics that are hardly known beforehand [3, 4, 5, 6].
Here, we propose a model independent approach for inferring synaptic connectivity of neural networks from spike trains alone. By introducing a mapping from the time series representation of neural recordings to high-dimensional event spaces, we successfully recover the synaptic connections. We thereby uniquely identify the incoming synaptic connectivity of each observed neuron, capturing also whether they are excitatory or inhibitory. Furthermore, we recover approximate delay times by an optimisation in the space of delays. These results suggest that synaptic connectivity and interaction delays may be effectively recovered from multiple spike train recordings alone.
title: Connectomics through nonlinear dynamics?

text:
Recently, many research groups have focused on the inference of networks from data such as brain networks from observed electroencephalography or functional magnetic resonance imaging data. In the example of the brain, this promises to disclose information about how the brain processes signals and how alterations thereof cause specific diseases. A key hypothesis is that important characteristics are not specific to individual subjects but rather common in a given population. This is reflected by the fact that brain networks but also other networks are typically classi ed into main prototypic networks, i.e., Erdos-Renyi, Small World and Scale Free Networks.
In the Inverse Problem, the challenge is to infer the network topology from data. Two challenges are particularly relevant: (i) to reliably obtain the links in the network once the nodes have been fixed, (ii) to use the characteristics above to uniquely determine the type of network. For oscillatory systems several cutting-edge methods have been suggested in the literature to address problem (i). Usually these techniques rely on statistical inference. The correct reconstruction of networks is therefore hampered by mis-estimation of links due to statistical uncertainties, unobserved processes, noise contamination to name just a few. Mis-estimated links in a network typically alter the key characteristics; this makes it particularly difficult to infer the correct type of network and it is the challenge of problem (ii).
We investigate to which extent classical statistical approaches to estimate links in a network are reliable; furthermore, we investigate if common rules of type I and type II errors should be modi ed to achieve a reliable inference of the correct type of network. Our approach is based on the topological analysis of the detected networks taking into account the role of two important parameters: false positive and false negative decisions about the presence and absence of links.
We present simulation results which indicate that standard alpha values for statistical inference are suboptimal when for instance the vertex degree distribution is to be estimated. We suggest a novel procedure to optimally balance false positive and negative conclusions. This enables us to obtain, e.g., the best estimate for the average shortest path length or degree distribution for a given analysis technique.
title: Improving Brain Networks Inference

text: We show that self-consistent partial synchrony in globally coupled oscillatory ensembles is a general phenomenon. We analyse in detail appearance and stability properties of this state in possibly the simplest setup of a biharmonic Kuramoto-Daido phase model as well as demonstrate the effect in limit-cycle relaxational Rayleigh oscillators. Such a regime extends the notion of splay state from an uniform distribution of phases to an oscillating one. The inhomogeneity of the distribution can be detected as a non-zero macroscopic mean field. The characteristic and most peculiar property of partial synchrony is the difference between the frequencies of single units and that of the macroscopic field.
title: A minimal model of partial synchrony

text: A single neuron is categorized as "multisensory'' if there is a statistically significant difference between the response evoked by a cross-modal stimulus combination and that evoked by the most effective of its components individually. The most widely applied quantitative index expresses multisensory enhancement (or inhibition) as a proportion of the strongest unisensory response. However, it has no theoretical foundation in terms of the possible operations a neuron may perform in combining unisensory inputs to yield the multisensory response. In particular, being responsive to multiple sensory modalities does not guarantee that a neuron has actually engaged in integrating its multiple sensory inputs rather than simply responding to the most salient stimulus. Here, a new index is proposed based on a (maximal negatively) dependent probability summation mechanism. It compares the mean observed cross-modal response of a neuron, defined as the absolute number of spikes within a time interval after stimulus presentation,  with the largest cross-modal mean achievable by stochastically coupling its unisensory responses. Because this new measure is, in general, more restrictive than the traditional one, many neurons previously categorized as "multisensory'' may possibly lose that property. The approach is illustrated by data from 27 recording sessions of cat superior colliculus neurons. A significant difference (bootstrapped confidence intervals) was found in all but four of the sessions. Computation of the new index is straightforward and it is as amenable to statistical testing as the traditional one. The new measure is applicable to multisensory neurons of any kind. The same logic of finding a benchmark can be applied to the “additive model”, predicting the largest achievable sum of the unimodal responses. Moreover, it is completely analogous to a widely-used procedure in behavioral studies of multisensory integration ("race model inequality''). Possible extension to more complex structures is also discussed.
title: A New Measure of Multisensory Integration in a Single Neuron Based on Coupling

text:
Synaptic kinetics is known to play a central role in the generation of oscillations in networks of inhibitory in-terneurons. A large body of computational work has shown that inhibitory networks of spiking neurons with synaptic kinetics generate oscillations in the gamma range via collective synchronization [1-4]. This neuronal mechanism is commonly referred to as ING (interneuronal gamma). Interestingly, these collective oscillations disappear for broad enough distributions of heterogeneity.
Here we thoroughly analyze the emergence of collective synchronization via the ING mechanism by means of a novel firing rate model with first order synaptic kinetics (FRM). This three dimensional FRM is exactly derived form a network of quadratic integrate and fire neurons and, in sharp contrast with heuristic firing rate models, it is capable to describe states with spike synchronization [5]. Linear stability analysis of the FRM shows that the asynchronous state loses stability at a (supercritical) Hopf bifurcation, leading to a partially synchronized state. The Hopf stability boundaries are analytically obtained, and reveal a closed region in parameter space where ING oscillations are observed. Consistent with previous numerical studies [1-3], collective synchronization is observed for intermediate values of the ratio of synaptic and membrane time constants, and for intermediate values of the inhibitory coupling. The region of oscillations progressively shrinks as the degree of heterogeneity is increased, and ceases to exist beyond a precise value of the quenched disorder. The results remain qualitatively the same considering second order synaptic kinetics, i.e. alpha synapses.
title: Synchronization in firing rate models with synaptic kinetics

text: To better understand the relationship between connectivity and function in the brain at different scales, in this work we show the results of using point-neuron network simulations to complement connectivity information from whole brain simulations based on a dynamic neuron mass model. In our multiscale approach, we simulate a whole brain parcellated into 68 regions using a setup similar to that described in Deco et al. 2014 [1]. Each region is modeled as a dynamic neuron mass, and in parallel, we also model each region as small point-neuron populations in NEST [2]. Structural plasticity in NEST is then used to calculate the inner  inhibitory connectivity required to match experimentally observed firing-rate behavior. An interactive tool was developed for steering the structural plasticity algorithm and bring all regions, which are also highly interconnected, to their ideal firing activity. An inner inhibition fitting was first proposed in the work by Deco et al. [1] using an iterative tuning method. In our work, we allow the point-neuron network to self-generate the connectivity using simple homeostatic rules and then we feed this information to the dynamic mass model simulation. With the resulting connectivity data from the NEST simulations and experimentally obtained DTI inter-region connectivity, simulations of the whole brain producing results comparable to experimental fMRI data are possible. Using this approach, the fitting and parameter space exploration times are reduced and a new way to explore the impact of connectivity in function at different scales is presented.
title: Multiscale approach to explore the relationships between connectivity  and function in whole brain simulations

text:
We used juxtacellular nano stimulation, a technique which allows stimulation of identified single neurons in vivo, in order to drive pyramidal cells in anesthetized rat motor cortex and senso-motoric cortex.
We found that stimulating with fluctuating stimuli (frozen bandpass-limited white noise) results in increased spike time reliability.
Once we have measured the neurons response function we were also able to generate spike trains with prescribed spike times that could be generated with similar precision as the neurons intrinsic reliability.
When analyzing spike train statistics like input output cross spectra and the spectral coherence function we find a sustained support of high frequencies (several times the firing rate).
We explored how well the spike trains as well as statistics like the power spectra and input output statistics can be captured by a model neuron.
In particular we used the classical one compartment exponential integrate-and-fire neuron, a simple model that has been successfully applied for reproducing spike times of pyramidal cells under noisy current stimulation in vitro and compare its performance to a spatially extended two compartment model which accounts for the dendritic load.
In agreement with previous studies we found the extended neuron model to better support the high frequency coding.
Thus we could reproduce our experimental data much more accurate with the two compartment model.
title: Juxtacellular stimulation in vivo allows for precise spike time control and reveals high frequency coding

text:
How a population of neurons encodes a signal -- sensory or internal -- is strongly influenced by the activity in other populations. The response of a primary sensory cortex to a bottom-up signal, for instance, is dependent on the top-down input it receives from higher cortical areas. This activity, which is not related to the signal in question, constitutes a background that shapes information transmission.  Background activity varies with the so-called brain state: while for attentive states, asynchronous activity has been reported, it becomes more synchronized during quiet wakefulness and slow-wave sleep, where collective periods of spiking (up states) are interspersed with silent periods (down states).

We study the transmission of a signal by an uncoupled population of leaky-integrate-and fire neurons that are subject to input from a background population. This background is either in an asynchronous regime, in which the firing rate is constant, or undergoes up-down transitions which are modeled by imposing a common backround rate that switches stochastically between high and low values. Our principal finding, obtained through extensive numerical simulations as well as novel analytical approximations, is the following: If the mean background rate is low, more information about the signal is transmitted with an up-down background. We demonstrate that this effect also occurs in a more realistic recurrent network and is robust with respect to the statistics of the up-down switching. Finally, we incorporate into our model that up states, in general, propagate across cortex as traveling waves. We find that this further enhances information transmission and also allows nearly continuous signal transmission.

It has been suggested that the functional role of such up-down regimes lies in the overall reduction in firing rates caused by the down states, which is thought to be important for cellular regeneration [1]. This raises the question why such a reduction is not instead achieved in a manner that maintains asynchronous firing. In this work, we propose that the answer may lie in the consequences the respective regimes have for information transmission: At reduced background rates, redistributing the spikes into up states maintains at least some information transmission capabilities.
title: Up-down-like background spiking can enhance neural information transmission

text:
Neurons express a large variability in the morphology of their dendritic trees and dendrite morphology is known to affect neuronal dynamics and function. This variability is prominently seen across cell types, but even across cells of the same class – no two cells are the same. Thus a number of statistics of dendritic trees were devised (for an overview see e.g. Scorcioni et al, 2008) that are commonly used to compare and distinguish cells and cell classes. 

Here we investigate a number of such statistics using a large sample of reconstructions of real dendritic trees from the NeuroMorpho.org database (Ascoli et al., 2007) containing reconstructions of a wide range of species, brain regions and cell types, as well as reconstructions of mouse neurons taken from the Allen Atlas (Sunkin et al., 2013). To maximize the validity of our conclusions, all reconstructions were manually inspected and reconstructions of low quality were discarded. In particular, we investigate for the first time the relations between statistics of both the geometry and the topology (i.e branching structure) of dendritic trees on such a comprehensive data set and identify interdependencies and scaling laws for the statistics holding across species and cell types.

The analyses were performed using a forthcoming version 2 of the TREES toolbox in Matlab (Cuntz et al., 2010) that greatly facilitates the analysis of populations of dendritic trees and allows to access the NeuroMorpho.org and Allen Atlas data bases directly from the Matlab command line using a newly developed software interface (API). In cooperation with the NeuroMorpho.org team we plan to soon make this API publicly available and thus allow other software to direcly access the full NeuroMorpho.org data set using a convenient query language.

text: How a cortical neuron responds to sensory stimuli is shaped by the activity of its thalamic afferents as well as the short-term dynamics at the thalamocortical (TC) synapses. TC synapses have been shown to be chronically depressed in vivo [1]. However, a recent study revealed that even while being in a depressed state, TC synapses can undergo diverse forms of further short-term plasticity, including facilitation [2]. It remains unclear how these complex synaptic dynamics affect the responses of the target cortical neurons. In this study, we used the NEURON simulation environment to investigate the response properties of cortical cells with different forms of synaptic organizations consistent with the observed synaptic diversity. We found that cells with homogeneous synapse dynamics (i.e. inter-neuron synapse diversity) could be differentially modulated not only by the average firing rate, but also by the temporal pattern of thalamic spike trains. Cells with heterogeneous synapse dynamics (i.e. intra-neuron synapse diversity) showed considerable differences in activity, depending on how well the dynamics of single synapses matched the average firing rates of single thalamic afferents. These results indicate that the short-term dynamics of TC synapses could modify the response properties of cortical cells with respect to information encoded in the temporal structure of thalamic spike trains. Our simulations suggest possible experiments that could lead to a better understanding of how TC synapse plasticity shapes cortical responses to sensory stimulation.
title: Modeling the interplay of thalamic firing properties and short-term plasticity at the thalamocortical synapse

text:
The processing and analysis of natural scenes requires the visual system to integrate localized, distributed image features into global, coherent percepts. A central hypothesis states that our brain uses statistical dependencies in visual scenes: when represented in neural interactions between elementary feature detectors, they will enhance the processing of certain feature conjunctions, while suppressing others. As a neural mechanism realizing these modulatory effects, pairwise interactions between feature detectors in early visual areas have been proposed.
By combining psychophysical experiments with computational modeling and image analysis, we investigated which interaction structures underlie feature integration in visual cortex, and how perception and neural interactions relate to natural scene statistics. 
As stimuli we used grating patch configurations (plaids) comprising four patches with varying orientations (45° / -45°), spatial frequencies (low / high), and inter-patch distances (1° / 2° of visual angle). 
Human detection thresholds for plaids were strongly modulated by inter-patch distance, number of orientation- and frequency-aligned patches and spatial frequency content (low, high, mixed). 
Using a structurally simplistic cortical model comprising orientation columns connected by horizontal axons, we were able to reproduce detection thresholds for all configurations quantitatively. The model consists of 4x4 neural populations, representing all patch configurations per position. Interaction strengths were initialized randomly and optimized by a stochastic gradient descent. We used two approaches, namely (A) having no restrictions on the weight matrix for allowing a maximum number of degrees of freedom (DOF), and (B) imposing a connection structure mirroring physiological and psychophysical evidence with a small number of DOFs. Both approaches yield similar results:  In addition to medium-range inhibition and long-range, orientation-specific excitation, model and experiment predict a novel form of strong orientation-specific, inhibitory interactions between different spatial frequencies. 
For large inter-patch distances, detection thresholds for the plaids were inversely related to their likelihood of occurrence in natural images. However, for small inter-patch distances, natural image statistics can not explain psychophysics, hence suggesting a different functional role of the suppressive interactions observed for small inter-patch distances.
title: Contextual interactions in grating plaid configurations are explained by natural image statistics and neural modeling

text: The mechanisms of neural encoding, storing and retrieving information are intensively under research. Especially, cellular and synaptic mechanisms underlying the dynamics of neurotransmitter release may play a critical role in these processes. In response to high levels of input into neural systems, the firing rate of neural populations may increase and it can in turn also lead to an increase in the firing rate of efferent neural areas. In order to control the level of neural activity, neurons are equipped with molecular and synaptic mechanisms like inhibitory neurons. In this work, we have developed a novel hypothesis explaining the mechanism of controlling neurotransmitter release at different levels of stimulation of neural systems. For this purpose we modelled a fast diffused retrograde signalling in dendrites. The results show the efficiency of designed neural network equipped with retrograde signalling based mechanism that is able to encode different stimulus intensities. The optimal values of dynamical parameters were investigated and used in encoding tasks. The results show high levels of encoding efficiency by applying these optimal values to detect and discriminate pairs of similar intensity of stimuli. This work suggests applying simplified molecular mechanism in the neurons for developing efficient neural systems to perform cognitive and behavioral tasks.
title: Controlling Neurotransmitter Release in an Adaptive Spiking Neural Network Based on Fast-Diffused Retrograde Signalling

text:
Networks of spiking neurons in the balanced state provide a prototype of complex recurrent interactions in biological networks which may give rise to self-generate intrinsic fluctuations. For instance,  an approximate balance between the excitatory and inhibitory input in cortical models introduces fluctuations that can explain the temporal irregular activity in the cortex [1]. Generally, the asymptotic analysis of these networks requires the assumption of the homogeneous randomness of neural connectivity. However, nonrandom and inhomogeneous features of synaptic connectivity are highly presented in local cortical circuits [2]. Here, we derive a unified mean-field theory (MFT) for a recurrent network of binary units with arbitrary connectivity architecture. We identified conditions on the connectivity patterns in which the MFT converges to a deterministic limit. Interestingly, our theory formally extends to both networks with sparse [1] and dense coupling [3] schemes. The mathematical analysis using martingale structures of Markovian dynamics further quantify the aggregate fluctuation of the population firing rate given the system size. We show that for homogeneous networks the diffusion term in the mean-field equation will vanish in the thermodynamical limits. 

We additionally explore the scope of applicability of the MFT under which it does not show a   point-wise convergence. In particular, we investigate a novel dynamical state that the asynchronous spiking of a subset of neurons may lead to stochastic synchronization in the network. This  stochastic synchronization directly results from inhomogeneous coupling micro-structures in the network. This phenomenon resembles non-trivial fluctuations in the average population firing rate which can survive irrespective of the network size. The concise analysis here enables us to represent the mean-field equation for these cases in a form of a stochastic ordinary differential equation.  Our results indicate the essential ingredient for  implementation of connectivity motives such as synfire chains [4] in the general theory of recurrent networks in the balanced state.
title: Phase transition to stochastic synchrony in the balanced networks

text:
Mouse striatal projection neurons (SPNs) recorded under ketamine anesthesia exhibit transitions between depolarized and hyperpolarized membrane potentials known as up- and down-states respectively. It is presumed that the activity during down-states is determined by intracellular processes, whereas the large membrane voltage fluctuations during up-states are a product of increased synaptic input. Because local striatal activity during an up-state is weak, the statistics of the up-state fluctuations mainly reflect cortical feedforward input to the SPNs.

To infer the statistics of the cortical input to SPNs we measured the statistics and spectrum of the membrane potential of SPNs in up- and down-states. The spectrum of the membrane potential reflects the filtering properties of the membrane and can be used to estimate the effective time constant (τeff) of the neuron. Our analysis showed that most of the recorded SPNs have significantly smaller τeff in the up-state than in the down-state, consistent with the assumption that the barrage of synaptic input causes an increase in membrane conductance during the up-state [1].

We demonstrate that the means (μ) of the membrane potential during up-states and their variance in the high-gamma band (σ) varied in a correlated manner (ρ). Using a point neuron model of an SPN and a simplified representation of the cortico-striatal network, we show that this effect in the up-states could be explained if we assume that SPNs receive correlated inputs. 

Across different SPNs we observed high variability in the correlation (ρ) between μ and σ. This variability could arise from the heterogeneity in the neuron morphology, intracellular properties, conductance state of the neurons, synaptic weights and the input rate and correlations. Using a point neuron model, we tested the dependence of ρ on each of these properties. Our analysis showed that the chief factor determining variability of the correlation between μ and σ is the diversity of synaptic weights and input correlations, and that most of the intrinsic properties of SPNs have little, to no effect. This suggests that neuronal heterogeneity could be obscured by the statistics of the synaptic inputs and synaptic weights.

In summary, our analysis allows us to make general inferences about characteristics of correlated synaptic input, such as strength of correlations and input firing rate, based solely on membrane potential recordings of SPNs exhibiting up- and down-states.
title: Estimating characteristics of input correlations to mouse striatal projection neurons that exhibit up- and down-state transitions

text:
Neurons in the primary visual cortex are selective for the orientation of light/dark edges in their receptive fields [1]. In primates and carnivores the preferred orientation of the neurons changes systematically across the cortical surface forming iso-orientation domains ordered around point-like topological defects called pinwheel centers [2]. It is a long standing theoretical prediction that visual cortical circuits are in a state of flux, such that the preferred orientation of the neurons represents a non-equilibrium steady state of circuit turnover [3]. If this prediction is true and multiple steady states coexist, then signatures of the underlying dynamical process should be observable as a rearrangement of the domains over time.

We tested this hypothesis by investigating the occurrence of the largest topological change conceivable in the layout: the generation and annihilation of pinwheel pairs. We conducted acute high accuracy large scale intrinsic signal imaging experiments in 30 ferrets. In 24 of the ferrets we further employed an adapted pairing protocol [4] between imaging sessions to  drive the cortical circuits out of a potential stationary state. To harvest significant topological changes we quantified the certainty of the measurements using re-sampling methods. The probability of pinwheel existence was calculated by tracking their position between bootstrap samples. The accuracy of the estimated orientation preference of individual pixels was computed from their inter-sample tuning distribution. We analyzed the dynamics of 2620 pinwheels by comparing the measured layouts in subsequent imaging sessions of 42 minutes each.

Using this extensive data set and precise analysis methods we found rare but conclusive examples of pinwheel rearrangement. The rate of these events was increased when the pairing paradigm was used. These results demonstrate for the first time dynamical changes of visual cortical architecture driven by neuronal activity.
title: Precision measurement and dynamical switching of visual cortical architecture

text:
Recent theoretical work suggests that heterogeneity of neuronal populations may substantially increase amount of information captured by the nervous system about sensory stimuli [1 – 4]. Shannon's mutual information (MI) provides a proper framework for considering this problem. However, evaluation and maximization of MI are technically challenging. Properties of encoding-optimal tuning curves (TCs) of single neurons described by Poisson statistics were thoroughly analyzed [3]. The results were extrapolated to predict the population level properties by combining responses of all neurons into one effective Poisson channel. Other studies exploited the approximation of the limit of large neuron number for this task [4]. It is, however, not fully understood how well these simplifications apply to realistic, finite size systems.

Here, we present results of numerical studies of the TC heterogeneity of MI-maximizing, finite size populations of independent neurons driven by a common stimulus. In the model, each neuron exhibits Poisson spike statistics and a monotonically increasing spike rate dependence on the stimulus intensity. Responses to static stimuli of fixed duration are considered.

Our results suggest that, like for a single Poisson neuron, MI-maximizing TCs are discrete for a set of independent neurons. Likewise, we find that the structure of optimal TCs changes with decreased output noise through a series of bifurcations. However, at any noise level considered, optimal MI increases with the maximal number of neuron subpopulations in the later case. This is in contrast to the situation of the lumped-population Poisson channel, when, at a given level of the output noise, MI is maximized by a population with a finite number of different TCs. Moreover, it turns out that the combination of independent neurons into one effective unit may substantially reduce the achievable MI.

Next, we find that the above results also apply to a more physiological situation of continuous TCs with finite dynamic ranges except that the optimal number of neuronal subpopulations is finite at a given level of output noise then. The exact heterogeneity structure, described by the sizes of different subpopulations and the parameters of their TCs, strongly depends on the output noise level. This opposes the prediction of the approximation of large neuron number, which anticipates the same heterogeneity structure of the population independent of the intensity of the output noise.
title: Structure of an encoding-optimal population of Poisson neurons driven by a common input

text:
The description of the correlated activity of large populations of neurons is essential to understand how the brain performs computations and encodes sensory information. Nevertheless, how to simply capture these correlations is still a matter of debate. Recent studies have shown that the activity of each cell is influenced by the population rate (Okun et al., 2015), defined as the summed activity of all neurons in the population. However, an explicit model for these interactions is still lacking.

Here we build a probabilistic model of population activity that reproduces the dependency between each cell and the population rate. Unlike other models of population activity, such as those reproducing couplings between pairs of neurons, this model is tractable, meaning that its predictions can be computed analytically. As a consequence, this model can then be learned in a few seconds on a standard computer, even for large population recordings. 

We inferred our model for a population of 160 neurons in the salamander retina. In this population, we uncovered new dependencies on the population rate that do not fit within the proposed division between soloists and choristers (Okun et al. 2015). In particular, a majority of cells were tuned to a preferred population rate at which they were most likely to fire, rather than being monotonically coupled to the population. These complex dependencies could not be explained by a linear coupling between the cell and the population rate. Overall, we found that population couplings had a similar predictive performance in the retina than what was found in the cortex.

We thus provide a simple and computationally tractable way to model the dependence of each neuron on the population rate. The procedure is general and can be applied to any recording of  spike trains within large populations.
title: A tractable method describing complex couplings between neurons and population rate

text: Functionally equivalent neuronal circuits can generate similar activity patterns despite disparate intrinsic and synaptic properties. Neuromodulators can alter these properties, by reconfiguring circuits and producing multiple behavioral outputs. One example is provided by the stomatogastric nervous system of crustaceans, where projection neuron MCN1 activates the circuit of interneurons LG and Int1 coupled by recurrent inhibition. In this circuit, activation of an entire projection neuron population produces different activity patterns in comparison to an “equivalent” activation of a subset of that population. We seek to uncover the interplay between circuit properties (intrinsic and synaptic) by examining circuit output to descending stimuli with different correlation structure. We use conductance-based models to investigate the role of descending inputs in regulating the output of small circuits comprised of two mutually inhibitory non-identical neurons. Using reduction methods from dynamical systems, high-dimensional conductance-based models are reduced based on quasi-steady state analysis, achieving timescale separation into three timescales corresponding to the upstroke of an action potential, the membrane potential repolarization following a spike and the interburst interval. The synaptic time constants further interact with the neurons’ intrinsic time constants, and allow us to relate circuit output to the circuit’s low-dimensional description. We discuss robustness of circuit output in response to stimuli with different statistics in the context of trade-offs between synaptic and intrinsic properties, which has implications for neuromodulation and plasticity that can dynamically change these properties.
title: Interplay between intrinsic and synaptic properties in small circuits

text:
Networks of randomly coupled rate neurons display a transition to chaos at a critical coupling strength [1]. These networks exhibit optimal information processing capabilities close to the transition – at the edge of chaos – and have been a focus both in neuroscience and machine learning. In the absence of noise or time-dependent inputs the transition is well understood by a dynamical mean-field theory describing the fluctuations of a single unit [1]. In particular, the transition to chaos occurs exactly when the trivial fixed point becomes unstable and hence can be predicted by linear stability analysis. Moreover, chaos is uniquely indicated by a decaying autocorrelation function. However, in nature and technology, these networks operate in the presence of noise or time-dependent inputs, rendering their dynamics stochastic or nonautonomous.

Previously it was found that noise shifts the transition to chaos to larger coupling strengths in simpler discrete-time systems [2], where the critical coupling corresponds to the point at which the system becomes locally unstable. The absence of temporal correlations on the one hand greatly simplifies the analysis, but on the other hand makes it impossible to transfer the results to continuous-time systems considered here. Kadmon et al. [3] studied the effect of small noise on the autocorrelation function and showed that noise smooths the transition. However, the fundamental mechanism by which noise affects the maximum Lyapunov exponent and the location of the transition are not understood.

Here, we investigate the effect of additive white noise on the transition to chaos. We develop the corresponding dynamical mean-field theory yielding the self-consistent autocorrelation function. As expected, the autocorrelation function always decays due to the noise and cannot be used as an indicator for chaotic dynamics. A transition to chaos must therefore be qualitatively different from the noiseless case. To find the transition we determine the maximum Lyapunov exponent, which describes the asymptotic growth of infinitesimal perturbations also for stochastic dynamics. We derive an exact condition for the transition from stable to chaotic dynamics. The transition is shifted to significantly larger coupling strengths than predicted by linear stability analysis of the local Jacobian matrix. This hints toward a dynamic mechanism by which noise suppresses chaos in continuous-time systems [4].
title: Transition to chaos in random neural networks in the presence of noise

text: Synchronization is a well-established, well-studied phenomenon. In particular, it is assumed that a new stimulus can induce synchronization between different regions of the brain [1,2]. Additionally, it is held that synchronization binds different features of a stimulus and results in a coherent perception [3,4]. However, the underlying mechanisms for robust stimulus-induced synchrony in the nervous system is still unknown. We believe that the proposals of criticality in the brain [5] can help to find the required conditions for the formation of robust stimulus-induced synchrony in neural systems. Accordingly, we have simulated 10,000 integrate and fire neurons with constant weight (w=1.0) and sparsity (0.02) while we changed the proportion of the inhibitory neurons. Simulation results suggest that the maximal stimulus-induced synchrony happens at a specific inhibition to excitation ratio that is highly similar to real-world biological networks. Accordingly, we suggest that the robust stimulus-induced synchrony in neural systems can happen due to a delicate balance between inhibition and excitation. Moreover, our finding can have intriguing implications for theories of criticality in the brain since it suggests that at a specific level of excitation, a property of the system tends to  show a divergent-like behavior. Therefore, we suggest that this property is probably resembling the “magnetic susceptibility” in previously studied physical systems.
title: Maximal Stimulus-Induced Synchrony at the Delicate Balance Between Inhibition and Excitation

text:
Selective and flexible routing among cortical areas is a key prerequisite for efficient information processing. The hypothesis of communication through coherence (CTC) suggests that this routing can be accomplished by means of attention-induced phase shifts between oscillating populations, such that an attended sender is in a favorable phase relation to a receiver, whereas non-attended senders assume a non-favorable phase [1]. Although several network models have been proposed that are capable to realize CTC, it is largely unclear how their relative phases are orchestrated by the attentional state, and it is completely unknown how the corresponding network structures emerge in the first place.

We use a Wilson-Cowan simplification of a spiking network model of three interacting cortical columns with realistic delays previously shown to reproduce hallmark electrophysiological effects of attention and information routing [2]. In this network, we randomly initialize recurrent coupling weights and introduce noise signals to the two sending populations to probe the efficacy of information transmission according to established experimental procedures [3]. 

We train network weights to optimize specificity of information transmission and find two distinct network structures, both capable of selective routing: an Interneuron-Network-Gamma (ING) network type, where most trained networks show an anti-phase alignment between the two sending populations, and a Pyramidal-Interneuron-Network-Gamma (PING) network type, in which sending populations assume a 2$\pi$/3 phase relation. Both realizations of CTC do not need an external mechanism which explicitly sets oscillation phases to their desired values: a constant rate modulation induced by attention suffices to self-organize relative phase such that selective information processing becomes possible.

The distribution of relative phases between the attended/non-attended sending, and the receiving populations makes an explicit prediction for physiological experiments allowing for a critical test of the two CTC realizations.
title: Self-organization and control of flexible information routing in cortical networks

text:
Memory consolidation, i.e., the transfer of memory from the hippocampus to higher cortical areas, is thought to be mediated by the interplay of specific oscillations. Particularly during slow-wave sleep in rodents, sharp wave-ripples (SPW-Rs) are prominent in local field potential (LFP) recordings of area CA1 in the hippocampus. SPW-Rs are characterized by strong voltage deflections (sharp-waves) with underlying high-frequency oscillations (~150-200 Hz ripples). As accompanied single unit activity reveals a replay of task related neural activity, SPW-Rs are a good candidate to play a key role in memory consolidation. To study underlying cellular processes, we built a  multi-compartmental model of a CA1 pyramidal neuron, which receives postsynaptic ripple currents reconstructed from hippocampal slice recordings. 
With this model, we could reproduce the experimental finding of sparse spiking activity during SPW-Rs in the pyramidal layer. Sparse firing activity in combination with dense connectivity is known to be instrumental in pattern recognition and reconstruction, which we are interested in as they might be a simple form of memory retrieval and consolidation.
Individual SPW-R typically last several cycles. We tested whether spiking is history dependent, i.e., if the amplitude of a preceding cycle influences the spike probability in the current cycle. We did not find such a dependence and concluded that intra ripple cycle history effects are negligible. Thus, we suppose that each cycle could function as an independent computational unit to learn or retrieve different patterns.
To further investigate the capacity to store different patterns, we  extended earlier theoretical works [1, 2] with a ripple cycle based, physiologically plausible network model, that reproduces experimental findings while linking those to theoretical considerations on memory capacity.
title: Integration of Sharp-Wave Ripple Currents in a CA1 Pyramidal Cell Model

text:
In the brain, neurons are the basic units that transmit and process information about the external world and internal states. The communication between neurons occurs predominantly in terms of action potentials: information is encoded in a neuron's spiking output. One of the open questions about neuronal communication is how information is encoded in a spike train and how features of presynaptic activity are transformed into postsynaptic spiking output.

In this work, we investigate the information transmission capacities of mean and variance coded signals. These coding schemes correspond to a signal dependent modulation of mean and variance of the postsynaptic somatic current. Previous work has shown that variance coded signals may transmit fast changing signals more rapidly and with a higher dynamic range (Lindner & Schimansky-Geier, Silberberg et al.). However, the effects of noise in these responses have not been investigated and an analysis of the information transmission capacities is lacking. Here we present an information theoretic investigation of both coding schemes. We find that for stationary input signals variance coding exhibits higher information transmission when the signal spectrum has considerable power at very high frequencies -- suggesting an advantage of variance coding for very fast signals. On the other hand, for a wide range of signal spectra with weight at lower frequencies mean coding possesses a higher mutual information that in some cases exceeds that of variance coding by an order of magnitude.
title: Information transmission capabilities of mean and variance coded signals

text:
In the last decades, inhibitory neurons have been identified as one of the core elements in shaping the activity of excitatory cells, modulating and expanding the spectrum of dynamical phenomena of neural circuits [1]. In more recent years, the combination of technologically advanced recording methods and the development of transgenic mice lines have boosted the amount of experimental data on various types of GABAergic interneurons [2-6]. However, the individual role of these interneurons are still mostly unresolved. A promising approach to gain insights and investigate the functional role of inhibitory neurons are computational models. 

Here, we present the results of a non-linear rate-based network model of layer 2/3 of the rodent cerebral cortex. The microcircuit comprises 4 different cell types: excitatory pyramidal cells (PC) and inhibitory parvalbumin- (PV), somatostatin- (SOM) and vasoactive intestinal peptide-expressing interneurons (VIP). All model parameters are constrained by physiological recordings to ensure realistic single cell and network properties [2-6]. We show that the rate response of pyramidal cells in the microcircuit is either shaped by SOM or PV cells. In the steady state, this division of labor is determined by the input regime, in contrast to the responses in the initial phase that are solely dominated by the PV cells. By means of phase plane analyses, we identify neuronal and network parameters that account for the phenomena observed: The cell-specific firing rate curves of the interneurons and the asymmetric connections between SOMs and PVs determine, which cell type dominates the steady-state response. The dominance of the PV interneurons during transient responses arises from their much smaller time constant and the strong connections between PVs and PCs. Furthermore, repetitive stimulation of PC neurons reveals a temporal redistribution from PV-evoked to SOM-evoked inhibition, suggesting a coordinated push-pull effect between PV and SOM neurons.

Our network model makes a number of predictions that can be easily tested in experiments by optogenetically stimulating or blocking various cell types in transgenic mouse lines, and hence may help revealing the functional role of interneurons within microcircuits.
title: The functional role of inhibitory neuron types: A theoretical study.

text:
About 2 to 5% of young children experience seizures during high fever, so-called febrile seizures [1]. While changes in pH seem to play a role in the induction of these convulsions [2], our modeling results suggest that the increase in temperature preceding a seizure could also directly contribute to seizure induction. 

We investigated the influence of temperature on type I model neurons and identified a critical temperature range where even mild temperature increases (≈1°C) alter single-cell dynamics such that network synchronization increases strongly. This critical temperature range lies close to a codimension-two bifurcation: the saddle-node-loop bifurcation (SNL). At the SNL point, the dynamics of firing onset switch from a saddle-node bifurcation (typical for type I neurons) to a homoclinic orbit bifurcation and, importantly, the phase response curve (PRC) changes from the canonical, symmetric shape to an asymmetric one, strongly favoring synchronization. Such a drastic change in synchronization caused by small increases in temperature constitutes a possible mechanism for the induction of febrile seizures. Our model analysis provides several predictions including the temperature dependence of PRCs and spike shapes, which we test experimentally in recordings of hippocampal pyramidal cells. 

We further analyze whether the proposed mechanism can explain genetic predispositions for strong febrile seizures: prevalence of febrile seizures should increase if a genetic mutation brings a neuron closer to the SNL point. Exploring established models of febrile-seizure-related ion-channel mutations, we find that this is indeed the case. Mutations lower the critical temperature of the SNL point, where synchronization and excitability explode. We conclude that the temperature-induced changes in neuronal dynamics could indeed contribute to the induction of febrile seizures. Because also other parameters can shift neuronal dynamics towards the SNL point, the relevance of the proposed mechanism could extend to other systems marked by a sudden increase in synchronization, such as other forms of epilepsy.
title: Increased temperature facilitates neuronal synchronization by switching the firing-onset bifurcation

text:
Overrepresentation of bidirectional connections in local cortical networks has been repeatedly reported [1,2,3] and is in the focus of the ongoing discussion of non-random connectivity in local circuits in the brain. However, the exact relation between the relative occurrence of reciprocally connected pairs and structured connectivity has not been explained.

In this theoretical work we show that in a network in which connection probabilities are symmetric in pairs, $P_{ij} = P_{ji}$, the occurrence of bidirectional connections and non-random structures are inherently linked; an overabundance of reciprocal pairs emerges necessarily when the network structure deviates from a random network in any form. For this we consider a random graph model in which each edge has a separate probability $P_{ij}$ to exist and show that when these probabilities are symmetric in pairs, the expectation for bidirectional connections $\mathbf{E}(P_{ij}^2)$ is minimal for an Erdős–Rényi network [4,5].

For two distributions of connection probabilities, the discrete two-point distribution and the continuous gamma distribution, we quantify how deviations from an Erdős–Rényi network structure increase reciprocity in the network. Representing different network connectivity principles, such as functionally specific connectivity and distance-dependent connectivity, both the discrete and continuous distribution can easily be tuned to account for a significant overrepresentation of bidirectional connections.
title: Non-random network connectivity comes in pairs

text:
In a population of neurons receiving the same supra-threshold sensory stimulus information transmission can be improved by population heterogeneity as well as noise. This effect, known as “suprathreshold stochastic resonance“ (SSR) [Stocks2000], works by decorrelating the responses in the population. Despite the fact that temporal dynamics play an important role in many systems (e.g. auditory or electrosensory systems) SSR has not been studied for dynamic stimuli yet.  

In our model system, the weakly electric fish Apteronotus leptorhynchus, two electrosensory systems provide information about different aspects of the electrosensory environment. The receptors of the active system densely encode information such as amplitude modulation of their own field induced by nearby objects or the electric fields of conspecifics up to frequencies of about 300 Hz [Benda2013]. The receptors of the passive system encode electrical fields originating from muscle activity of prey that are in the range below 50 Hz [MacIver2001]. Both systems, though closely related, exhibit different amounts of noise [Grewe2016]. The signals are relayed by the receptor cells to pyramidal cells in the electrical lateral line lobe (ELL) [Maler2009, Krahe2014] which consists of distinct maps that differ in frequency tuning. Also, pyramidal cells in different maps integrate over different numbers of receptors and we suggest that the amount of neurons over which they integrate is optimized with regards to the bandwidth of the two classes of natural stimuli and different noise levels in the input population.

We simulated populations of leaky Integrate-and-Fire neurons that were driven by signals with different bandwidth (0-50 Hz, 0-200 Hz). Similar to the static stimuli from Stocks' paper we show for dynamic stimuli that for a fixed neuronal population size there is a certain amount of noise that maximises mutual information between the input signal and the output of the neuronal population; if the amount of noise is kept fixed, we find the optimal population size. For weak stimuli we observe a simple correlation between signal amplitude and optimal noise level.
We compare the expectations from the simulations to intrinsic coding properties of pyramidal cells, which were recorded in in vitro recordings from different maps.
title: Suprathreshold stochastic resonance for stimuli of different bandwidth in electrosensory systems

text: Cortical excitatory neuronal activity is thought be controlled by feedback, disynaptic inhibition from local GABA-ergic interneurons. In vitro, it has been shown that trains of action potential can recruit somatostatin expressing interneurons and disynaptic inhibition of neighboring pyramidal neurons in vitro (Silberberg and Markram, 2007; Kapfer et al. 2007). However, in vivo, layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons activity is very sparse firing only single or doublet of action potentials (Barth and Poulet, 2012). To examine which circuit could underlie disynaptic inhibition in layer 2/3 in vivo, we made in vivo multiple two-photon targeted whole cell patch clamp recordings in somatosensory cortex of neighbouring layer 2/3 excitatory neurons and identified interneurons in anaesthetized mouse. We found that a single excitatory action potential is sufficient to recruit neighbouring parvalbumin expressing interneurons that subsequently inhibit the local excitatory network. Thus the net impact of a single excitatory action potential is inhibition. Our findings provide a rapid inhibitory feedback circuit that may underlie the sparse firing of cortical layer 2/3 pyramidal neurons in vivo.
title: Single action potential evoked disynaptic inhibition in vivo

text:
Deep neural networks have received considerable attention in the past several years, due to their success in solving real world machine learning applications and their potential importance for understanding sensory processing in cortical sensory hierarchies. However, our theoretical understanding of the computational benefits of deep architectures is  still lacking. In this work we propose a rigorous theory for information processing in feedforward structures.

Using a simple model of clustered noisy inputs and an analytically tractable learning rule, we derive exact recursion relations describing the propagation of signals and noise along the deep layers. Introducing a performance measure characterising the accuracy of the top readout layer allows us to compare the functionality of different layouts of networks, all performing the same task and using the same learning rules. Interestingly, correlations in the noise structure induced by the synaptic weights affect the dynamics and degrade performances. We find that that deep structures outperform a shallow layout, even when the latter has an arbitrary large size. More generally, for fixed total resources there are optimal depths and widths that maximize the readout performances.
title: Optimal Architectures in a Solvable Model of Deep Networks

text: Decision making belongs to one of the most important principles in the nervous system of living species. The crucial trade-off between time to decide (speed) and accuracy is essential for a creature to react to environmental stimuli and most importantly, relevant for survival. In-depth studies of coherent motion tasks in primates, based on two-choice decision experiments, led to a profound understanding of neuronal information processing and even bridged the gap to behavioural psychology. Three fundamental processing stages are needed to successful perform a two-choice decision experiment based on a saccadic eye movement task: the neuronal representation of the sensory signal, the integration of the incoming stimuli and the comparison of the accumulated information to a threshold for a final decision. In accordance to the seminal work of Shadlen and Newsome [1, 2] of decision making in primates, an analogue electronic decision making circuitry was developed. Our concept study includes an LED-display showing moving light dots (i.e. the tasks screen in primate experiments), an array of photo diodes (i.e. retina of the primate, sensory evidence), a Hassenstein-Reichardt Detector (HRD) based motion detection (i.e. a correlation-type motion detector with a high biological relevance, based on an inhibitory circuitry) [3-5] and finally a signal integration circuit. The later stage represents the decision making unit and is realised through an inhibitory mutual coupling of the accumulated signals. The entirely analogue circuitry is based on relaxation oscillators to mimic real neurons. Details of the circuitry and first results will be presented and discussed.
title: A bio-inspired decision making circuitry based on the  Hassenstein-Reichardt direction detector

text: Attentive tracking of multiple moving targets engages widely distributed networks of cortical regions [1], leading to significant functional correlations between time-varying average fMRI signals in these regions.  To study functional correlations at the level of single voxels, we subdivided the recorded volumes in 160990 voxels defined in 90 areas anatomically (AAL parcellation in MNI 152 space, with around 250 to 5k voxels per ROI)[2]. For each voxel, we established the number of significant local correlations (positive or negative) with others voxels in the same area (locFC, [3]) under three behavioral conditions: resting state, passive viewing, and attentive tracking.   Terming ‘stimulus contrast’ (SC) the comparison of passive viewing with resting state and ‘attention contrast’ (AC) the comparison of attentive tracking with passive viewing,  both showed widespread and consistent changes in locFCD: Positive locFCD was decreased in sensory cortices (SC 14k and AC 24k voxels), and increased in Frontal Sup Medial L/R, Frontal Mid L and Cuneus R (SC 400, 200, 100 voxels, respectively), and Occipital Mid L/R and Parietal Sup L/R (AC 450 voxels, 350 voxels, respectively). Negative locFCD was unchanged by SC but increased by AC (inside functional networks VAN and FPC and, to a lesser extent, DAN and LAN) in Frontal Sup L/R, Temporal Mid L/R, Precuneus L/R and Angular L/R (AC 1k, 1k, 850 and 300 voxels respectively).  In summary, we found different changes for positive and negative correlations as well as for areas within and adjacent to frontoparietal networks. We conclude that attentive tracking extensively changes the fine-grained cooperative dynamics of brain activity, as indexed by time-varying MRI signals from individual voxels, confirming and extending traditional studies of coarse-grained cooperative dynamics.
title: Attentive tracking of moving visual targets modulates positive and negative functional correlations at the voxel level (locFC)
