text:
Roving is a random task presentation paradigm, in perceptual learning, whereby multiple tasks are learned in a randomly interleaved sequence. For certain experiments, such as bisection tasks, human subjects appear to be unable to learn the individual tasks under roving conditions (Otto et al. 2006). In general, theoretical descriptions of perceptual learning experiments have resorted to approaches involving tuning of inputs using either recurrence or suppression (Zhaoping et al. 2003, Schaefer et al. 2009, etc.) However, these approaches have exhibited only partial success in  tackling roving. In 2010, Herzog et al. proposed a theoretically inspired explanation involving a constant drift in synaptic efficacies in the system (unsupervised bias), due to an inability to maintain accurate task specific estimates of performance, which leads to a failure to learn using feedback. We present a more realistic update on this model and use it to examine whether the unsupervised bias can still explain roving or not.

The proof-of-concept model proposed in Herzog et al. does indeed lead to a failure to correctly learn during roving but, while it fails due to the mooted unsupervised bias in the learning rule, the implementation relies on unbounded weight growth, an unrealistic phenomenon. We introduce a simple weight normalisation term, to counteract the unbounded weight growth, and implement a cognitive bias, often observed in human subjects, towards 50:50 presentation ratios, and discover a much more realistic model of human perceptual learning performance. The model (i) learns correctly on a single bisection or vernier task, (ii) fails to learn during roving of multiple tasks, (iii) exhibits the human tendency towards 50:50 ratios of choice, thus failing when a 75:25 ratio is used, (iv) similarly to human subjects (unpublished data), restores correct learning when informed of the altered presentation ratio.

Aspects of the model, consistent with intuitions within the perceptual learning community, indicate that the degree of overlap in task representations combined with the unsupervised bias, introduced via relative task difficulty, leads to the difference in outcomes between successful transfer learning versus failure. Interestingly, a cognitive bias towards 50:50 task presentation ratios appears to be quite helpful in a range of presentation paradigms often rescuing potential failures to learn in the long run.
title: Cognitive biases interact with the unsupervised bias in a model of roving during perceptual learning

reasonForTalk: This work combines a cutting edge translational approach to restore vision with a strong mathematical analysis and constitutes a case where computational neuroscience can benefit directly to translational research.
text:
When trying to restore vision in blind patients, a major issue with current approaches based on retinal prosthesis is that the visual acuity of implanted patients remains below the level of legal blindness. Expressing an optogenetic protein in ganglion cells is a promising alternative, but the acuity that can be expected has not been quantified. This acuity cannot easily be measured with behavioral experiments due to the lack of blind primate models.
Here we combine experiments on mouse and macaque retina, with modeling and ideal observer analysis to estimate the theoretical acuity that could be reached by a patient treated with optogenetic therapy. 
Using adeno-associated virus, we delivered microbial opsins in mouse and macaque ganglion cells. We measured the receptive fields of these light-sensitive ganglion cells from the explanted retinae and showed that a classical Linear-Non-linear-Poisson (LNP) model predicted well the responses of these cells to complex stimuli.  
Because the entire retinal circuit is bypassed by this direct optogenetic stimulation, each cell was conditionally independent of the others. Therefore, from the precisely fitted LNP model, we obtained a complete model of how the population of reactivated ganglion cells responds to complex stimuli. 
We then performed an ideal observer analysis of this model to estimate how well letters in different orientations could be discriminated by the brain, assuming an optimal use of information. We displayed letters to the model, simulated the ganglion cell responses, and then decoded which orientation was displayed with a Bayesian inversion. The decoding performance gave a prediction of the best acuity that can be reached by patients treated with this type of optogenetic reactivation. The smallest letter size that could be reliably discriminated was 250 microns, corresponding to an acuity of 20/200. This acuity meets the limit of legal blindness, a promising result for future clinical studies.
title: Predicting the visual acuity reachable for blind patients treated with optogenetic therapy

text:
Fast ripples (FR, 250-500 Hz) in the intraoperative ECoG have recently been shown to be specific predictors of surgical outcome in epilepsy patients. FR detection is restricted by their low signal-to-noise ratio and time consuming visual marking.  We present here a novel approach combining a low-noise recording system with FR automatic detection. 
Intraoperative pre- and post-resection ECoG (N = 9 patients, 5722 minute recordings, 135 channels ) was simultaneously recorded by a commercial device (CD, input noise level 21 nV/√Hz) and by a custom-made low-noise amplifier (LNA, input noise level 2.3 nV/√Hz). The automatic detector performed first an entropy-based computation of baseline amplitude and then the validation of events in the time-frequency domain. 
The baseline amplitude for FR was 2.0±1.4 µV in CD and 1.3±0.8 µV in LNA. FR rates were 0.2± 0.5 in CD and 0.9±1.5 in LNA (p <0.001).  Across patients, the similarity of spatial patterns between CD and LNA was 0.76±0.3 for ripples and 0.2±0.4 for FR. Comparing post-resection ECoG FR rates to seizure outcome resulted in PPV = 100% CI [0 100] and NPV = 62% CI [24 91] in CD, and PPV = 100% CI [29 100] and NPV = 80%, CI [35 99] in LNA.  
Our findings support that low-noise recordings enhance the SNR in the FR spectral range. Furthermore, the combination of an optimized acquisition system with an unsupervised FR detector improved FR detection. This novel tool could contribute to superior epilepsy surgery outcomes in the future.
title: Prediction of seizure outcome improved by fast ripples detected in low-noise intraoperative corticogram
topic: Brain disease, network dysfunction and intervention

text: Motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease are thought to be associated with pathological synchronization among neurons in the basal ganglia. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is an effective treatment for Parkinson’s disease patients, and is hypothesized to desynchronize the neural activity through injecting high frequency current pulses. In the coordinated reset (CR) stimulation of DBS (Tass, 2003), multiple electrodes are used to generate high frequency inputs with different timings to obtain desynchronized state. The CR neuromodulation to the subthalamic nucleus was shown to be effective for improving the motor function of Parkinsonian monkeys. In this study, we construct a neural network model consisting of leaky integrate-and-fire neurons, and examine the optimized stimuli for the CR DBS to produce desynchronized network state with less electrical energy. In the proposed DBS method, the stimulus waveform is temporally continuous and described as Fourier series. Each Fourier coefficient is globally optimized by the pattern search algorithm to minimize a weighted sum of the order parameter and current energy. We show that the trade-off problem between the desynchronization effect and energy consumption can be readily addressed by using the proposed method. The simulation results suggest that the DBS with continuous stimuli is more effective to break synchrony than the conventional DBS with pulse-type stimuli.
title: A model of deep brain stimulation optimized for desynchronization of network activity
topic: Brain disease, network dysfunction and intervention

reasonForTalk: We believe this talk will be of interest to experimental & theoretical neuroscientists. We show how cells with active dendrites learn sequences, a core function of cortex. It has generated considerable interest in both machine learning and neuroscience.

text: Pyramidal neurons represent the majority of excitatory neurons in the neocortex. Each pyramidal neuron receives input from thousands of excitatory synapses that are segregated onto dendritic branches. The dendrites themselves are segregated into apical, basal, and proximal integration zones, which have different properties. It is a mystery how pyramidal neurons integrate the input from thousands of synapses, what role the different dendrites play in this integration, and what kind of network behavior this enables in cortical tissue. It has been previously proposed that non-linear properties of dendrites enable cortical neurons to recognize multiple independent patterns (Poirazi et al, 2003, Larkum and Nevian, 2008). In this paper we extend this idea in multiple ways. First we show that a neuron with several thousand synapses segregated on active dendrites can recognize hundreds of independent patterns of cellular activity even in the presence of large amounts of noise and pattern variation. We then propose a neuron model where patterns detected on proximal dendrites lead to action potentials, defining the classic receptive field of the neuron, and patterns detected on basal and apical dendrites act as predictions by slightly depolarizing the neuron without generating an action potential (Hawkins and Ahmad, 2016). By this mechanism, a neuron can predict its activation in hundreds of independent contexts. We then present a network model based on neurons with these properties that learns time-based sequences. The network relies on fast local inhibition to preferentially activate neurons that are slightly depolarized. Through simulation we show that the network scales well and operates robustly over a wide range of parameters as long as the network uses a sparse distributed code of cellular activations (Ahmad and Hawkins, 2016). We contrast the properties of the new network model with several other neural network models, including echo state networks (Jaeger, 2002) and LSTMs (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, 1997), to illustrate the relative capabilities of each. We conclude that pyramidal neurons with thousands of synapses, active dendrites, and multiple integration zones create a robust and powerful sequence memory. Given the prevalence and similarity of excitatory neurons throughout the neocortex and the importance of sequence memory in inference and behavior, we propose that this form of sequence memory may be a universal property of neocortical tissue.
title: Why Do Neurons Have Thousands of Synapses? A Theory of Sequence Memory in Neocortex

text:
It is an abstract of [4], at http://arxiv.org/abs/1603.02238 or (google arXiv Ambroszkiewicz).
According to Fields et al. 2015, [1]:  “Glia are supposed to be responsible for higher order organization of information processing in the neuronal connectome, i.e. for homeostatic regulation, alterations in structural and functional connectivity of neural networks.  What do glia contribute to information processing that neurons cannot accomplish?”
Glia are responsible for creating synapses and managing their activity. Is it only a process dedicated for a single synapse connecting two circuits? If so, then how these processes are created, managed and controlled? There must be a generic meta-composition process for doing so, where the parameters are: two circuits (to be composed), presynaptic neurons of one circuit, and postsynaptic neurons of the second one.
From a theoretical computational point of view, neural circuits can be represented as first order computable functions on natural numbers (spike bursts as natural numbers in the unary code).  Synapse creation between two circuits corresponds to the mathematical notion of function composition. Higher order functions (functionals) are constructed on the basis of the composition. Functionals take functions as arguments, and may return also (other) functions as results. This high order information processing is done by dynamic establishing links (compositions) between functions. Since these very links corresponds to synapse creations, the basic rules for constructing functionals may have counterparts in the human brain as mechanisms for higher order organization of information processing in the neuronal connectome.
Hence, the generic meta-composition process  in the brain may be represented as constructions of higher order functionals. Theoretical research on computable functional in Computer Science is well established, see  [2] and [ 3].
Let us summarize. Glia are responsible for higher order computations, i.e. for dynamic creating, composing, and reconfiguring neuron circuits. At the bottom level it is realized by creating new synapses; this corresponds to function composition. Since the function composition is the basis for construction of the higher order functions (functionals), the generic processes of dynamic synapse creation correspond to functionals.
The hypothesis:   Glia seems to be the appropriate place where the mechanisms, corresponding to the constructions of computable functionals, are realized.
title: On higher order computations in the human brain: IT point of view

text:
Declarative memory denotes the storage of facts and concepts from perceived stimuli. The formation of such memories, in particular their allocation in neural circuits is still an unresolved problem. In general, different stimuli to be learned have to trigger the formation of different memory representations. In addition, each learned stimulus has to maintain its assignment or allocation to its specifically formed memory representation. Experimental findings imply that variations in neural excitability due to a complex cascade of proteins that make individual neurons more susceptible form a memory representation of a new stimulus [1]. Furthermore, the concept of synaptic tagging, which assumes cascades of plasticity-related proteins, is assumed to locally determine the synapses involved in the memorization process [2]. However, both ideas require complex, highly specialized cascades of several proteins to allocate memories.

Here, we show in a theoretical model that the allocation of memory can already be solved by the self-organized dynamics of synaptic plasticity. The system consists of three neuronal populations: an input population projects activity patterns (stimuli) through random excitatory connections on a second, recurrently interconnected memory population. All feed-forward as well as the recurrent synapses are adapted by a combination of Hebbian synaptic plasticity and synaptic scaling [3]. An inhibitory population is mutually connected to the recurrent layer to provide global competition. 
Interestingly, first of all, our model successfully forms stable memory representations: presenting a given stimulus to the recurrent layer causes a locally clustered group of neurons to become strongly interconnected with each other (Hebbian cell assembly [4]). Furthermore, presenting another stimulus of sufficient dissimilarity to the first one causes the formation of another memory representation. Remarkably, if the stimuli are quite similar to each other, both are allocated to the same memory representation. In addition, the system shows the dynamics of competitive memory recall, i.e. differentiating recognition [5], as the activation of one memory representation fully suppresses others.
In summary, the here-presented simple but biologically plausible concepts of stimulus-dependent self-organization of plasticity provide a promising approach to the question of how memory allocation is coordinated in the brain.
title: Self-Organized Memory Allocation by Hebbian Cell Assemblies

references.text: Cheng, S. (2013), The CRISP theory of hippocampal function in episodic memory. Frontiers in Neural Circuits, 7, 88

text: We recently proposed that episodic memories are best represented by temporal sequences of neural activation patterns and that the hippocampal circuit is optimized to store these sequences [1]. One central feature in this theory, called CRISP, is that hippocampal area CA3 intrinsically produces temporal sequential activities through its abundant recurrent connections. Here, we first study the possible mechanisms by which a relatively fixed recurrent network structure in CA3 can generate neural activity sequences intrinsically. We find that the robustness of sequence generation depends on the network architecture. For instance, randomly connected recurrent networks (RCRNs) are very sensitive to noise, whereas locally connected recurrent networks (LCRNs) generate moderately robust neural sequences [2]. Networks with sparse connectivity, which are trained with sequences of random patterns, exhibit the most robust dynamics. Next we implement a cortico-hippocampal circuit consisting of the EC-CA3-CA1-EC loop. During memory encoding, intrinsic CA3 sequences are hetero-associated with EC sequences, which are driven by sensory inputs. Downstream, CA3 sequences are hetero-associated with sequence in CA1 and finally, the CA1 patterns are hetero-associated with the sensory inputs in EC, thus closing the loop. During memory retrieval, intrinsic CA3 sequences have to be reactivated based on partial, noisy cues, which is provided to EC. Finally, the retrieved sequences in CA3 reactivate the stored sequences in EC via the CA1 layer. We find that memory performance is determined by the network’s ability to perform pattern completion of individual patterns as well as robust retrieval of sequential information from CA3. These two functions have competing requirements, i.e., the conditions that lead to good performance in one function might have detrimental effects on the other. For instance, modeling CA3 as a LCRN, the stored sequence is retrieved robustly, but the temporal correlations between patterns in the sequence impair pattern completion when decoding the CA3 pattern. On the other hand, a RCRN facilitates decoding, but sequence retrieval fails if any noise is present. Combining the advantages of each of these two models, networks pre-trained on sequences of random patterns achieve a good overall memory performance. In conclusion, we find that the cortico-hippocampal circuit can robustly store and retrieve sequences of pattern, as hypothesized by CRISP.
title: Storing and retrieving pattern sequences in the hippocampal circuit

text:
Grid cells are neurons of the medial Entorhinal cortex that have multiple spatial firing fields arranged in a strikingly-regular hexagonal pattern [1]. Since their discovery, grid cells have been studied extensively, as they are believed to support high-level cognitive tasks, such as self-location, memory, and navigation [2,3]. Nevertheless, to date, the origin of grid-cell activity remains unclear.
Kropff and Treves [4-6] investigated a single-cell model in which grid patterns emerge from a competition between persistent excitation by spatially-selective inputs and the reluctance of a neuron to fire due to spike-rate adaptation. The model provided an important proof-of-principle, but    was formulated at a rather abstract level. In particular, a network-level normalization mechanism effectively coupled the output rates of the neurons such that the simulated patterns did not emerge from a purely single-cell process. Additionally, the synaptic weights did not obey Dale's law, and it was unclear whether the model was robust against shot noise due to stochastic spiking.

To overcome these issues, we propose here an alternative formulation of the model by Kropff and Treves, which is, on one hand more biologically realistic, and on the other hand better suited for analytic treatment. We show that grid-like patterns can emerge from a purely single-cell process that requires only 1) spatially-tuned feed-forward inputs, 2) spike-rate adaptation, and 3) Hebbian synaptic plasticity. To increase biological plausibility, we constrain the synaptic weights to positive values, and we demonstrate the robustness of the model against shot noise due to stochastic spiking.  Finally, we construct a mathematical theory that quantitatively predicts the results of the numerical simulations, and that establishes a direct link with classical pattern-forming systems via the Turing instability.
title: Grid-cell pattern formation via Hebbian learning

text: The hippocampus is one of the crucial brain areas for learning and consolidation of memory in human brains. In particular, it serves as a classical model for neuroplasticity investigations. Therefore, important plasticity mechanisms such as long-term potentiation and depression have been identified and demonstrated in the hippocampal field. For the description of the working principles of the hippocampus a circuit model  (see fig.1)  has been proposed which based on auto- and heteroassociative networks. In this talk, a computational neural-network model of the hippocampal circuit is presented. Spiking neurons and memristive Hebbian synapses are employed into Hopfield- and Feedforward network structures. The obtained network performance is discussed in the framework of pattern completion  and recognition and recent studies of mnemonic competence [1; 2].
title: Pattern Separation and Pattern Completion in the hippocampal loop emulated by memristive Hebbian Plasticity

text: Numerous experiments have been conducted in the past in order to monitor the complex interactions that drive activity-dependent long-term plasticity of synapses. Spike timing, firing rate and synaptic location have been found to be important factors that dynamically contribute to the outcomes of plasticity induction protocols. While several theoretical models that implement plasticity rules already exist, they have not yet been used in depth to study plasticity in neuron models with detailed morphology. Here, we propose a hybrid biophysical framework based on an existing phenomenological voltage-based plasticity rule and apply it to a L5 pyramidal cell model with active dendritic properties and realistic propagation of voltage. We show that the hybrid rule not only reconciles outcomes of several popular experiments with only slight changes in parameters, but also that it predicts spatiotemporal patterns of plasticity that are characterized by individual stimulation protocols and their impact on local processes at the synapse. Due to this focus on local signals, our framework can explain synaptic plasticity in the absence of postsynaptic action potentials, as suggested in recent studies. We thereby link experimental results that would intuitively seem to require entirely different rules, showing that a unifying rule might explain the vast majority of experiments in cortical pyramidal cells if multiple biophysical pathways are taken into account. Ultimately, we can now study how the cell-type specific electrotonic properties can explain differences in emerging plasticity by incorporating our plasticity rule in a variety of existing detailed compartmental models such as models of hippocampal pyramidal or granule cells. To summarize, a simple plasticity rule that utilizes pre- and postsynaptic plasticity pathways can explain experimental results with a large variety of induction protocols when the plasticity rule is incorporated in the compartmentalized structure of a detailed dendritic model.
title: A novel synaptic plasticity rule for detailed model neurons

text:
Excitatory synapses in cortex typically reside on dendritic spines. Although cortical synapses play an important role in long-term memory, these spines undergo a remarkably high turnover [1,2]. This poses the question how information can be stored on a variable substrate as synapses. As a possible solution, we propose that information is stored and retained by the collective dynamics of multiple synapses. Such a collective dynamics can already be found on the connection between two neurons, which can consist of multiple synapses. More precisely, the experimentally obtained distribution of the number of synapses on these connections, which are bimodal with peaks at zero and multiple synapses, can only emerge from a collective dynamics of the involved synapses [3]. Modelling studies showed that this collective dynamics can emerge from the interaction of synaptic and structural plasticity [4,5] and that altered external stimulations can influence the dynamics such that the neurons become either unconnected or connected with multiple synapses [5].
Here, we investigate the information storage and retention of these collective dynamics with a simple stochastic model of structural plasticity, where synapses are created with a constant probability and removed with a probability depending on the number of existing synapses and the external stimulation. Using information theoretic measures, we show that the collective dynamics yielding the bimodal distributions of the number of synapses enables information retention on time scales orders of magnitudes longer than the typical lifetime of a synapse. Thus, the conflict of spine turnover and long-term memory can be resolved by storing information in the collective dynamics of multiple synapses.
Yet, at different external stimulation levels where the collective dynamics yield distributions with a single peak either at zero or at multiple synapses, information about the initial conditions decays quickly. This, however, implies that these stimulations can be used to learn new information orders of magnitude faster than it is forgotten. We confirm this by using these stimulations to store an image in a population of multi-synaptic connections. Indeed, this image can be retained orders of magnitude longer than it took to store it. Thus, learning can be faster than forgetting, which is  also a necessary prerequisite to solve the plasticity-stability dilemma in learning and memory on the time scale of structural changes.
title: Long-term information storage by the collective dynamics of multi-synaptic connections

text:
Neurons in the adult visual cortex of mice prefer to make synapses with neurons responding to similar visual features. As such a bias in connectivity is not observed at the time of eye opening, it has been proposed that the functional subnetworks are formed through rewiring of recurrent synaptic connections, induced by visual experience [1]. However, it is not clear according to which rules this structure develops. The emergence of feature specific wiring was recently demonstrated in a balanced network model with appropriate rules of functional synaptic plasticity [2]. In this model, however, connectivity was evaluated based on the strength of already existing synapses, and the structure of the network remained unchanged throughout the simulation.
 
Referring to recent findings of homeostatic regulation of cortical activity in rodent visual cortex in vivo [3,4], we employ here a structural plasticity rule based on firing rate homeostasis described previously [5] for simulating network restructuring during sensory stimulation. We show that, next to other biologically meaningful properties, feature specific connectivity also emerges in a balanced network of changing structure, using a plasticity rule that does not depend on spike timing.
title: Maturation of sensory networks through homeostatic structural plasticity

text: Structural plasticity, a change of the physical structure of networks, is believed to be critical for long-term development of synaptic connections in the neocortex. Here we model cortical circuits that exhibit structural plasticity, using numerical simulations of large-scale recurrent neuronal networks of integrate-and-fire neurons and mathematical analysis. Experimental data suggest that neurons in the neocortex tend to be either unconnected, or they form multiple connections [1]. Also, the distribution of EPSP amplitudes recorded in the primary visual cortex has a long tail, and a small number of very strong connections tends to dominate the network dynamics [2]. The network architecture considered here is a generic neocortical circuit, i.e. a balanced random recurrent network of integrate-and-fire neurons. We model structural plasticity as a Markov process with transition rates that depend on the strength (size) of synapses [3,4], while the temporal evolution of synaptic strength is described by additive spike timing-dependent plasticity (STDP). We show that neuronal circuits that exhibit both structural and functional plasticity can help to explain experimentally reported distributions of synaptic weight and number of synaptic contacts in the neocortex. Structural plasticity can indeed explain long tails of distributions of synaptic coupling strength. A subset of strong and persistent synapses could provide a possible substrate for long-term memory.
title: Structural and Functional Plasticity in Recurrent Neural Networks

text:
Persistent activity, the ongoing activation of stimulus-driven neurons in cortical networks, is thought to underlie the cognitive function of working memory and has been observed and correlated with working memory performance in numerous animals studies. A large body of modelling studies has reproduced this kind of activity using cell assemblies with strengthened synaptic connections. However, almost all of these studies have considered persistent activity within networks with homogeneous neurons and synapses, making it difficult to judge the validity of such model results for cortical dynamics. 

Here, we consider persistent activity in a highly detailed network model of the prefrontal cortex with heterogeneous distributions of neuron and synapse parameters which are determined by anatomical and in vitro electrophysiological data, and which has previously been shown to statistically reproduce a wide range of measures from in vivo prefrontal data [1]. We found that persistent activity was prevented by the naturally occurring heterogeneity in the neuron parameters of the inhibitory interneurons and the parameters of short-term synaptic plasticity, while heterogeneity e.g. in the synaptic weights or the parameters of the pyramidal cells has no such effect. In particular, cellular heterogeneity makes a subset of the interneurons overly excitable, which results in a strongly skewed distribution of interneuron firing rates which cannot be compensated by adjusting its mean. We also show that persistent activity is recovered if the effective excitabilities of the interneurons are aligned to each other by regulating their background input, e.g. by means of a homeostatic plasticity mechanism. Furthermore, the synapses connecting the assembly neurons must be selected such that they exhibit only a single type of short-term synaptic plasticity (facilitating or depressing) for each pair of cell types. Cell assemblies shaped by these two principles may be potentially targeted by distinct inputs or become more responsive to specific tuning or spectral properties.
title: Constraints on Persistent Activity in a Biophysically Detailed Network Model of the Prefrontal Cortex with Heterogeneous Neurons

text:
Humans are able to perform cognitive strategies to solve problems they are faced with. Thus, they generate a huge variety of strategies which cannot all be hard wired in their neuronal networks which consist of a finite number of neurons. One hypothesis is that neural entities are reorganized to participate in different cognitive purposes. Therefore, different entities are exploited, recycled, and redeployed and, thus, put to different uses without losing their original function [1]. Given this idea, to enable an accurate reaction according to a given situation, humans adaptively organize the learned memories of previous experienced environmental stimuli. However, the neuronal principles for the functional reorganization of the brain, thus, for rewiring the links between memories are still unknown.
Here, we use an adaptive neuronal network model depending on the interactions of synaptic plasticity [2, 3] and synaptic scaling [4]. Hebbian synaptic plasticity adapts the efficacies of synapses dependent on the corresponding neuronal activities [5]. With the intertwined mechanism of synaptic scaling, thereby, synaptic plasticity yields the formation of strongly interconnected subgroups of neurons (cell assemblies; CAs) [6]. These CAs serve as neuronal representations or memories of specific environmental stimuli [5]. As we are interested in the functional organization of the brain, we started to investigate the interaction between two memories. We describe the dynamics for the representation of each memory by homogeneous populations and drive the CAs with different external stimuli. It is shown that neuronal competition (synaptic plasticity combined with synaptic scaling) is mandatory for the formation of CAs [4, 7]. Here, we investigate the role of competition between memories for their functional rewiring. Therefore, we combine synaptic plasticity with different generic synaptic scaling mechanisms. Thus, we gradually increase the influence of synaptic scaling from a constant to a more complex and activity-dependent condition. Interestingly, increased competition between both CAs leads to the formation of different functional interactions between them. Dependent on the external drive and the internal competition the two-memory system is capable to build up different functional links between these memories such as association, discrimination, and sequence [8].
This work describes different forms of functional organization of memories in the brain.
title: The role of competition in memory organization

text:
Oscillatory patterns such as sharp wave-ripple complexes (SWR) are important for memory consolidation [1]. SWRs are oscillations of the extracellular field potential that can be decomposed into a $\approx100$ ms long sharp wave superimposed by $\approx200$ Hz fast ripple oscillations. The hippocampal neuronal network that is responsible for the ripple generation is currently not well understood [2-4]. 
A promising model for the generation of ripple oscillations is based on recurrent interneuronal networks of fast parvalbumin-positive basket cells in the hippocampal region CA1 [4]. According to this model, the interneuron network in CA1 receives a burst of excitation from CA3, the sharp wave, which leads to an ultrafast synchronization of the collective activity that causes the ripple oscillations. In these networks, interneurons are not exclusively connected by chemical synapses but are also coupled by gap junctions. While the functional role of the chemical synapses for the SWR oscillations has been studied extensively (e.g. [5]), the role of electrical synapses has attracted less attention [6].
Here, we investigate the contribution of gap junctions to the ripple component of the SWR by employing numerical network simulations. The network is realized by leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF) neurons, which are recurrently connected by inhibitory chemical synapses and gap junctions. The gap junctions are implemented in the LIF network following an approach from Lewis and Rinzel (2003). The effects of the different gap junction parameters such as coupling strength and connectivity on ripple oscillations are explored. We show that gap junctions increase the oscillation synchrony and robustness, while the network frequency is only mildly affected. A comparison of these findings to experiments that investigate the role of gap junctions is in particular interesting since these recordings, which either rely on gap junctions blockers or Cx36-knockout mice, show contradicting results.
title: Interneuronal gap junctions increase synchrony and robustness of hippocampal ripple oscillations

text:
Grid cells in the enthorinal cortex fire in a triangular pattern that tessellate the surface of the surroundings, assumed to form a spatial map of the environment. If grid cells are to be used as a spatial reference, they need to be stable by somehow anchoring to their environment. Although strikingly regular, the grid pattern does not consist of homogenous equidistant triangles but display local distortions in the shape and the orientations of the vertices, related to the walls and corners of the recording enclosure. The consistencies of the distortions over animals suggest that they arise from a common mechanism, possibly reflecting the anchoring of the grid to the environment. 
There are several conceptual models describing how the grid pattern is formed and shifted during locomotion of the animal. In the continuous attractor model the specific connectivity between grid cells form an activity bump that is moved using input from speed and head direction cells, which are also found in the entorhinal cortex. The adaptation model, however, assumes that the grid is learnt anew in each novel environment, relying on place cell input from the hippocampus that together with synaptic plasticity and spike rate adaptation forms a grid. 
Our main focus regards the development and distortions of the grid pattern during learning. In a novel environment the continuous attractor and the adaptation models should behave differently. Therefore, in this study we look at how grid cells respond to a novel environment with a focus on spatially localized distortions and the dynamical unfolding of the grid pattern. We examined grid cell activity during the first few moments when an animal first experienced a new enclosure in an unfamiliar room and recorded several sessions after that to study the long term development of the pattern. 
We found that grid cells display rich dynamics during learning a new environment possibly reflecting how the entorhinal cortex uses sensory cues such as corners and walls of the environment for anchoring. Our hope is that the data will provide evidence for how the grid is formed and more generally how computations within and between different areas of the cortex are executed.
title: Spatial dynamics of grid cells during novelty

text: Mediotemporal EEG characteristics are closely related to long-term memory formation. It has been reported that rhinal and hippocampal EEG measures reflecting the stability of phases across trials are better suited to distinguish subsequently remembered from forgotten trials than event-related potentials or amplitude-based measures (Fell et al. 2008, Lopour et al. 2013). Moreover, we recently have described that single-trial rhinal and hippocampal phase values per se are predictive for subsequent memory (Höhne et al. 2016). For the majority of subjects (23 out of 27) above chance prediction (overall accuracy 69.2%) was possible based on only three absolute single-trial phase values. Prediction based on absolute single-trial phase values outperformed that based on power values. However, it remained an open question whether relative phase values (i.e. the phase differences relative to a previous time point) are as well suited for memory prediction as absolute phases. This would mean that phase adjustments triggered by the to be memorized stimuli are predictive for subsequent memory. Therefore, we analyzed EEG signals from the hippocampus and rhinal cortex of 27 presurgical epilepsy patients with implanted depth electrodes. Intracranial EEG was recorded while patients performed a continuous word recognition task. Phase information relative to stimulus onset was used for prediction of subsequently remembered versus forgotten trials applying a support vector machine for two-class classification. Above chance prediction was possible for the majority of patients (19 out of 27) using just one rhinal phase value, one hippocampal phase value and one rhinal-hippocampal phase difference from the post stimulus interval (overall accuracy 64.9 %). In contrast to absolute phase values, no significant difference can be found between prediction accuracy based on relative phase values compared to that based on power values. Prediction accuracies based on absolute single-trial phase values surpassed those based on relative single-trial phase values. These findings indicate that the absolute EEG phases within rhinal cortex and hippocampus and not the relative phases are most relevant for successful memory encoding.
title: Prediction of memory formation based on rhinal and hippocampal phase information in intracranial EEG signals

text:
The strengths of excitatory synapses in cortex and hippocampus have been shown to follow a rightward-skewed or long-tailed distribution [1,2]. Such distributions can be achieved in recurrent balanced networks [3,4], after synaptic modification by Spike-Timing Dependent Plasticity (STDP) [5] and synaptic scaling [6]. Recently, long-tailed distributions have also been observed for inhibitory synapses in cultured cortical neurons [7], confirming early findings in hippocampal slices [8]. However, the conditions and plasticity mechanisms necessary for achieving long-tailed distributions of inhibitory synapses are unknown. Furthermore, different forms of inhibitory STDP have been reported, but the effect of various inhibitory learning rules on the distribution of inhibitory synaptic efficacies have not been explored [9-11].

Here we demonstrate that plasticity in the inhibitory synapses in a self-organised recurrent neural network (SORN [12]) with leaky integrate-and-fire neurons can lead to long-tailed distributions of inhibitory and excitatory synaptic weights under different types of iSTDP. The dynamics of the inhibitory weights over time resemble the experimental data on inhibitory synaptic strengths [7] given a precise ratio of potentiation and depression in various iSTDP window types.
We additionally find that the balance between excitatory and inhibitory currents is improved when the distribution of inhibitory weights is right-skewed. 

Our results suggest that long-tailed distributions of inhibitory weights are likely to be a ubiquitous feature of neural circuits that employ different plasticity mechanisms.
title: A recurrent network with STDP and long-tailed distributions of inhibitory and excitatory synapses

text:
Basal ganglia circuits are involved in motor control including the initiation and cancellation of movements. While movement-related firing rate changes of single neurons have been described in different basal ganglia subregions and cell types, the resulting population coding schemes remain unclear. Different population coding schemes may reflect different functional contributions of each subregion and cell type to motor control. Here we apply advanced data analysis techniques to a large data set of electrophysiological recordings in rats performing a stop-signal task to study those schemes. We use dimensionality reduction techniques to generate low-dimensional trajectories that characterize the diverse firing patterns during movement initiation.

Starting from conventional principal component analysis, we use information theory to describe the population coding schemes, geometrical measures to interpret the low-dimensional population trajectories, and matrix theory to better understand the mathematical structure of the underlying trajectory space. We find that different subregions and cell types have distinct population trajectory shapes during movement initiation. For example, the trajectory for the substantia nigra (pars reticulata) shows an almost linear evolution around movement, while the trajectory for the subthalamic nucleus has a more complex shape. Furthermore, we find that the trajectories for all the subregions differ from those expected from smoothed random processes. In addition to the time-based analysis, we develop further measures to describe the structure of the  population code based on sparseness and heterogeneity. While sparseness is a measure of the amount of active neurons during a particular condition, heterogeneity describes the diversity in the response patterns. We find that the coding scheme in striatal medium spiny neurons is sparse and heterogeneous. In contrast, the code in the substantia nigra pars reticulata is distributed and homogeneous. This points to the input and output stages of the basal ganglia having opposite coding strategies. These differences can have direct clinical implications because the effect of deep brain stimulation is also likely to depend on how heterogeneous and sparse the code in the target region is.
title: Different population coding schemes in basal ganglia subregions during movement

text:
Neurons in the hippocampus involved in spatial navigation like place cells are known to respond more variable to the place stimulus than expected for poissonian response activity [Fenton and Muller 1998, Fenton et al. 2010]. This phenomenon is called over-dispersion and lead to several conclusions ranging from attentional fluctuations, dynamic tuning and others [Fenton et al. 2010]. Here we show that also grid-cells in the entorhinal cortex show over-dispersion in grid fields.
Furthermore we suggest an alternative mechanism producing the high variability of grid cells, i.e. that subgroups of the grid population rest or burst together and thus lead to noise correlations as reported by Mathis et al. 2013. To test our hypothesis we extensively simulate grid cell firing activity using a contineous-zero-inflation model and compare it to electrophysiological data. Our findings constrain the hippocampal formations ability to decode the animal’s current location and we provide tools to improve statistical modelling of grid cell spike trains.
title: Structure of the noise in the entorhinal cortex

text:
We present a simple cerebellar model$^{[1]}$, real-time simulated on the SpiNNaker platform$^{[2]}$, and connected$^{[3]}$ to musculoskeletal robots$^{[4]}$. We demonstrate that the same network can learn two seemingly different tasks, antagonistic motor control$^{[4]}$ and delay timing, using the exact same learning mechanism. 
Whereas conventional models of cerebellar delay conditioning rely on neuronal network dynamics and require millions of neurons to represent long ( > 1.0 s) time periods$^{[5]}$, our model relies on mechanical action as well as proprioceptive feedback and can learn supra-second time periods with a few hundred neurons.
title: A cerebellar clockwork unifying movement and time

text: In multivariate pattern analysis of neuroimaging data (cf. Haynes, 2015), 'second-level' inference is often performed by entering classification accuracies into a $t$-test vs chance level across subjects (e.g. Haxby et al., 2001). We argue that while the random-effects analysis implemented by the $t$-test does provide population inference if applied to activation differences (Holmes and Friston, 1998), it fails to do so in the case of classification accuracy or other 'information-like' measures (Kriegeskorte et al., 2006), because the true value of such measures can never be below chance level. This constraint changes the meaning of the population-level null hypothesis being tested, which becomes equivalent to the global null hypothesis that there is no effect in any subject in the population. Consequently, rejecting it only allows to infer that there are some subjects in which there is an information effect, but not that it generalizes, rendering it effectively equivalent to fixed-effects analysis. This statement is supported by theoretical arguments as well as simulations. We review possible alternative approaches to population inference for information-based imaging, converging on the idea that it should not target the mean, but the prevalence of the effect in the population (Friston et al., 1999; Rosenblatt et al., 2014).
title: Valid population inference for information-based imaging: Information prevalence inference

text:
A central question in sensory neuroscience is to understand how sensory information is represented in neural activity. A crucial step towards the solution of this problem is the characterization of the neuron’s receptive field (RF), which provides a quantitative description of those features of a rich sensory stimulus that modulate the firing rate of the neuron.
For visual neurons, the stimulus space can be very high dimensional, and RFs have to be estimated from neurophysiological recordings of limited size. The scarcity of data makes it paramount to have statistical methods which incorporate prior knowledge into the estimation process (Park & Pillow 2011), as well as to provide quantitative estimates of uncertainty about the inferred RFs (Stevenson et al 2011). For many sensory areas, there are canonical parametric models of RF shapes – e.g., Gabor functions for RFs in primary visual cortex (V1) (Jones & Palmer 1987). Bayesian methods provide a quantitative way of evaluating these models on empirical data by estimating the uncertainty of the inferred model parameters.
We present a technique for full Bayesian inference of the parameters of parametric RF models, focusing on Gabor-shapes for V1. We model the spike generation process by means of a generalized linear model (GLM, Paninski 2004), whose linear filter (i.e., RF) is parameterized as a time-modulated Gabor-function. Use of this model dramatically reduces the number of parameters required to describe the RF, and allows us to directly estimate the posterior distribution over interpretable model parameters (e.g. location, orientation, etc.). The resulting model is non-linear in the parameters. We present an efficient Markov Chain Monte Carlo procedure for inferring the full posterior distribution over model parameters.
We show that the method successfully detects the presence or absence of a RF in simulated data – even when the total number of spikes is very low – and can correctly recover ground-truth parameters. When applied to electrophysiological recordings, it returns estimates of model parameters which are consistent across different subsets of the data. Our current implementation is focused on the response of simple cells in V1, but the approach can readily be extended to other sensory areas or non-linear models of complex cells.
title: Full  Bayesian  inference  for  model-based  receptive  field  estimation,  with application to primary visual cortex

text:
The quantity and complexity of experimental data being recorded in Neuroscience is increasing quickly. Many traditional data analysis tools do not scale to large datasets and there is an urgent need for accessible high-performance algorithms. To this end we developed and released a flexible Blind Source Separation (BSS) method that is capable of handling high-dimensional data such as 2p imaging recordings and encompasses many traditional methods such as sparse Principal Component Analysis, Independent Component Analysis or Non-Negative Matrix Factorization. More concretely, the algorithm is (1) based on a high-throughput probabilistic formulation, (2) can flexibly incorporate prior information about the sources (e.g. sparsity or non-negativity), (3) employs random-projection PCA to reduce its memory-footprint and can (4) be run on the GPU.

We apply the method to a 2p imaging video recorded in a zebrafish, extract regions of interest (such as the position of cells or dendrites) and single-cell calcium traces and then compare with manual labeling. We additionally benchmark the algorithm quantitatively on a composition of a 2p recordings with manually appended cells. On large-scale data the new algorithm can easily be 1-2 orders of magnitude more memory- and run-time efficient then other commonly employed BSS algorithms and can often discover more meaningful sources due to its flexible incorporation of prior information (like the sparse, non-negative responses of single cells with localized ROIs).
title: Large scale blind source separation

reasonForTalk: The study compares two widely used neuron models in terms of predictive power, and demonstrates that the assumption of Poisson spiking is unsuitable to reproduce the experimentally measured dependence of spike count correlations on stimulus contrast.

text: Modelling neural response variability is central to computational methods that aim to characterize state- or stimulus-dependent population responses in the brain. However, both assumptions about the source of stochastic processes contributing to this variability and the parametric form vary across the literature (Macke et al, 2011; Yu et al, 2009; Lin et al, 2015). These differences have critical impact on response statistics and therefore affect the predictive power of population methods. Here we formulate two models which represent different assumptions on the source of spiking variability. The Doubly Stochastic Poisson (DSP) model reproduces the linear relationship between the mean and variance of spike count responses using a Poisson process to generate spikes. Beyond the variability in spike generation, we model a second source of variability, that is correlated among neurons, as a multivariate distribution for membrane potentials. In contrast to the DSP model, the Rectified Gaussian (RG) model (Carandini, 2004) assigns variability solely to membrane potentials and assumes a spike generation process with minimal amount of stochasticity. We confirm that single-cell statistics of the two models are compatible and therefore can achieve similar predictive performance on the marginals of population responses. Critically, we derive contradicting predictions on changes in response correlations when membrane potential means and variances are manipulated, which can potentially dissect the predictions of DSP and RG models. In order to contrast the predictions of the two models, we build a population model of V1 neurons and test stimulus-contrast and orientation-related changes in noise correlations. Using single unit spike trains recorded from the V1 of awake monkeys (Ecker et al, 2010), we show that the difference of the population distribution of spike counts at different stimulus contrast levels in the experimental recordings is compatible with the predictions of the RG model but contradict those of the DSP. Distributions of spike counts in response to stimuli with different orientations are compatible with both models, but also favor the RG against the DSP. We conclude that based on co-activation statistics of spiking responses, it is possible to discriminate between spiking models assuming different sources of variability without explicit knowledge of the membrane potential statistics, allowing for the efficient prediction of response correlations.
title: Response correlation dissects spiking variability and subthreshold variability in a model of V1 neurons

text:
As one gains more intuitions and results on the importance of concerted activity in spike trains, models are developed to extract potential canonical principles underlying spike coding. These methods shed a new light on spike train dynamics. However, they require time and expertise to be implemented efficiently, making them hard to use in a daily basis by neuroscientists or modelers. 

To bridge this gap, we developed the license free multiplatform software ENAS integrating tools for spike trains analysis and simulation. These tools are accessible through a friendly Graphical User Interface that avoids any scripting or writing code from user. Most of them have been implemented to run in parallel to reduce the time and memory consumption. One of the main strength of ENAS when compared to competing software is to provide statistical analysis with Maximum Entropy-Gibbs distributions taking into account both spatial and temporal correlations as constraints, allowing to introduce causality and memory in statistics. Conversely, given this analysis or other known statistics, ENAS one can also generate new spike trains.  These methods result from a series of work (e.g. Vasquez et al. 2012, Nasser et al. 2013, Nasser and Cessac 2014) and they have already been applied to the analysis of retina data in Vasquez et al 2014 and Herzog 2015. This comes in addition to basic visualizations and classical analysis for statistics of spike trains analysis. All these tools are generic and can be applied to any spike train.  

Interestingly, ENAS also includes specific tools dedicated for vision, and the retina in particular. For example, one can jointly visualize stimulus and spiking activity or estimate receptive fields. ENAS also includes a virtual retina simulator extending former simulator (Wohrer and kornprobst 2009) to include lateral connections in the IPL. 

We hope that ENAS will become a useful tool for neuroscientists to analyze spike trains and we hope to improve it thanks to user feedback.  Our goal is to progressively enrich ENAS with the latest research results, in order to facilitate transfer of new methods to the community. It is downloadable from https://enas.inria.fr where documentation, tutorials and samples of spike trains are available.
title: EnaS: a new freeware for spike trains analysis and simulation

text:
The tendency of neurons to fire bursts of action potentials has been associated with many physiological processes, including information processing and long-term potentiation. Precise identification of periods of bursting activity thus plays a critical role in many applications, such as the accurate quantification of time course changes in network behaviour during development, or as a result of pharmacological or genetic manipulations. Microelectrode array (MEA) recordings of cultured neuronal networks are a common and efficient means of studying this bursting activity in vitro. 

To address the problem of accurate identification of bursts, a large number of burst detection techniques have been proposed, many of which have been developed and verified based on MEA recordings from rodent nervous systems. Recently, human stem cell-derived neuronal networks cultured on MEAs have been shown to exhibit spontaneous bursting activity [1]. There is thus a demand for a robust method of analysing bursting in these networks, which commonly exhibit more variable and complex patterns of bursting activity than rodent neuronal networks [2]. 

Using both synthetic and experimental data, we assessed the performance of a number of existing burst detection techniques at identifying bursts in spike trains with properties resembling those of human neuronal network recordings. We identify a number of issues with common burst detection techniques, and show that although no current method can provide ‘perfect’ burst detection results, two burst detection techniques, the MaxInterval [3] and logISI [4] methods, outperform compared to others. We further use these methods to examine the ontogeny of bursting activity in networks of human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived neurons over several months of development.
title: A comparison of the computational methods for detecting bursts in neuronal spike trains and their application to human stem cell-derived neuronal networks

text:
Structured spiking activity of neural populations is believed to convey information of sensory signals perceived by an animal. Therefore, to understand the fundamental principles of perception and cognition it is crucial to study the statistical structure of population activity. However, variability and dynamics of recorded data make this a nontrivial task. Approaches inferring dynamic networks conventionally assume stationarity over repetitions of a behavioral paradigm or reduce the dimensionality of the data. Here, we propose a different approach that does not postulate any stationarity and still infers a full coupling structure of a population.

We consider a spike train model that generates spike data $S=\{\boldsymbol{s}_1,\ldots,\boldsymbol{s}_T\}$ according to a certain state. This state may switch occasionally and hence the statistics of the data change. In detail: At each time $t$ a network's activity with $N$ neurons is described by an  $N$-dimensional binary vector $\boldsymbol{s}_t$. We assume that at each time point the network is in a certain state $z_t=k$. If this is the case the probability of the activity pattern $\boldsymbol{s}_t$ depends on the coupling matrix $J_k$ and the previous activity $\boldsymbol{s}_{t-1}$. The transition probability is known as the 'kinetic Ising model'. The couplings $J$ may switch at each time point with probability $\gamma$. When the state changes, the next state $l$ is chosen with state probability $\pi_l$. For a fully Bayesian approach the model assumes priors over all latent parameters $J,\boldsymbol{\pi},Z$. Thus, the full model describes a Dirichlet process with an additional state switching dynamics. The graphical model is shown in Figure $1$. 

Exact inference of model parameters is intractable. For approximate inference the state labels $Z$ are considered to be independent from the rest of the parameters resulting in a variational approach. 

We show that inference can be done accurately for artificial data, i.e. couplings $J$, state labels $Z$ and state probabilities $\boldsymbol{\pi}$ are inferred correctly. Furthermore, V4 spiking data recorded while a monkey performed a simple fixation task [$1$] are analyzed. The model identifies distinct states in ongoing and evoked activity.  

The framework allows single-trial analysis of neural data while still considering the full connectivity matrix of a network. It may particularly be useful when activity changes rapidly due to stimuli or internal states.
title: A Discrete State Model for Inferring Neuronal Couplings from Dynamic Single-Trial Spiking Data

text:
Stereo vision in biological systems is based on disparity-tuned cortical neurons integrating visual information from the left and the right eye. Disparity tuned neurons also show specificities for other stimulus parameters, most notably edge orientation and scale. They are therefore often modeled as a pair of Gabor functions, one for the left and one for the right eye, with the differences between these two functions defining stereo disparity. As a consequence of neuron-based disparity representation, biological stereo systems do not react exclusively to position-defined point disparities, but also to intensity differences between the two half-images of a stereogram [4,5,6]. Indeed, human stereo vision is not adequately described by calculating a list of feature-disparities from solutions of the correspondence problem; rather intensity-based disparities and higher order shape descriptors have been shown to play an important role [2,5]. 
What are the primitives of stereo vision? As one possible access to this problem, we study the joint statistics of stereoscopic image pairs, using a neural network approach, the sparse coding algorithm. It has originally been proposed to be the underlying mechanism of neural receptive field generation and is therefore largely inspired by response properties of cortical neurons and by reasoning about the goal of sensory coding [3,4]. 
We extend the sparse coding algorithm described in [7] to binocular images and present and analyze the resulting disparity-tuned receptive fields. The results show that disparity tuning occurs in unsupervised learning of sparse image codes without explicit cues to object depth or disparity. Binocular kernels show both, phase-based and position-based disparities but no strong dependence between the two types. The co-existence of both disparity types is in line with neurophysiological findings [1,8] but in conflict to older claims that phase disparity should be preferable. Furthermore the results indicate that the arising binocular receptive fields are not restricted to point disparity detectors, but include detectors for intensity-based and higher order disparities. In ongoing work, we will expand on the catalog of stereo disparities and test putative disparity types in psychophysical experiments on human depth perception.
title: Sparse coding in binocular vision systems predicts tuning for point and higher-order disparities

text:
The present study focuses on the inference of network parameters from empirically observed activity. This problem has attracted a lot of interest in the past decades. The detection and strength estimation accuracy depends on the model assumed for the node dynamics. In particular, graphical models (for partial correlations), autoregressive models and linear-nonlinear models have been successfully applied to large networks. Here we consider various models of noise-diffusion networks, including the first two models mentioned above, and provide a mathematical analysis that links them. 
We apply the corresponding methods to estimate either the presence of a connection or its strength. Following our recent study [1], we focus on fMRI data for which we estimate the so-called effective connectivity, namely the strengths of dynamical interactions between cortical areas. We discuss the improvement of the method when combining anatomical information obtained using diffusion-tensor imaging (DTI), which constrains the cortical model by providing a skeleton and reduces the number of connections to tune. For noise-diffusion models, these methods provide quantitative estimates of both inputs and connectivity, which allows for the study of the propagation of activity in the cortical model.
title: Inference of network interactions and application to fMRI data

text:
In recent studies spike train recordings from large populations of neurons have been analyzed by estimating the information transfer in these networks using transfer entropy[1]. This quantifies the directed interactions between neurons as a model-free method even for non-linear interactions. High information transfer between two spike trains is evidential for an underlying excitatory synapse between the neurons, but even inhibitory synapses show significant information transfer when observing sufficient spiking activity. We extend the effective connectivity analysis by revealing whether the information transfer is coming from an excitatory or an inhibitory synapse. To distinguish these type of interactions we analyze the local transfer entropies[2] of each interaction and define the sorted local transfer entropy as the discriminating quantity. We improve these network reconstructions by applying state-conditioning[3] to the entropy estimations to remove the network effects during highly synchronized events, which leads to a better delay estimation of the interactions. Surrogate tests, where the presynaptic spike times are jittered, but the inter-spike interval distributions remain largely unchanged, also improve the reconstruction. We also explore various normalization techniques of the entropies and show their effect on the reconstructions. Assuming Dale's principle, we further show that neurons can be correctly classified into excitatory and inhibitory from their estimated outgoing connection types. 
We test these techniques on simulated spike trains from random networks of Izhikevich neurons with random synaptic delays and spike-timing-dependent plasticity evolved connection weights like in a previous study, showing that we can distinguish interaction types, improve the reconstruction and classify the neurons.
title: Network reconstruction and neuron classification from spike trains using sorted local transfer entropy

text:
In empirical research it is vital to ensure that inferences are caused by the intended experimental manipulations and not by confounding influences. A well-established approach to avoid and control for confounds is to employ classical design principles pioneered by Fisher, such as counterbalancing the presentation order, and to carry out additional analyses on control data. Here we investigated whether this standard practice is suitable for neuroimaging studies using cross-validation or multivariate decoding.
We find that this standard practice can – counterintuitively – lead to the exact opposite of what it should achieve: Classical design principles might not only fail to effectively control confounds, but can even induce them. This can lead to systematic positive or negative statistical biases (such as significant below-chance decoding accuracies), potentially yielding false positive or false negative findings. As a consequence, researchers who believe they successfully controlled confounds may be tempted to conclude with stronger certainty that their results are correct, even though this conclusion is not justified. Interestingly, these problems typically do not depend on whether multivariate or univariate analyses techniques are used; neither are they specific to decoding approaches or multivariate pattern analysis. Instead, they are caused by "design–analysis interactions", i.e. designs that are not suitable for the employed analysis pipeline.
We provide several examples illustrating the effect of incompatible designs and analysis pipelines and demonstrate how intuitions about effects of classical design principles can be misleading. In order to effectively detect, avoid, and eliminate these and related problems, we suggest to perform the same analysis that is used to analyse the main experimental data on (i) design variables, (ii) control data, or (iii) simulated data. The approach can be employed either after data collection to detect problems and quickly test potential remedies; or it can be applied before data is collected, thereby preventing errors already at the design creation stage. Although we demonstrate these effects for neuroimaging experiments, the same analysis approach can also detect, avoid, and eliminate similar problems in other fields that employ complex analysis pipelines, such as machine learning or genetics.
title: Detecting, Avoiding and Eliminating Confounds in Neuroimaging Data Analysis: Design–Analysis Interactions and the Same Analysis Approach

text:
Many sensory systems have been shown to exploit sparsity in order to efficiently encode natural stimuli [1]. Here we address the question whether sparse coding of head motion yields efficient representations and whether there is physiological evidence for this coding principle. We learned a sparse code from recordings of linear acceleration and angular velocity of human head motion. The code consists of a set of signal-adapted basis functions, or kernels, that represent temporal patterns of all six degrees of freedom of movement. We found that these kernels  can efficiently encode  the majority of  naturally occurring movements. However, highly sparse representations do not permit exact stimulus reconstruction, in part due to the inherently non-linear relationship between angular velocity and acceleration due to gravity. Furthermore, we found evidence that the learned code employs a distributed encoding of rotational and translational components, similar to neurons in the vestibular nucleus (VN), the first stage of vestibular convergence [2]. 

We recorded linear acceleration and angular velocity of head motion from 10 different subjects performing 7 different activities each (running, biking, walking on grass, walking on pavement, playing soccer, walking upstairs, walking downstairs) using an inertial measurement unit, the MTx from Xsens. This data was used to learn a sparse code which could efficiently encode natural head motion using a multivariate dictionary learning algorithm [3]. The coding performance was evaluated by encoding a distinct set of test data with the learned kernels and measuring the error of reconstruction from the coded data. 

We also measured the energy contained in the rotational and translational components of the kernels, respectively. This energy corresponds to their sensitivity to either types of motion. We found a distribution different from that found in the training data with some kernels mostly responding to linear acceleration, others to angular velocity and a majority of kernels sensitive to both. This encoding is similar to that observed in VN neurons, supporting the hypothesis that the convergence in the VN is optimized to permit efficient coding of head motion at higher stages of vestibular processing.
title: Efficient encoding of natural head motion

text: Recent advances in multi-unit recordings pave the way for a quantitative understanding of the statistical structure present in the responses of large neural populations. An intriguing feature of the correlations observed in both real [1] and artificial [2,3] neural populations is criticality—a term coined for the observation that the dynamic range of the frequencies of observed population patterns is anomalously large. Here we introduce a general method for constructing probabilistic models which take into account the prior knowledge that the modeled population could be close to critical. The class of models we consider consists of an energy function which parametrizes interactions between small groups of neurons, and an arbitrary positive, strictly decreasing, and twice differentiable function which maps the energy of a population pattern to its probability. Both the parameters of the energy function, and the nonlinear map from energies to probabilities have to be learned from data. Our models admit an interpretation in terms of a latent variable globally coupling the whole population which is a recently proposed mechanism underlying criticality [4]. To demonstrate the usefulness of our method, we show that augmenting an energy function which models pairwise interactions between neurons with a nonlinearity yields an accurate description of the activity of retinal ganglion cells. Criticality has also been observed in many other datasets such as natural scenes or amino acid sequences of proteins suggesting that our method has a wide range of possible applications.
title: Semiparametric energy-based models of systems exhibiting criticality

text: Managing neuroscience data requires the integration of information from multiple sources. Information about stimuli, animals, protocols, and other background information about the experiment, together often called "metadata", are necessary to interpret the resulting data correctly. Storing such information consistently alongside the recoded data is therefore an essential part of experimental research and depends crucially on available file formats. Many existing formats provide only limited support for storing metadata along with the data. Here we present the NIX project, consisting of an open format and software tools to store, organize, and link data and metadata. The format[1] can represent various kinds of recorded and derived data in conjunction with all the metadata and links between data entities to facilitate data organization and data retrieval, as well as data sharing. Units and dimension information is stored directly with the data, for immediate correct interpretation. The NIX software libraries support direct, fine-grained access to the data and the linked metadata. This enables selecting specific subsets of the data, such as signals recorded from a certain electrode channel, or spike trains from a certain single unit in trials with a given stimulus. Efficient use of NIX format features is facilitated by software libraries for different languages, including C++, Python [2], Matlab [3], and Java [4]. Installable packages exist for different platforms, together with documentation, examples, and tutorials [5]. The NixView program [6] can be used to explore, plot and export the stored data in a user-friendly and convenient way. The NIX project includes tools that link to other open data format projects like Neo [7,8] and Neuroshare [9]. This enables seamless integration of data access with data analysis, and creates a route for the conversion of raw data from various proprietary formats to the open NIX format. Moreover, results of data analysis done with Neo, e.g. using the Elephant [10] toolkit, can be saved in the very same format. The NIX project thus supports comprehensive annotation and efficient organization of neuroscience data, and the variety of libraries makes it easy to integrate access to data and metadata in the lab data collection and analysis workflow.
title: Keeping track of your data with NIX: tools for comprehensive data organization

text:
Deep convolutional neural nets (DCNNs) are the most successful computational models of primate ventral visual pathway for object recognition. Interestingly, DCNNs tolerate object variations as humans do[1], use IT-like object representations[2], and match the spatio-temporal dynamics of the ventral pathway[3]. Nevertheless, DCNNs are not biologically plausible in terms of neural processing (sending floating-point values) and learning mechanism (supervised backprop algorithm). Actual neurons communicate with each other by sending spikes, and the information is coded in the spike times. Besides, learning in primates is mostly unsupervised, and at the neuronal level, depends on spike times (e.g. STDP). Employing such neural coding and learning mechanism in DCNNs would decrease the power consumption, and resolve learning deficiencies like overfitting and the need for millions of labeled images.
Several spiking deep neural network (SDNN) have been proposed in recent years[4,5,6], but none of them exploit temporal coding and unsupervised spike-based learning at the same time. Here, we propose to encode the information in the timing of first spikes and employs STDP to learn visual features, like [7] and [8], but using a deeper architecture.
Figure A illustrates a sample architecture of the proposed SDNN. The first layer uses DoG filters to detect contrasts. It codes the strength of these contrasts in the latencies of its output spikes (the higher the contrast, the shorter the latency). Neurons in convolutional layers detect more complex features by integrating input spikes from the previous layer which detects simpler features. Convolutional neurons emit a spike as soon as they detect their desired visual feature determined by their input synaptic weights. Neurons that fire earlier perform STDP and prevent others from doing so via a one-winner-take-all mechanism. In this way, more salient and frequent features will be learned by the network. Pooling layers provide translation invariance and also compact the visual data using a local maximum operation. Receptive field sizes gradually increase through the network and neurons in higher layers become selective to complex objects or object parts (See Figure B), in a totally unsupervised manner. Finally, a supervised SVM classifies  the input images based on the extracted features.
We evaluated our proposed SDNN on MNIST, Caltech face/motorbike, and ETH-80 datasets and reached accuracies of 98%, 98%, 81%, respectively.
title: Learning Visual Features With STDP in a Spiking Deep Neural Network
