text:
The Nidus multicompartment neural network simulator will enable new scales and classes of morphologically detailed network simulations on current and future supercomputing architectures.  Nidus is being developed as a collaboration between the Neuroscience SimLab at the Forschungszentrum Juelich and the Swiss National Supercomputing Center (CSCS) under the aegis of the NEST Initiative.  The trend towards "many-core" architectures such as GPU and Intel Xeon Phi based systems demands new approaches in software development and algorithm design.  Nidus is being written specifically for these architectures; it aims to be a flexible platform for neural network simulation, interoperable with the models and workflows of NEST and NEURON.

Improvements in performance and flexibility will enable a variety of novel experiments, but the design isn't finalised, and will be driven by the requirements of the community.  This is where you come in!  We are very interested in your ideas for features which will make new science possible: we ask you to think outside of the box and build this next generation neurosimulator together with us.

Possible features and use cases:

 o Simulate significantly larger networks over longer time scales
         - Larger proportion of CNS systems with morphological detail
         - Longer simulations for slowly developing phenomenon
         - Improved statistical power by leveraging large data sets

o A well defined high performance C++ API which allows tight integration with other codes
        - Multiscale by coupling with simulations at other scales
        - Real-time visualization on HPC resources
         - Online statistics to avoid scaling bottlenecks
         - Networks embedded in physically modeled animals

 o Dynamic data structures which allow the creation of models with a time-varying number of neurons, synapses and compartments
         - Neuronal development
         - Healing after injury
         - Age related neuronal degeneration.

What questions haven't you asked yet?

text:
Neuronal spike trains often show changes in their firing activity such as changes in the intensity or regularity of spike occurrences. Violating such changes may yield misleading statistical analyses if they require stationarity of the underlying models. Therefore, we are interested in locating ’change points’ in spike trains, i.e., points in time where the intensity or regularity of spike occurrences change. With regard to statistical modeling, one can then segment the spike train into regimes that can be assumed approximately stationary.
We propose a multi-filter procedure that aims at the detection of change points that appear on different time scales within the same train. For that, we test the null hypothesis of absence of change points. After rejection of the null, we use a multi-filter algorithm in order to localize change points. This is a two step procedure where we first analyze changes in the intensity. Second, we investigate changes in the regularity incorporating the information about the estimated intensity. Our approach is applicable to spike trains modeled by a large class point processes including Poisson- or renewal processes (i.i.d. ISIs), as well as processes with even less restrictive ISIs (renewal processes with varying variance).
title: Detecting Changes in the Intensity and Regularity of Neuronal Spike Trains

text:
Dynamic changes in the firing rates of neuronal discharges can be important signals for information processing as well as problematic for statistical analyses that are sensitive to rate changes. Therefore, we propose a multiple filter test (MFT) that tests the null hypothesis of rate stationarity and an algorithm that estimates the change points in the rate. Most importantly, our method incorporates practically relevant issues: (1) un unknown number of rate changes can occur (2) on multiple time scales, (3) other process parameters such as the variance of inter spike intervals are unknown, and (4) processes can show a high variety of patterns and distributions, including also serial dependencies.

Our MFT uses a filtered derivative process with multiple filters that converges weakly to a parameter free limit process that can be used to obtain the rejection threshold for the test. By specifically estimating serial dependencies in the test statistic, we show that the MFT can be applied to a variety of empirical firing patterns, including positive and negative serial correlations as well as tonic and bursty firing. We apply the newly proposed method to an empirical data set of spike trains with serial correlations and use simulations to show improved performance against methods that assume independence. For positive correlations, our new MFT is necessary to reduce the number of false positives, which can be highly enhanced when falsely assuming independence. For the frequent case of negative correlations, the new MFT shows an improved detection probability of change points and thus, a higher potential of signal extraction from noisy spike trains.
title: Multi-scale detection of rate changes in spike trains with weak dependencies

text:
Retinal Ganglion Cells spiking activity changes with the stimulus, generating different spatio-temporal patterns, depending on the stimuli features. One-way to analyse these patterns and their link to the  stimulus is the use of Maximum Entropy (MaxEnt) models generalised so as to take into account the network history, memory and causality [1,2]. The price to pay, however is a huge set of parameters that must be fitted to experimental data to explain the observed spiking patterns statistics. There is no a priori knowledge of which parameters are relevant and which ones are contributing to overfitting. We propose a method of dimension reduction, i.e. a projection on a relevant subset of parameters, relying on the so-called Susceptibility matrix (χ) closely related to the Fisher information. In contrast to standard methods in information geometry though, this matrix handle space AND time correlations. The spectral analysis of χ, allows, as we show, to extract the relevant/irrelevant dimensions. Especially, we observe several cut-off in its spectrum, for synthetic and experimental data. These cut-offs can be interpreted in the context of information geometry in terms of effective volume in the space of parameters [3]. 

We have applied this method for retina data obtained in a diurnal rodent (Octodon Degus) and a 252-MEA system. Three types of stimuli were used: spatial and temporal uniform light (photopic spontaneous activity, PSA), white noise (WN) and a natural movie (NM).  The results will be presented in the poster.  Especially we shall show the role played by time-delayed pairwise interactions in the neural response to stimuli both for close cells (with overlapping receptive fields) and distant cells (where correlations are not due to overlap of receptive fields). Our conclusion is that, to explain the population spiking statistics we need both short-distance interactions as well as long-distance interactions, meaning that the relevant functional correlations are mediated not only by common input (i.e. receptive field overlap) but also by long range connections.

text: Neuromodulators potently affect cortical sensory representations. In particular, acetylcholine (ACh) and dopamine (DA) trigger long lasting plastic changes in the response properties of sensory neurons. These modifications may serve to adapt sensory representations to the requirements of perceptual tasks, thereby improving perception. Here, we investigate this hypothesis in a neural network model. We model the release properties of ACh and DA as well as their putative effect on synaptic plasticity. We then measure the impact of the neuromodulators on the performance of the network on a visual classification task. In the model, ACh release follows task difficulty, a proxy for attentional demand. DA release follows reward prediction errors. Both neuromodulators act identically on synaptic plasticity by modulating the sign and magnitude of the network’s learning rate. We find that these two signals trigger distinct changes in sensory representations but both yield improvements in classification performance. ACh leads to population-wide reorganisations such that more neurons encode stimuli that are challenging for the network. DA adapts synaptic weights such that neural responses better match the distinct classes of the task at hand. These results indicate that neuromodulatory signals affecting synaptic plasticity can refine sensory representations and improve perception.
title: The role of neuromodulators in refining sensory representations

text:
Visual contrast sensitivity has an optimal spatial frequency while lower or higher spatial frequencies are progressively harder to detect. The equivalent internal noise paradigm[1] decomposes contrast sensitivity into two independent quantities: Equivalent Internal Noise and Computational Efficiency. The decline of sensitivity towards high spatial frequencies is likely to be due to optical and acuity factors. The decline at low spatial frequencies comes mostly from an increase in internal noise[2]. This effect is even more pronounced in aging[3], accounting for most of the sensitivity decrease at low spatial frequencies in older observers. To explain this dependency on both spatial frequency and age, we consider three hypotheses: 
(a) An increase in variability, which would lead to a measurable increase in equivalent internal noise. However, it is unlikely that cortical processing of low and high spatial frequency stimuli relies on vastly dissimilar mechanisms, such that their internal variability could actually be different.
(b) Different sizes of cortical receptive fields, according to which the increase of equivalent internal noise would stem from the larger integration area over which the stimulus, and thus the external noise, is averaged, thus reducing the ratio of external over internal noise. Cortical cells do in fact have larger receptive fields for low spatial frequency stimuli[4].
 (c) A change in non-linearity, such as the cortical contrast gain control. Retinal, thalamic and cortical gain control mechanisms affect contrast thresholds and internal noise. Baldwin et al.'s model[5] explains the sensitivity decrease by the saturation variable of the gain control non-linearity. Yet, they cannot explain why the gain control depends on spatial frequency, other than receptive field area. 
We tested these hypotheses in a linear-non-linear orientation detection model. We could recreate an increase in internal noise when using appropriate increases in spatial integration at each spatial frequency (hypothesis b). Mechanisms (a) and (c) could also be used to alter equivalent noise measurements (possibly explaining aging effects at low spatial frequency). In this poster, we discuss the plausibility of spatial frequency and age dependence for each of the proposed mechanisms, as well as interactions between them.
title: Using Equivalent Internal Noise as a Constraint on Vision Models

reasonForTalk: Visual modulation across saccades have not been shown before in the retina. I therefore show interesting data suggesting that diversity of modulations known from higher visual areas might be caused by modulations within the retina.
text:
During natural viewing, image flow on the retina is determined primarily by the behavior of the observer. Eye movements during active visual exploration, such as saccades, are particularly dominating in this regard, especially because they incessantly occur 3-5 times per second. Despite this, retinal image processing has in the past often been studied with isolated stimuli, ignoring the highly dynamic aspects of natural viewing. We are therefore exploring the effects of eye-movement induced image motion on signal processing in the retina. 

We recorded activity of ganglion cells from isolated mouse and pig retina using multi-electrode arrays (MEA) while showing a visual stimulus paradigm mimicking saccades. The paradigm consisted of rapid saccade-like image shifts across the retina followed by a test stimulus at different intervals after the saccade.

We found that the retinal responses to these "test stimuli", when presented in the context of saccades, are strongly modulated in comparison to responses to the same stimuli presented in isolation. Moreover, we show that saccades exude their modulatory effects for up to 1 second, suggesting a highly relevant role of eye-movement induced effects under natural conditions with short inter-saccadic fixations. Importantly, our results indicate that saccade-related retinal modulation critically depends on the statistical properties of the background scene present during the saccade; on the ambient luminance level; and on the specific retinal cell type. For example, the responses of OFF ganglion cells, but not ON ganglion cells, can be positively modulated after saccades. This suggests that the different pathways within the retina are distinct with respect to the properties of saccadic modulation. Thus, the diversity of modulations known from higher visual areas might be, at least in part, caused by the diverse modulations seen in the retina.
title: Retinal processing around saccades

text: Moving gaze from one point of a scene to another is coupled with a mandatory shift of attention: visual performance increases selectively at the saccade target (Kowler & Schneider, 1995 [1]; Deubel & Schneider, 1996 [2]). The mechanisms underlying these pre-saccadic attention shifts remain unclear. Here, we investigate if saccade preparation modulates perceptual orientation tuning curves, similar to attention-related changes in neuronal orientation tuning in visual cortex. In a psychophysical experiment, we presented two sequences of randomly oriented Gabor patches at a temporal frequency of 30 Hz, left and right of fixation. Simultaneously with the onset of these two sequences, a central cue pointed to one of them, and observers were asked to generate a rapid eye movement to the cued location. The sequences disappeared with saccade onset. Upon saccade landing, a response cue highlighted with equal probability the location of the saccade target (congruent trials), or the opposite location (incongruent trials). Observers had to report whether a target orientation (horizontal or vertical, defined before each block of trials) was present in the sequence. Using a reverse correlation approach, we studied distributions of stimulus orientations in trials in which observers reported presence of the target orientation, allowing us to quantify the temporal dynamics of perceptual orientation tuning before saccade onset. We observed a strong influence of saccade preparation on perceptual orientation tuning: Present reports were associated with orientations tuned to the target orientation if these appeared within 100ms before saccade onset, and this effect was specific to congruent trials. Our findings suggest that pre-saccadic perceptual benefits arise from the temporal dynamics of orientation tuning before saccades. We will discuss similarities and differences in the dynamics of perceptual and neural orientation tuning curves.
title: Perceptual orientation tuning before saccades

text:
The detection of motion direction and velocity in visual scenes is important in everyday tasks, e.g., for avoiding cars when crossing the street or for assessing the optic flow when navigating through a room. We study the encoding of visual motion on the level of the retinal ganglion cells. There, direction-selective ganglion cells (DSGCs) are known to encode certain directions of a drifting pattern. They are thought to provide important information about the optic flow to higher brain areas. In the salamander, we found three subtypes of DSGCs whose preferred directions are separated by 120°, similar to the directional organization of ON-type DSGCs observed in mouse. We probed the motion encoding of salamander DSGCs with more complex motion patterns than simple drifting gratings and projected textures following a 2-dimensional random walk onto the isolated salamander retina. We recorded up to 30 DSGCs simultaneously with multielectrode arrays for performing population analysis.
We used a commonly deployed linear decoder to estimate which features of a random motion trajectory a downstream neuron could extract from the responses of individual DSGCs and DSGC populations. The linear reconstruction of the motion trajectory from individual DSGC responses captured low-frequency components of motion into the cell's preferred direction. We derived the mutual information between stimulus and linear reconstruction and found that the joint activity of DSGC populations with different preferred directions conveyed more information than the sum of its individual contributions. This synergy is caused by the fact that motion encoding by individual DSGCs for complex stimuli is strongly confounded by non-motion-direction-related activity, leading to a non-monotonic nonlinearity in the motion encoding. The concerted firing of DSGCs with different preferred directions can counteract the ambiguity of this non-monotonic stimulus dependence.
Our findings suggest that in complex visual scenes, the decoding of motion direction from DSGC responses is challenged by the simultaneous encoding of strong contrast changes in the cell's receptive field caused by large translational movements of the pattern in either direction. This leads to a strongly nonlinear direction encoding whose unfavorable effects for linear motion decoding are partly compensated by the concerted signalling of DSGCs with different preferred directions, causing synergy.
title: Synergy in the linear decoding of random motion trajectories from populations of direction-selective ganglion cells

text:
When free-viewing scenes, the first few fixations of human observers are driven in part by bottom-up attention. Over the last decade a large number of models have been proposed to explain these fixations. One problem the field is facing is that the different metrics used to evaluate model performance produce very different rankings for the models. We recently standardized model comparison using an information-theoretic framework and found that existing models captured at most 1/3 of the explainable mutual information between image content and the fixation locations, which might be partially due to the limited data available [1]. Subsequently, we tried to tackle this limitation using a transfer learning strategy. Our model "DeepGaze I" uses a neural network (AlexNet, [2]) that was originally trained for object detection on the ImageNet dataset. It achieved a large improvement over the previous state of the art, explaining 56% of the explainable information [3] (Figure 1c). In the meantime, a new generation of object recognition models have since been developed, substantially outperforming AlexNet. The success of “DeepGaze I” and similar models suggests that features that yield good object detection performance can be exploited for better saliency prediction, and that object detection and fixation prediction performances are correlated. Here we test this hypothesis. Our new model "DeepGaze II" uses the VGG network [4] to convert an image into a high dimensional representation, which is then fed through a second, smaller network to yield a density prediction. The second network is pre-trained using maximum-likelihood on the SALICON dataset and fine-tuned on the MIT1003 dataset. Remarkably, DeepGaze II explains 83% of the explainable information on held out data (Figure 1c), and has since achieved top performance on the MIT Saliency Benchmark. The problem of predicting spatial fixation densities under free-viewing conditions could be solved very soon.
What makes DeepGaze predictions different? Models before DeepGaze were not only close in performance but also very similar in their predictions, clustering mostly around a simple mean-contrast-luminance model (MLC, Figure 1d). Prediction performance over time shows that DeepGaze II is especially successful at explaining fixations in the first 600ms (Figure 1e). The fact that fixation prediction performance is closely tied to object detection informs theories of attentional selection in scene viewing.
title: DeepGaze II: Explaining nearly all information in image-based saliency using features trained on object detection

text: Neurons in the central nucleus of the main center of convergence in the auditory midbrain, the central nucleus of the inferior colliculus (ICC) have been shown to display either linear significant receptive fields [1] or both linear and nonlinear significant receptive fields [2]. In this study, we used reverse correlation to probe linear and nonlinear response properties of single neurons in the cat ICC. The receptive fields display areas of stimulus parameters leading to enhanced or inhibited spiking activity, and allow investigating neural processing of complex sounds. Spiking responses were obtained from recordings of anesthetized cats in response to dynamic moving ripple (DMR) stimuli [3]. The DMR sound contains amplitude and frequency modulations and allows systematically mapping neural preferences. Spike-triggered average and covariance were computed for the envelope of the DMR, separately for each frequency carrier (range of 0-5.5 octaves). This enables studying processing of the sound envelope, and to investigate whether nonlinearities are more pronounced at the neuron's preferred frequency rather than for other frequencies. We find that more than half of the neurons display significant nonlinear response properties at least for one frequency carrier. Nonlinearities are dominant at the neuron's best frequency. The nonlinear preferences have either the same or opposite temporal receptive field pattern (e.g. on-off) as the linear preferences. No relationship to other neural properties such as feature-selectivity, phase-locking, or the like has been found. Thus, these nonlinearities do not seem to be linked to a specific type of neuron but to be inherent to ICC neurons indicating a diverse range of filtering characteristics.
title: Nonlinear response properties of single neurons in the auditory midbrain

text: An objective of sensory neuroscience is to understand how the brain responds to the natural world.  This is true for the sense of hearing, however much of our understanding of the auditory system has been garnered using carefully crafted artificial stimuli.  In this study we employed natural sound textures, such as sparrows chirping or a stream flowing, to investigate the functional organization of the human auditory system using fMRI and sound synthesis.  Behavioral evidence from McDermott and Simoncelli (2011) suggest sounds textures are identified using time-averaged summary statistics, but possible neural mechanism have yet to be explored. In this study, synthetic textures were generated from “texture statistics”, including marginal moments and pair-wise correlations, measured from a model that captures the frequency and amplitude modulation selectivity of the auditory system. Contrasting the BOLD-signal change between synthetic textures and spectrally matched noise for six different texture families, we observed texture-selective responses in auditory cortex, including Heschl’s Gyrus and anterior planum temporale. In a second experiment, we generated textures by cumulatively including five subgroups of statistics for seven different texture sounds. A corresponding increase in BOLD-signal strength in auditory cortex was observed as the statistical subgroups were included. However, the BOLD-signal strength in inferior colliculus was similar for all statistical subgroups.  In a corresponding behavioral experiment, we found that listeners’ ability to identify textures generated with different statistical subgroups correlated with the parametric increase in BOLD-signal strength, particularly in right planum polare and left planum temporale. Collectively, these results point towards a cortical mechanism that could identify auditory textures via time-averaged statistics.
title: Sensitivity to Sound Texture Statistics in Auditory Cortex

text:
Human sensitivity to the temporal detail of statistically homogenous sounds such as rain, fire, or flowing water (otherwise known as “auditory textures”) decreases with the stimulus duration. After the first few hundred milliseconds following stimulus onset, the auditory system seems to form a lossy, compressed representation of the detailed structure of texture sounds, as reflected by the inability to distinguish different exemplars of the same texture. This observation might be considered surprising given the known ability of auditory neurons to precisely encode fine temporal properties of sound, and it remains unclear why certain sounds have such a coarse perceptual representation. It has been proposed that lossy stimulus transformations are a consequence of inability of sensory systems to encode stimuli exceeding certain informational bandwidth. 

We consider whether sensory compression might instead be consistent with a normative perspective. We assume that the goal of the auditory system is to maximize information about the environment while minimizing energy expenditure. To achieve this goal the system should decrease encoding accuracy (i.e. coding cost) of stimuli which carry little information about the state of the world. Stimuli originating from a distribution which is predictable and known to the observer would accordingly be compressed in a lossy way. Due to their temporal stationarity, auditory textures are a prime candidate for such compression scheme.

To distinguish normative compression from capacity limits, we dissociated waveform coding cost (entropy, i.e. “density”) from stationarity by introducing practical measures of these properties. This allowed us to quantify them in natural sounds. In a psychophysical study we found that sound source stationarity, rather than entropy rate, was predictive of human performance in an exemplar discrimination task. Listeners had difficulty discriminating different exemplars generated by a homogenous source regardless of their entropy, suggesting that compression is not primarily due to coding capacity limits. In a second experiment we found that human listeners became able to discriminate the temporal detail of high entropy sounds following changes in the generating distribution. Taken together, our results suggest that perceptual compression of auditory textures reflects an adaptive coding strategy that minimizes processing resource when representing uninformative stimuli.
title: Lossy Compression of Stationary Stimuli by the Human Auditory System

text:
Recent studies have pointed out that the neural code may use multiplexing to encode unique information at different temporal scales of spike trains [1,2]. However, how to mathematically separate out the different components of a neural code and to identify the unique contribution of each time scale to sensory coding and behaviour has remained an open challenge.
Here we investigated this problem by analytically deriving the information loss caused by adding to the spike times a random jitter uniformly distributed within a given time range whose size is varied parametrically. By increasing the size of the jitter range we destroy gradually and in a controlled manner the contribution of the different temporal scales, from fine to coarse. Therefore, the derivative of the information with respect to the jitter represents the non-redundant information that each temporal scale conveys about the stimulus, and provides a way to easily quantify and summarize in one single figure the encoding strategy used by each individual neuron to temporally encode a particular set of stimuli. 
To implement this approach, which we termed the Information Derivative (IDE) method, we approximated the information derivative with respect to the jitter as follows: 1) we analytically derive the average firing rates associated with an arbitrary jitter size; 2) we use these analytical firing rates to compute the information contained in the jittered neural response, assuming no noise correlations. We tested the IDE method with simulated data in which several temporal scales are relevant for discriminating the presented stimuli and confirm the method is able to detect the contributing temporal scales and to assign the correct relative contribution to them.
The IDE method we propose allows inferring the contribution of different temporal scales to the information contained in the neural responses about a given set of stimuli. The method thus provides a way of studying in detail the information processing capabilities of a multiplexed neural code.
title: A Novel Approach to the Analysis of Multiplexed Neural Codes

text:
The mouse gains ever increasing importance as a model to study the visual system. One well established behavioral methodology to quantify visual abilities in mice is based on the optomotor reflex: Mice compensate for global image drift in the visual environment with reflexive eye (optokinetic) and head (optomotor) movements. This behavior can be used to characterize the visual features that can still be recognized by the animal, thus gaining information about spatial acuity or contrast sensitivity. 
In the “virtual” optomotor drum, the animal is surrounded by computer screens which display a slowly rotating striped cylinder. Previous versions of the optomotor drum suffered from three major shortcomings, which are addressed in our newly developed "OptoDrum" testing system. First, there was no animal detection software available to provide reliable position data to analyze the gaze direction. We developed a robust automated image analysis package, for detecting freely moving mice in a non-static illuminated background. Our algorithm is specifically adapted for the precise detection of head-follow movements, to analyze the behavior inside the optomotor drum. Second, with freely moving animals, accurately measuring the visual acuity is compromised when the distance between the subject (mouse) and the object (rotating stripes) changes. We solve this problem by automatically adjusting the stripe width in real time to the position of the animal. Third, assessing the animals' behavior has previously been performed by human observers, introducing subjectiveness and bias to the results. We have developed a robust algorithm which scores the animals' behavior reliably without user interference. 
Our data show the applicability of the method by characterizing the contrast sensitivity function of wild type (wt) mice, as well as the progressive decline of visual performance in mouse models of retinal degeneration.
title: Automated Characterization of Visual Performance in Mice  Based on the Optomotor Reflex

text: Our experience of the world depends on integration of cues from multiple senses to form unified percepts. How the brain merges information across sensory modalities has been the object of debate. To measure how rats bring together information across sensory modalities, we devised an orientation categorization task that combines vision and touch. Rats encounter an object comprised of alternating black and white raised bars that looks and feels like a grating and can be explored by vision (V), touch (T), or both (VT). The grating is rotated to assume one orientation on each trial, spanning a range of 180 degrees. Rats learn to lick one spout for orientations of 0±45 degrees (``horizontal'') and the opposite spout for orientations of 90±45° (``vertical''). Though training was in VT condition, rats could recognize the object and apply the rules of the task on first exposure to V and to T conditions. This suggests that the multimodal percept corresponds to that of the single modalities. Quantifying their performance, we found that rats have good orientation acuity using their whiskers and snout (T condition); however under our default conditions, typically performance is superior by vision (V condition). Illumination could be adjusted to render V and T performance equivalent. Independently of whether V and T performance is made equivalent, performance is always highest in the VT condition, indicating multisensory enhancement. Is the enhancement optimal with respect to the best linear combination? To answer this, we computed the performance expected by optimal integration in the framework of Bayesian decision theory and found that most rats combine visual and tactile information better than predicted by the standard ideal observer model.  Electrophysiological recordings in the posterior parietal cortex (PPC) of behaving rats revealed that neuronal activity is modulated by decision of the rats as well as by categorical or graded modality-shared representations of the stimulus orientation. Because the population of PPC neurons expresses activity ranging from strongly stimulus related (e.g. graded in relation to stimulus orientation) to strongly choice related (e.g. modulated by stimulus category but not by orientation within a category) we suggest that this region is involved in the percept-to-choice transformation.
title: Visual tactile integration in rats and underlying neuronal mechanisms

text:
To understand how sensory input maps to neural activity is one of the key goals of sensory neuroscience. Ever since the seminal work of Hubel and Wiesel [1] the notion of receptive fields have greatly aided our understanding of how information entering our senses is represented in the brain. Though receptive fields were initially posed as a property of individual neurons, it is now clear that the notion of receptive fields can also be applied to a population of neurons in for example an fMRI voxel [2]. Current techniques for estimating population receptive fields have been using a grid search approach to find the parameters that maximize the likelihood. Here we present a Bayesian technique that poses several advantages over the currently used approaches. 
Our technique is based on estimating the posterior probability of the receptive field parameters given  measured neural data by use of a slice sampler. By estimating a probability distribution we automatically obtain an uncertainty measure of the estimated parameter values in contrast to the grid search approach, where just the best fit is returned. In estimating the posterior we have the benefit of being able to include priors on our parameters, which can greatly improve the estimates of the population receptive field estimates. 
We show in simulations that our technique improves the estimate of population receptive field parameters over the grid search approach. On a real fMRI data set, we compare our approach to the grid search approach and show the benefits of having an uncertainty measure and a prior on the population receptive field parameters.
The flexibility of this Bayesian approach also provides possibilities for easy extensions of this model. Here we use only Gaussians as the underlying population receptive field model, but this approach can easily be extended to estimate more complex models of receptive fields. Furthermore, it is possible to extend our model to also include estimates of physiological parameters of a voxel such as its hemodynamic response function. We believe that the flexibility and benefits of our approach will make it a valuable tool for any researcher trying to understand the mapping from sensory input to neural activity.
title: Bayesian Population Receptive Field Estimation

text:
Physico-chemical processes in all living creatures strongly depend on temperature. In nervous systems, this particularly applies to the ion channel kinetics underlying electrical activity [1]. Therefore, variations in temperature are likely to interfere with signal encoding and information processing. Mammals invest energy into the maintenance of a constant body temperature, thus retaining functional nervous systems despite a temperature dependence of their components. In contrast, cold-blooded animals (poikilotherms) adopt the temperature of their surroundings, such that changes in temperature directly affect neural processing, with potentially severe consequences for behavior. Yet, many poikilotherms exhibit robust behaviors across the temperature range they are exposed to, and hence must have developed compensatory mechanisms.

Female grasshoppers, in particular, recognize the courtship song of male conspecifics across a temperature range of around 15°C [2]. Whether this robustness is achieved at the cellular or network level is unknown. Here, we address this question and, first, studied the effect of temperature on ascending neurons, a known bottleneck of sound processing [3]. To that end, we fitted linear-nonlinear models [4,5] to neural responses to sound stimulation at different temperatures. We found no consistent effect on nonlinear processing, but temperature affected the shape of neural temporal filters, ruling out a purely cellular mechanism of temperature compensation.

The temperature dependence of the recorded cells apparently did not match the known temperature robustness of song recognition on the behavioral level. We hence tested how to resolve this discrepancy using a neural filter-based model of song recognition. Relying on a very basic set of computations, our model quantitatively reproduced published grasshopper song preferences [2]. Importantly, introducing the measured temperature dependence of neural filters to the model enabled temperature robustness of song recognition.

Our results hence suggest that temperature robustness of song recognition is achieved via a network effect, based on temperature-dependent neural filters. Due to its simplicity, the proposed mechanism of temperature compensation may be used in other poikilothermic sensory systems.
title: Robust pattern recognition with temperature-dependent neural filters

references.text: Retinal bipolar cells: elementary building blocks of vision
The functional diversity of retinal ganglion cells in the mouse

text:
The extraction of visual features into parallel streams begins in the retina. Visual stimuli are transmitted from the photoreceptors via the bipolar cells to the retinal ganglion cells, which in turn relay the signal to the brain. In mice, processing streams diverge from 3 types of photoreceptors to 14 types of bipolar cells types to at least 32 ganglion cell types (Euler et al., Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 2014; Baden, Berens, Franke et al., Nature, 2016). Two-photon imaging with calcium and glutamate-sensitive fluorescent indicators allows us to record neural activity in the mouse retina. In many cases of interest, multiple functional units are present within a single recording field, corresponding to axon terminal systems or dendritic trees of different bipolar or ganglion cells or – in the extreme - to different axon terminals or dendritic compartments of the same cell.

Here, we present experimental and computational methods for the reliable identification and separation of such components. Specifically, we establish alternative imaging strategies which improve the spatiotemporal resolution of the data allowing us to better separate signals from different neuronal compartments. In addition, we designed light stimuli to probe for differential activation of functional units. Finally, we developed computational models to capture the dynamic correlational structure in the data. Our preliminary data from bipolar cell axon terminals suggests that noise stimuli and simple receptive field estimation techniques can be used to identify functional units belonging to single cells. Units likely corresponding to axon terminals of a single bipolar cell often show distinct spatiotemporal patterns of activity, suggesting that different axon terminals of a single cell can signal partially independent information.
title: Identifying functionally independent units in the mouse retina

text:
Rodents are becoming increasingly popular models for the integrative study of the neural circuits underlying vision (Zoccolan et al., 2015). To lay solid foundations for such investigations, it is crucial to reconstruct the receptive field (RF) spatiotemporal structure of neurons in primary visual cortex (V1), which is the first stage in the cortical processing chain of visual information. Reverse correlation approaches, such as Spike Triggered Average (STA), allow probing visual neurons with random spatiotemporal luminance patterns to infer the RF transfer function (or filter) underlying the unit’s stimulus-response relationship (Schwartz et al., 2006). These methods have been successfully applied for this purpose in monkeys (Ringach et al., 2002), cats (DeAngelis et al., 1993) and, more recently, mice (Niell and Stryker, 2008), but never in rats.
In our study, we performed extracellular neuronal recordings, via 32-channel linear microprobes, from anesthetized rats, passively exposed to full-field, full-contrast visual stimulation. We recorded from 67 single units in V1. Their tuning profiles were assessed by analyzing their responses to drifting gratings, designed to match a range of spatial and temporal frequencies. We found the majority (~70%) of our sample population to be orientation selective (OSI >= 0.6) (Fig.1a, left panel). A much lower share (~30%) exhibited direction selectivity (DSI >= 0.6) (Fig.1a, central panel). The preferred combination of spatial and temporal frequency was observed to be 0.02 cpd and 4 Hz, respectively (Fig. 1a, right panel). Two examples of such tuning profiles are reported in the figure (Fig. 1b, left and central panels).
STA analysis, performed over the pattern of neuronal responses elicited by 0.02 cpd-matched Gaussian noise movies, allowed uncovering striking features in the RF structure of the sample population: i) multiple-lobed, Gabor-like structures (see examples in Fig. 1b right panels); ii) spatiotemporal inseparability, with inversions of excitatory and inhibitory lobes over the time preceding a spike. These properties were predictive of single unit orientation and direction tuning, as assessed with gratings. These results speak to the complexity of the computations performed by rat V1 neurons, highlighting their similarity with those performed by highly-visual mammals (such as monkeys and cats), thus stressing the potential of rats as models to investigate fundamental aspects of cortical visual processing.
title: Receptive field structure of visually selective neurons in rat visual cortex

text:
Fast gamma oscillations are commonplace along the visual pathway and can provide an effective mechanism to amplify and route information towards higher order visual areas and/or a way to bind simple visual features into a unique, more complex, percept. In the mouse these oscillations have been studied mainly in primary visual cortex and in relation to locomotor activity [1,2]. Less is known about how these oscillations are modulated by diffuse illumination (irradiance) in freely behaving animals and whether this modulation, if present, plays any functional role in visual perception. 
In a previous work we showed that different levels of photopic irradiance have a strong widespread effect on dLGN baseline and evoked firing rates [3]. Here we describe the emergence of gamma oscillations, a complementary component of irradiance spike responses in dLGN.  
We first show that gamma oscillations are reliably triggered by 10s irradiance steps both in anaesthetized mice and in awake freely moving mice (Fig.1A). In awake animals these oscillations are present both in stationary and moving animals. 
We carry on showing that these oscillations are coherent throughout the whole extent of the dLGN.  Increasing irradiance increases coherence in the gamma band (Fig.1B). Narrowband coherence has an important functional role: it allows an effective summation of responses throughout the dLGN. If disrupted the summed population response is substantially reduced (Fig.1C).  
Finally we show that long latency oscillatory potentials in mouse flash ERG also express narrowband gamma oscillations. By performing simultaneous ERG-dLGN recordings we confirm that they these oscillations are inherited from the inner retina. 
Our data show that irradiance driven gamma oscillations robustly occur during unconstrained behaviour, are inherited from the retina and, by enhancing coherence, provide a suitable temporal structure for population coding.
title: Modulation of fast narrowband oscillations in the mouse retina and dLGN according to background light intensity

text:
Pitch is a fundamental attribute of auditory sensation. A dyad is a sound presenting two simultaneous pitches; it is one of the most common perceptual scenarios in human auditory soundscape. However, the neuronal mechanisms underlying the perception of dyads are poorly understood.
Dyads evoke a strong percept related to the ratio between the fundamental frequencies of the two sounds. Simple ratios (e.g. 3:2) evoke a consonant, pleasant sensation while complex (e.g 16:15) ratios evoke a more dissonant percept. The N100m is a transient neuromagnetic response of the auditory evoked fields observed in MEG recordings, sensitive to fundamental auditory properties such as pitch or timbre [4]. The N100m is associated with activity in the antero-lateral Heschl's gyrus (alHG) in human auditory cortex (AC) [3]. 
First, we studied the effect of consonance and dissonance on the dynamics of the N100m using six different dyads built from two iterated rippled noise (IRN). We found a strong and significant correlation between the dissonance percept reported by human listeners (Fig. A, grey) and the latency of the N100m (Fig. A, blue).
The major goal of this study was to understand this correlation on the basis of the competitive dynamics of a cortical excitatory and inhibitory network of neural ensembles[6], endowing realistic neural and synaptic parameters [2]. Excitatory populations encode the pitch value, and receive direct inputs from an idealised model of subcortical processing [1], based on a well established model of the auditory periphery [7]. In accordance with recent findings on the organisation of the mammal AC [5], inhibitory-to-excitatory connectivities follow a harmonic pattern that is crucial for cortical processing of pitch.
The model was able to simultaneously decode the two single pitch values present within the stimuli, and to predict the latencies of the N100m evoked by the dyads (Fig. A, red; Fig. B compares field predictions and observations). 
The model output suggests that the correlation of the N100m latency with consonance perception stems from the harmonic connectivity structure in AC. Simple frequency ratios (consonant dyads) preserve a greater harmonic relationship than more complex ratios (see green dashed lines in Fig. A), and thus are naturally faster to decode in cortex, eliciting an earlier N100m.
In conclusion, our results suggest that the simulated competition dynamics in alHG provide a mechanistic explanation of consonance perception.
title: Mean-field model of auditory cortex explains the differences in neuromagnetic fields evoked by dissonant and consonant dyads

text: Assessing, validating and improving quality of human-robot interaction (HRI) is so far commonly performed by collecting subjective measure from human interaction partners in experimental HRI setups, e.g. questionnaire ratings. Although these measures can be of high value to roboticists and designers when aiming to improve general HRI, they are very sensitive and can be inaccurate or biased [1]. In this work, we propose a neuro-based method for objectively measure robot behavior in HRI. Using electroencephalography (EEG) signals acquired from a human interaction partner we aim at detecting the perception of inappropriate/unexpected/erroneous robot behaviors. In order to validate this method, we conducted a human-robot interaction experiment, in which a humanoid robot displayed context-dependent erroneous actions from time to time. The EEG data collected from 13 participants revealed biologically plausible error-related neurophysiological responses (ErrP) that resemble previously reported ErrPs from different, but related experimental contexts [2,3]. In case of robot erroneous actions, we observed the characteristic N2 component that has been reported consistently in relation to cases of high conflict (e.g. incongruent stimuli) [4]. Also, we observed an increased P300 component which has consistently been associated with stimuli expectancy. We further demonstrated that these responses can successfully be modeled with standard pattern recognition techniques and detected from the human EEG with above-chance classification accuracies of avg. 69.7%. With these findings we confirm principal feasibility of our proposed method and suggest that EEG-based ErrP detection can be used for quantitative evaluation and improvement of robot behavior and HRI.
title: Detecting erroneous robot behavior from the electroencephalogram (EEG) during human robot interaction

text: Rats collect tactile information about their surrounding environment while actively rubbing and taping their whiskers against objects. The nature of the physical signals that rats use for the discrimination of surface textures is still poorly understood. We investigated the mechanical modalities of the signal transference from the whiskers tip and object contact zone to the base and mechanoreceptors interface. To this end we extracted the spatiotemporal evolution of the local curvature of plugged rat vibrissae from their motion acquired by high speed and high resolution videography less than two kHz frame rate. The vibrissa was mounted on a rotating axis and swept by a stepper motor at different angular velocities and distances across sandpaper surfaces of different grades. Our measurements suggest that dynamic friction, expressed as stick slip movements of the vibrissa tip is converted to bending waves propagating along the whisker towards its base. We constructed a mathematical model which converts local curvature into moments along the vibrissa shaft. We found that the bending moment variations are transmitted quasi instantaneously from tip to base and are strongly amplified. In a second approach we aimed at explicitly modelling the tip contact zone giving rise to frictional movements and linking it to a model of the conically tapered shaft. Preliminary results showed good agreement of these model outcomes with the previously observed torque amplification.
title: Biomechanical coupling of frictional movements at the tip of a vibrissa to its base.

text: It has been discovered that the functional architecture of the visual cortex in carnivores and primates obeys invariant layout laws [1]. Currently the only quantitative explanation for the generation of this specific type of functional architecture is a symmetry defined class of optimization models [2]. It is known that models from this class exhibit a strong multistability. However, what is the exact number of essentially different solutions has been unsolved. Here we examine this question by means of group theoretic and combinatorial methods. We demonstrate the equivalence of the model solution set with self-dual configurations of so called necklaces [3]. This mapping provides an exact expression in terms of the Euler totient function that shows that the number of solutions grows to leading order exponentially. Furthermore, we define a natural metric that relates similar solutions to each other and examine whether a principled categorization of the solution set can be derived. A graph based on minimal distance in this metric is found to be densely connected. This shows the absence of structure in the solution space that could form the basis of a natural categorization. We conclude that lexicographic ordering is the most natural grouping possible. It is remarkable that a highly symmetric optimization problem, as studied here, exhibits an excessively large set of equivalent solutions. Our results provide a key ingredient for further studies of their detailed features.
title: On multiplicity of optima in models for the architecture of the visual cortex

text:
The insect olfactory system is an excellent model for the study of sensory processing. The first olfactory relay - the antennal lobe (AL) - is clearly structured and accessible for electrophysiological methods. In the AL processing of olfactory inputs occurs through a complex network local interneurons (LNs), intrinsic, and synaptic mechanisms. Interactions in the AL shape olfactory representations, e.g. regulating the tuning profile of projection neurons (PNs), the principal output neurons of the AL.

Although the cellular composition of the insect olfactory network has been studied extensively, knowledge of intrinsic cell properties and their dedicated functions is still fragmented. Thus, the characterization of PNs and the LNs is key in understanding odour responses and processing in the AL. In the cockroach $periplaneta\ americana$ recent work established morphology and physiological response properties of distinct LN types [1,2] and found a range of different spike frequency adaptation behaviours in LNs and PNs [3].

Here we add on to the characterisation of AL neurons in $periplaneta\ americana$ with a model driven approach. To this end, we estimate intrinsic neuron parameters from patch clamp recordings of LNs and PNs and test the performance of integrate and fire type models. In addition, we propose the fit of a generalized integrate-and-fire model [5] stimulating AL neurons with filtered Gaussian white noise currents [4]. Such inputs allow us to take into account the fluctuating nature of synaptic inputs. We anticipate this work to ground realistic models of AL neurons in the cockroach $periplaneta\ americana$
 .
title: Single Neuron Model Description and Intrinsic Properties of Different Neuron Types in the Cockroach Antennal Lobe

text:
The role of recurrent interactions in processing visual information in primary visual cortex is largely unclear at present. Moreover, the layout of orientation preference in primary visual cortex varies considerably across mammalian species, but it remains to be determined, whether this variation reflects different processing strategies [1]. Here we model the influence of different connectivity patterns in conjunction with different architectures for orientation selectivity on visual processing abilities. Specifically, we study which biologically plausible network structure exhibits superior performance in an angle discrimination task using moving oriented gratings.

Our model consists of a single-layer recurrent firing-rate network receiving an initially tuned feed-forward input in form of visual patterns passed through properly oriented Gabor filters. We vary the feed-forward tuning strength and test two different layouts of feed forward selectivity: a smooth orientation preference map (observed in primates and carnivores) and a salt-and-pepper organization (observed in rodents). Recurrent connectivity is considered as either purely distance-dependent or distance- and angle-dependent with excitation between cells with similar and inhibition between cells with orthogonal preferred orientations [2]. Varying the relative strength of lateral and feed-forward connections, we measure the performance in angle discrimination using a logistic regression classifier of population activity.

We find that a minimal amount of feed forward tuning is necessary for angle discrimination. A combination of orientation dependent inhibitory and excitatory lateral connections shows the largest performance in angle discrimination. Recurrent connectivity in the form of distant-dependent ‘Mexican-hat-type’ projections improves the performance with stronger effect for the smooth orientation map. Angle-dependent connectivity improves discrimination to a similar degree in both smooth maps and the salt-and-pepper organization. Improved discriminability is accompanied by an increase of the orientation selectivity in individual units, larger simple-to-complex cell ratio, increased population sparsity and a weak increase in the signal-to-noise ratio, but the increase of none of these properties by itself implies high discrimination performance. We conclude that recurrent interactions generate a complex population behavior which can be beneficial for processing visual information.
title: Angle discrimination in recurrent models of visual cortex

text:
Retinal waves are spontaneous bursts of activity propagating in the developing retina and thought to play a central role in shaping the visual system and retinal circuitry. They first occur at early embryonic stages of development and gradually disappear upon maturation. Understanding their generating mechanisms may help us control and use them in order to re-train the retina for rewiring and possibly improve vision restoration, after treatment, in some degenerative retinal diseases.
From the dynamical systems perspective, a retinal wave is spatiotemporal activity which is generated by the conjunction of local (cell level) nonlinear characteristics and network effects, can have different forms (fronts, spiral, standing waves) and is induced by generic dynamical mechanisms, associated with typical bifurcations. We have developed a biophysical model of these waves, close enough to biology to reproduce several prominent experimental results observed in [1], and accessible to dynamical systems analysis. The model features a network of cholinergic-coupled Starburst Amacrine Cells (SAC) with a Calcium-controlled slow After HyperPolarization current (sAHP) [2], [3]. SAC burst spontaneously and periodically and their coupling gives rise to spatio-temporal activity. Especially, arousal of waves is related to a specific type of bifurcation. More generally, we observe a wide variability of spatiotemporal patterns, depending on two important biophysical parameters: the rest potential (which can be changed upon pharmacological manipulations) and the coupling intensity (changing upon maturation). This variability is illustrated in Figure 1, where we compute the pairwise distance correlations between cells for different levels of cholinergic coupling strength. This shows that we can classify the emerging patterns according to the coupling strength, namely the cholinergic conductance. Therefore, our main conclusions are that one can observe substantial change in spatio-temporal activity within stage II depending either on maturation or on pharmacological control.  Our biophysical model is able to predict this change in the patterns within stage II and propose a specific recipe for experiments to validate our findings. This suggests new possible experiments to explore yet unexplored aspects in developmental retinal waves.
title: Classifying the spatiotemporal patterns within stage II retinal waves through dynamical systems analysis

text:
There have been many recent attempts at creating large-scale network models of spiking neurons to understand the functioning of the brain. In creating these large-scale brain models, there is a trade off between the level of detail and the size of the simulation due to the constraint of computational resources. While most of the large scale brain models use billions of cells with simplified spiking neuron models [1-4], a few have used multi-compartmental neuron models at a smaller scale (around 100,000 cells) with extreme detail in terms of cell morphology and ion channel mechanisms in the cell membrane [5, 6]. Dendrites play an important role in determining a neuron’s sensitivity to stimuli [7]. Therefore, it is a good idea to include dendritic morphology in simulations. We propose a reduced order model based on spike-triggered analysis [8] that preserves the features of morphology while improving computational efficiency. 

The spike-triggered analysis is used very frequently in experimental neuroscience [9, 10] to understand the relation between stimulus and spiking of sensory neurons. There are some cases where this method has been applied to computational models like integrate and fire neurons [11] and Hodgkin-Huxley neurons [12] to find isolated spikes (spikes preceded by a long silence) from current input. The spike-triggered analysis method commonly used is explained in Figure 1 (A and B).

We extend the spike-triggered analysis procedure to include effects of morphology and refractory period (Fig 1C). We apply the method on a multi-compartmental model containing cell body with Hodgkin-Huxley mechanism and one passive dendrite. To understand the effect of dendritic morphology, we find the STA and static nonlinearity for different locations along the dendrite by injecting white noise current at different locations of interest. To understand the effect of the cell’s refractory period, we compute the STA for different inter-spike intervals. We choose the STA dynamically based on time passed since the last spike and the static non-linearity based on the location of the current input. We compare the accuracy of our reduced model to the full model for white noise and synaptic inputs. We also propose a method of using our reduced order model in a network. For a single cell, the reduced order model is approximately ten times faster than the full HH model.
title: Reduced order modeling of dendrites using Spike Trigerred Average

text:
Two classical approaches to simulate neuronal networks are the time-driven and event-driven methods [1]. Both methods describe the physical system in terms of set of state variables representing the neurons and events that mediate their interaction, i.e. spikes.

In the discrete-time (on-grid mode) of the NEST simulator [2], the dynamics of each neuron is propagated by a pre-defined simulation step.  Various pitfalls of this approach such as artificial synchronization have been addressed previously by embedding event-driven methods in a globally time-driven simulation[4,5]. This method is applicable to a certain class of neuron models [3] whose sub-threshold dynamics can be exactly integrated by applying methods that process spikes in continuous-time.

However, the accuracy of these continuous-time "precise" models (off-grid mode) of the NEST simulator has not been systematically investigated yet. One source of imprecision is the possibility to miss spikes caused by brief and unnoticed excursions of the membrane potential beyond threshold. We here develop a new spike detection algorithm based on state-space analysis of variables governing the linear system of a leaky integrate-and-fire neuron with exponential currents. 

Conventional spike detection methods in time-driven simulations propagate the state of neuron forward i.e. from $t$ to $t+\Delta t$ (or) $t_{\mathrm{incoming\_event}}$ and check whether there has been a threshold crossing only at the end of time interval. If the neuron dynamics is such that its voltage is below threshold at $t$ and $t+\Delta t$ (or) $t_{\mathrm{incoming\_event}}$ and supra-threshold between, this leads to a spike miss. The idea of this work is to understand whether such voltage excursions occur and if so, how frequent they are and what is their effect on accuracy the of the LIF model. 

Instead of propagating the neuron state forward, we propagate the threshold plane backward in time to find the set of initial conditions (spiking states) that would cross threshold in the future. By doing so, we get two distinct regions in state-space: the initial states leading to a spike, and those not leading to a spike, within a simulation step as illustrated in Fig(1).

This algorithm confirms that the precise LIF model in NEST rarely misses spikes. The reason is that frequently arriving synaptic impulses effectively induce a fine-grained grid of check points making brief excursions above threshold extremely unlikely.
title: Perfect detection of spikes via time-reversal

text:
Background: Information theoretic approaches have been applied to a wide range of problems in neuroscience, including consciousness. A prominent example is the Integrated Information Theory (IIT) of consciousness developed by Tononi et al. IIT proposes a measure called φ to quantify the state-dependent information integration of a system of elements. However, the calculation of φ has undergone important changes over time, and the most recent instantiation by Oizumi et al. (IIT 3.0) features some aspects that are not easily apprehended, such as the assumption of virtual elements or conditional probabilities over the empty set of variables. We therefore aim at a parsimonious and traceable formulation of φ in a probabilistic model.
Formulation and Results: We interpret the elements of a system as random variables in a Markov process that can be described by probability distributions in standard notation. Under the assumption of conditional independence, we define a joint conditional distribution over all elements, corresponding to a Markov transition probability matrix. Together with the definition of a uniform distribution over past states, we derive a multidimensional joint distribution (MJD) encompassing two adjacent temporal states of a system. We suggest that all derivations for the calculation of integrated information are obtained from this MJD. Based on this, we show that the assumption of virtual elements is no longer necessary for IIT. We also examine the partitioning of a network and derive the number of possible bipartitions of a set of elements as an identity of the Stirling number of the 2nd kind. We assert that in IIT every bipartition corresponds to a factorization of the MJD and derive a general formulation of this, based on which the notion of conditioning with the empty set of variables is no longer necessary. We thus arrive at a general formulation of φ in a standard probabilistic framework. When applied to the same simple example system in IIT 3.0, our formulation allowed for a reproduction of φ without the need for virtual elements, conditioning with the empty set of variables, or normalization constants.
Discussion: We suggest that our formulation of φ may improve traceability and parsimony of IIT 3.0. Independent attempts to improve measures of integrated information have been made very recently by Oizumi et al. and Tegmark, although more focused on IIT 2.0. Further work is necessary to extend our formulation to non-discrete systems.
title: A parsimonious probabilistic formulation of integrated information

reasonForTalk: We give general and novel insights about the influence of the readout mechanism of synchronous activity on information transmission. This work combines analytical theory, computer simulations and analysis of experimental data.

text: Synchronous firing of neurons is a prominent feature in many brain areas. Here, we are interested in the information transmission by the synchronous spiking output of a noisy neuronal population,  which receives a common time-dependent sensory stimulus. Earlier experimental [1] and theoretical [2] work revealed that synchronous spikes encode preferentially fast (high-frequency) components of the stimulus, i.e. synchrony can act as an information filter. In these studies a rather strict measure of synchrony was used: the entire population has to fire within a short time window. Here, we generalize the definition of the synchronous output, for which only a certain fraction γ of the population needs to be active simultaneously – a setup that seems to be of more biological relevance. We characterize the information transfer in dependence of this fraction by the spectral coherence function between the common stimulus and the partial synchronous output. We present analytical approximations to derive this frequency-resolved measure. We show that there is a critical synchrony fraction, namely the mean of the summed activity of the population, which maximizes the information transmission of the synchronous output.  At this value, the partial synchronous output acts as a low-pass filter, whereas  deviations from this critical fraction lead to a more and more pronounced band-pass filtering effect. We confirm our analytical findings by numerical simulations for the leaky integrate-and-fire neuron.  We also show that these findings are supported by experimental recordungs of P-Units electroreceptors of weakly electric fish [3], where the filtering effect of the synchronous output occurs in real neurons as well.
title: Information filtering by partial synchronous spikes  in a neuronal population

text:
Two important parts of electrophysiological recordings are the spike times and the local field potential (LFP), which is considered to primarily reflect input activity. In [1], it was shown by unitary event analysis [2,3] that excess synchronous spike events are locked to the phase of LFP beta-oscillations more strongly than spikes not part of such events. Denker et al. proved by a statistical model that this finding could be explained by the existence of cell assemblies, i.e. groups of (excitatory) neurons that are more strongly connected amongst each other than to the rest of the network.
To study the influence of the LFP on the correlated single neuron activities first for a simple model capturing the main properties of cortical neural networks, we examine a balanced network of homogeneously connected binary model neurons [4] receiving input from a sinusoidal perturbation [5]. The Glauber dynamics of the network is simulated and approximated by mean-field theory. Treating the periodic input in linear response theory, the cyclostationary first two moments are analytically computed, which agree with their simulated counterparts over a wide parameter range. The deviations of the zero-time lag correlations from their stationary values consist of two summands owing to the modulated susceptibility (one via direct modulation, one via modulated mean activity) and one to the driving of the autocorrelations. For some parameters, this leads to resonant correlations and non-resonant mean activities. Our results can help to answer the question how oscillations in mesoscopic signals and spike correlations interact. As a next step, our model could be extended to include cell assemblies [6], which will allow us to compare our results with the experimental findings more closely.
title: How does an oscillatory drive shape the correlations in binary networks?

text:
Learning the receptive fields of V1 simple-­cells, given natural scene input, is a well studied setting. For this,
several models based on spike­-timing dependent plasticity (STDP) have been published. However, these
models have several limitations as they rely on rate­-based learning dynamics (referring to symmetric STDP),
lack an inhibitory circuit, or have only been described in a single­-neuron setting [1,2,3].
We   implemented   a   spiking   network   consisting   of   144   excitatory   and   36   inhibitory   recurrent   connected
neurons, receiving inputs from a population of Poisson neurons. Excitatory synapse strengths are learned
using a homoeostatic voltage­-based triplet STDP rule [4], and inhibitory synapse strengths using symmetric
inhibitory   STDP   [5].   The   network   was   stimulated   with   pre­-whitened   natural   scene   patches   [6]   and
implemented with the neural simulator ANNarchy [7].
The   neurons   in   the  network   develop   V1   simple   like   receptive   fields.   Further,   excitatory  and   inhibitory
neurons   with   similar   tuning  develop   strong   bidirectional   synaptic   weights.   We   observed   that   a   state   of
balanced   excitation   and   inhibition   was   virtually   impossible   to   achieve   using   the   pulse­like   synaptic
transmission used in the STDP model by Clopath et al. [4], which led to strongly fluctuating excitatory and
inhibitory synaptic currents with little temporal correlation in our setting. As a consequence, we employed
longer synaptic time constants, which improved the representation acuity of the network in terms of the
image reconstruction error.
However, this also had effects on the learning dynamics, such as differences in the feed­-forward receptive
field sizes and learning speed, presumably through compensatory effects of the homoeostatic mechanism of
the excitatory learning rule on the inhibitory learning. Finally, the model's coding performance compares
favourably to existing models [1].
title: Combination of voltage­-based STDP with symmetric iSTDP to learn V1 simple­-cells

text:
Although genetic information is critically important for brain development and structure, it is widely believed that neocortical functional architecture is largely shaped by activity dependent mechanisms. The information capacity of the genome appears too small to contain a blueprint for hardwiring the cortex.
 Here we show theoretically that genetic mechanisms can circumvent this apparent information bottleneck. Using our prior research on universality classes of circuit self-organization in the visual cortex [1], we devised mathematical models of genetic networks of neurons interacting by long-range axonal morphogen transport.  Neurons dynamically generate morphogen patterns that prescribe the layout of orientation domains as experimentally observed in the primary visual cortex (V1) of primates and carnivores [2,3,4]. We use analytical methods from weakly non-linear analysis [5] complemented by numerical simulations to obtain solutions of example genetic networks. In particular we find that active transport and fast synaptic rearrangements are crucial for orientation domain development. Furthermore, we scan for specific genetic networks that produce orientation domains, which are best compatible with experimental data.
The hypothesis of genetic circuits shaping the complex architecture of V1 is in line with several recent biological findings. For instance, (1) transcription factors have been found to be transported via axons and to translocate into the nucleus of  target neurons [6], (2) a molecular correlate was recently found for ocular dominance columns in V1 [7], (3) V1's architecture is intriguingly robust against radically abnormal developmental conditions such as dark rearing [2,4,8].
Our theory for the first time shows how a complex cortical processing architecture can be specified using a genetic mechanism of small bandwidth and opens a novel perspective on the experimentally observed robustness of V1's architecture against radically abnormal developmental conditions [8].
title: Genetic assimilation of visual cortical architecture

text:
Depending on behavioral context, sensory signal information is selectively routed throughout the brain. For the visual system, studies have shown that V4 neurons can ‘select’ the behaviorally relevant stimulus out of multiple active inputs [1]. The corresponding mechanisms are still debated, however, frequency-band synchronization has emerged as a promising candidate, proposing that information routing (IR) occurs between populations with a favorable phase-locked relationship and is suppressed otherwise (communication-through-coherence, CTC) [2]. 
Electrical stimulation offers the possibility of causally testing CTC by externally perturbing the neural dynamics, and by quantifying its impact on IR. However, there are two major obstacles. First, one has to quickly and accurately determine the actual network state from noisy, non-stationary activity. Second, the behavior of a coupled system is much more constrained than the dynamics of its constituting modules in isolation, making it difficult to control by external stimulation.
Here, we address these two problems in a biophysically realistic model [3] (Fig A) by exploring a paradigm that employs precisely timed perturbations derived from phase-response curves (PRCs) to control the relative phase of neural populations, allowing for direct control over IR [4]. In contrast to enforcing a desired state by strong stimulation, we use minimal perturbations to push a multistable system into one of its preferred states.
To determine the network's state in real-time, we investigated multiple methods, finding that a combination of predictive autoregression (AR), bandpass filter and Hilbert transform provides the best results [5]. It is fast and accurate, and perfectly applicable to animal experiments even in presence of recording/stimulation artifacts. Further, we focused on the network's dynamics and analyzed its tendency to spontaneously switch between states where either population X or Y is in favorable phase with Z. Using previously calculated PRCs together with AR real-time Gamma phase estimation (Fig B), we exploit this bistability for controlling which populations will enter a favorable phase relationship. In particular, we propose two alternative scenarios in which this is possible by stimulating higher level, or by stimulating lower level areas (Fig A+B). By imposing independent signal streams onto the input populations, we prove that our controlled synchronization routes information as desired.
title: Model-based inferences into attention and bistablity information routing control via precisely-timed pertubations
