text:
Spikelets are small spike-like depolarizations that can be measured in somatic intracellular recordings. In general, spikelets are considered to reflect action potentials (APs) generated in an electrotonically distinct compartment. However, the precise origin of spikelets in pyramidal neurons is not well understood.
    Chorev and Brecht (2012) performed dual intra- and extracellular recordings in hippocampal pyramidal neurons in vivo and identified extracellular correlates of AP and spikelet firing. They observed that the onset of the AP-associated extracellular waveform slightly precedes the onset of the spikelet-associated waveform, which provides strong constraints for the mechanism(s) of spikelet generation in pyramidal neurons.
    To gain further insights into the implications of this data for spikelet origin, we simulated extracellular waveforms associated with APs and spikelets in compartmental models of pyramidal neurons. We considered spikelets generated in neurons coupled by gap junctions as well as spikelets originating at the axon initial segment in a single cell.
    According to our results, the single-cell hypothesis of spikelet origin is consistent with the experimental data by Chorev and Brecht (2012). Also the electrotonic coupling mechanism can account for all considered data features, but only for an axo-axonal location of the gap junction and a large distance (> ca. 140 μm) between the somata of the coupled cells, such that  the extracellular AP waveform only reflects the intracellularly recorded cell . This scenario is virtually indistinguishable from a single-cell case, in which spikelets are evoked through distal axonal stimulation  (antidromic spikelets).
    Our simulations demonstrate that a cell producing a spikelet generates a measurable  extracellular waveform, and importantly, that this waveform is different from when the same cell shows an AP. This implies that spikelets and APs generated in a single cell will be incorrectly classified as two different units in extracellular recordings, albeit they together constitute the output of a single pyramidal cell.
title: Extracellular correlates of spikelets: what do they reveal about spikelet origin?

text: One prominent feature of pathological states such as Parkinson's disease is the emergence of correlated neural activity among basal ganglia output neurons (Bergman et al., 1998). Importantly, in healthy animals the activity in basal ganglia output regions is usually uncorrelated, potentially due to active decorrelation (Wilson, 2013). However, the functional role of active decorrelation on information transmission from the basal ganglia to downstream regions is unknown. Basal ganglia output neurons transmit motor commands, for example by decreasing their firing rate during movement initiation (Schmidt et al., 2013). Previous studies have shown that such decreases in firing rate may generate low-threshold rebound spikes in thalamocortical neurons (e.g. Goldberg et al., 2013). Here we investigate the effect of different degrees of correlation among basal ganglia output neurons on the generation of rebound spikes in a Hodgkin-Huxley model of a thalamocortical neuron (Rubin et al., 2004). Our results show that, for uncorrelated input, the thalamocortical model neuron elicits a rebound spike exclusively briefly after the movement-related decrease. However, even small correlations in the input lead to rebound spikes also at other, random times, which may impair the clear transmission of motor commands. Moreover, correlations in the input increase variability in the timing of the rebound spikes triggered by the movement-related decrease. We conclude that active decorrelation in the basal ganglia output may promote transmission of motor commands via thalamic rebound spikes with high temporal precision. Furthermore, pathological correlations and the resulting impaired transmission of motor commands may be related to some of the motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease (Magnin et al., 2000).
title: Active decorrelation in basal ganglia output promotes transmission of motor commands to thalamus

text:
To produce complex sequential behaviors such as playing a musical instrument or writing, humans and some animals need to precisely coordinate their muscles on the timescale of seconds or minutes. How does the brain achieve this coordination for such long time scales is an open question. A putative neural mechanism for the production of sequences is the exploitation of an autonomously generated sequence of neural activations from which the desired motor output can be read out. It has been hypothesized that songbirds use this mechanism to produce songs, with neurons in RA that seem to read out from neurons in HVC [1,2]. In the songbird case the autonomously generated sequence in HVC is a chain-like pattern whose length scales linearly with the number of neurons. This strategy seems inadequate to apply for more complex sequential behaviors, since it would require a very large amount of neurons. We ask what is the longest sequence that can be autonomously generated.
We show that Hopfield neural networks with synchronous dynamics and asymmetric weights admit stable orbits that form sequences of maximal length. For $N$ units these orbits have length $T=2^N$ i.e. they cover the full state space. The result is obtained using a mathematical proof that proceeds by induction and that is constructive, i.e. it provides an algorithm to obtain both the orbit and the weight matrix that allows its production. 
The exponentially long orbit comes with the cost of an exponential fine tuning of the weights. Surprisingly however, the orbit is relatively robust to dynamical noise while perturbations of the optimal weights reveal other periodic orbits that are not maximal but typically still very long. Due to the learnability limit of the perceptron [3], not all the sequences of length $2^N$ can be read out from the autonomously generated one. Interestingly however, the resulting dynamics exhibits slow time scales, that can be used to generate non-trivial output sequences.
title: Maximal-length orbits in Hopfield neural networks

text: Reservoir networks are a well-established model of neural networks performing complex time-resolved computations [1]. In particular, they have been discussed as a possible model of the processes implementing human and animal working memory [2]. The basic working principles of reservoir networks stem from the concept of non-autonmous and non-linear transient systems [3]. While various implementations and applications of reservoir networks have been shown, a thorough understanding of their actual abilities and limitations is missing. Typical tasks solved by reservoir networks include additive or multiplicative noise in the input signals or within the reservoir itself. However, in most tasks, the timinig of the input signals is very precise or even constant. In contrast, in real-world situations, neural network continuously interact with other networks, i.e. brain areas, or the environment. The signals received via these pathways, however, do not necessarily exhibit a reliable and precise timing. Here, we investigate the consequences of abolishing precise timing of input signals in benchmark tasks for the performance of reservoir networks. The network is trained to remember the sign of received stimulus pulses and produce an output signal depending on the sign of  the second-last received stimulus. We train the network by both the Echo State Approach [4] as well as the FORCE-method [5]. Interestingly, we find that in both cases the performance of  the reservoir declines dramatically with increasing variance in the input. Analyzing the dynamics of a trained network projected onto its principal components, we observe that the transient storage mechanism relies on only small distances between the different trajectories evoked by incoming stimuli. Introducing noise in the input timing directly affects this storage mechanism.  In order to increase the distances between trajectories representing different memory content, additional read-out signals maintaining relevant memory content can be introduced. It turns out that this way, the originally purely transient network is turned into a system with multiple attractor states. We propose that optimal performance is achieved if the maintenance of memory content and the production of complex output trajectories is separately implemented by attractor states and transients, respectively.
title: Influence of Input Timing Variance on the Performance of Reservoir Networks

text: Spike trains of cortical neurons are composed of a mixture of short bursts and single spikes. One mechanism for converting single spikes into bursts relies on active dendrites receiving top-down information. Specifically, single-cell experiments suggested that bursts signal a coincidence between bottom-up signals and the top-down signals impinging on apical dendrites (Larkum et al., 1999) but it is not clear how this mechanism scales to the network level. We investigate coding by burst and single spikes in networks of deep cortical cells in the presence of feedback inhibition onto their active dendrites. Our computational models are calibrated on electrophysiological recordings (Naud et al., 2014) to reproduce the signatures of calcium spikes in apical dendrites (Larkum et al., 1999, Larkum et al., 1999b) and the properties of Martinotti cells (Pala and Petersen, 2015). At the network level, we find that dendrite-mediated bursts compute a difference between top-down and bottom-up inputs. Coincidence detection is recovered when the Martinotti-cell inhibition is impaired either by reducing the net excitatory drive to inhibitory cells or by weakening the inhibitory synapses. Using regression analysis, we then determine a phenomenological model of the burst rate, which reveals that the burst rate computes a nonlinear function of the bottom-up and top-down inputs. Lastly, the top-down modulation of the firing rate is studied. We find that, in the presence of potent Martinotti-cell inhibition, the gain is affected by top-down inputs only in the weak input regime. This suggests a multiplexing of the neural code where spikes encode bottom-up signals but bursts encode a difference between top-down and bottom-up signals.
title: Difference or Coincidence: Burst and Single Spike Computations in the Martinotti Loop

text: Subgroups of neurons in barreloids of the rat ventroposterior medial thalamus (VPM) respond synchronously with temporal precision to different kinetic features of naturalistic whisker motion (spike-time coding) [1]. Temporally precise responses in the somatosensory cortex, such as those observed during passive whisker deflection or active whisking, are thought to be triggered by synchronously firing VPM cells, but the minimum number of convergent synchronously firing VPM cells needed to reliably drive the spiking of a given cortical cell is not known. Here, we used the Blue Brain Project’s digital reconstruction of a somatosensory microcircuit of a juvenile rat [2] to characterize this minimum number of convergent synchronous inputs for different morphological types in the somatosensory cortex. We activated an increasing number of synchronously firing VPM fibers in both simulations of single cells, and of the whole reconstructed microcircuit. We found that inhibitory neurons in layers 3 and 4 quickly approached maximum spike-timing reliability for around 10-15 synchronously firing VPM neurons. Excitatory neurons in layers 3 and 4 required substantially more synchronous VPM fibers, but less than excitatory neurons in layers 5 and 6. With an average of eight synapses per connection, these numbers are significantly higher than what was observed in a previous in silico study in the cat visual cortex [3]. We show that this can be attributed to a lower synaptic release probability in vivo than in vitro, due to lower extracellular calcium concentration [4], which is taken into account in our simulations but not in previous studies.
title: Spike-time encoding of thalamic inputs in a neocortical microcircuit with in vivo-like synaptic reliability

text:
High-level brain function such as memory, classification or reasoning can be realized by means of recurrent networks of simplified model neurons. Analog neuromorphic hardware constitutes a fast and energy efficient substrate for the implementation of such neural computing architectures in technical applications and neuroscientific research. The functional performance of neural networks is often critically dependent on the level of correlations in the neural activity. In finite networks, correlations are typically inevitable due to shared presynaptic input. Recent theoretical studies have shown that inhibitory feedback, abundant in biological neural networks, can actively suppress these shared-input correlations and thereby enable neurons to fire nearly independently. For networks of spiking neurons, the decorrelating effect of inhibitory feedback has so far been explicitly demonstrated only for homogeneous networks of neurons with linear sub-threshold dynamics. Theory, however, suggests that the effect is a general phenomenon, present in any system with sufficient inhibitory feedback, irrespective of the details of the network structure or the neuronal and synaptic properties.
Here, we investigate the effect of network heterogeneity on correlations in sparse, random networks of inhibitory neurons with non-linear, conductance-based synapses [Pfeil et al. (2016), Phys. Rev. X 6, 021023]. Emulations of these networks on the analog neuromorphic hardware system Spikey allow us to test the efficiency of decorrelation by inhibitory feedback in the presence of hardware-specific heterogeneities. The configurability of the hardware substrate enables us to modulate the extent of heterogeneity in a systematic manner. We selectively study the effects of shared input and recurrent connections on correlations in membrane potentials and spike trains. Our results confirm that shared-input correlations are actively suppressed by inhibitory feedback also in highly heterogeneous networks exhibiting broad, heavy-tailed firing-rate distributions. In line with former studies, cell heterogeneities reduce shared-input correlations. Overall, however, correlations in the recurrent system can increase with the level of heterogeneity as a consequence of diminished effective negative feedback.
title: Effect of Heterogeneity on Decorrelation Mechanisms in Spiking Neural Networks: A Neuromorphic-Hardware Study

text: It has been proposed [1] that the brain operates at criticality, as the critical point is associated with desirable properties such as optimal information processing capacity and maximal dynamic range [2,3,4]. In many critical systems activity occurs in avalanches, with the avalanche size $S$ following a probability distribution given by $p(S)\sim S^{-\gamma}$. This was observed both in vivo and in vitro with Local Field Potential (LFP) recordings [5,6], suggesting that the brain operates at criticality. However, the avalanche analysis introduces many parameters in order to extract discrete events from the continuous recording. Moreover, little is known about the processes contributing to the LFP [7,8]. Thus it is possible that the brain operates in a subcritical regime (which is supported by spiking data [9]), mistaken for critical by the avalanche analysis. Here we model the LFP using a two-layer system, where the network dynamics of firing nodes is measured by an array of simulated electrodes. We characterize the impact of analysis parameters and experimental conditions, and identify the inter-electrode distance (IED) as capable of masking subcriticality by generating power-law shaped $p(S)$ from subcritical systems (Fig. 1a,b). This is important in view of the availability of increasingly denser multi-electrode arrays. We suggest two ways of differentiating apparent from truly critical systems: (1) while varying the bin size $b$ and IED $d$ can change the shape of the avalanche size distribution, only for the critical system we observe an invariance of $p(S)$ as long as they obey $b_{2}/b_{1}=2^{d_{2}-d_{1}}$(Fig. 1c,d). (2) analyzing the LFP power-spectral density (PSD) we observe a $1/f^{\beta}$ decay in power. The exponent $\beta$ depends on the features of the system, e.g. if the signal decays as $1/R$ or $1/R^{2}$ with distance $R$ from the source, and whether a frequency filter is present. Therefore, $\beta$ can shed light into potential differences between in vivo and in vitro systems. Regarding criticality, the critical system displays a $1/f^{\beta}$spectrum, whereas the subcritical one is marked by a flatter spectrum for lower frequencies. While the $1/f^{\beta}$spectrum is not sufficient to assert a system as critical, only the critical system is expected to generate both $1/f^{\beta}$ spectrum and power-law avalanche distribution. Thus, combining avalanche and PSD analyses we can differentiate critical, subcritical and Poisson dynamics.
title: Deceptive Power-Laws: asserting criticality from coarse measures

text: Neuronal morphology shapes connectivity in a way that is dependent on the extent of the overlap of axonal and dendritic arbors (Hill et al., 2012; Stepanyants and Chklovskii, 2005). However, the extent to which the specific morphologies of different neuron types determine the emergence of specific motifs is still unclear. In a recent reconstruction of neocortical microcircuitry (Markram et al., 2015), we utilized this principle along with other biological constraints to derive a statistical neocortical microconnectome (Reimann et al., 2015). In this study, we will use information theory to investigate the structure of connectivity introduced by morphological diversity captured in the digital reconstruction. Our analysis reveals that morphological diversity severely constrains the space of possible connectomes. This is because different morphological types display characteristic distance dependent connectivity profiles, and prefered pre- and postsynaptic combinations of morphological types. Distance dependence and the bias for reciprocal connectivity can be explained by overlapping clouds of arbor densities, but the over-expression of clustered connectivity motifs requires specificity of neuronal arborization. We conclude that the principles determining the connectome cannot be understood without considering the detailed morphologies of individual neuron types.
title: Morphological Determination of Structured Neocortical Connectivity

text:
Neural morphology and membrane properties vary greatly between cell types in the nervous system. While the function of neurons is thought to be the key constraint for their biophysical properties, additional constraints may further shape neuronal design and explain observed properties. Here, we focus on principal neurons in the MSO nucleus of the auditory brainstem and show that a tradeoff between a functionally relevant computation and energy consumption predicts optimal ranges of biophysical parameters.

Biophysical properties of MSO cells as well as their function are well characterized: MSO cells encode the direction of sound in the horizontal plane. Inputs to MSO cells are phase-locked to sound wave stimuli to each ear and the interaural time difference (ITD) of sound waves is used to compute source location. To achieve sensitivity to ITDs in the range of tens of μs, MSO cells have specialized membrane properties, including a very fast membrane time constant (~1 ms) and a low-threshold K$^+$ current (I$_{\rm KLT}$), both contributing to a very short input integration window.

Next to function, energy use can be assumed to significantly constrain MSO cell properties. Overall, the brain accounts for a disproportionately large part (~20%) of the energy budget [1], with metabolic energy being mostly spent on synaptic input, action potentials, and resting potentials [2]. MSO cells, in particular, receive inputs at very high rates (hundreds of Hz), generate action potentials at similarly high rates, and display a very leaky membrane.

Here, we quantify and contrast sensitivity of MSO cells to ITDs as well as the associated metabolic cost. Using cable theoretic methods, we developed a mathematical model of MSO cells that included a quasi-active description of I$_{\rm KLT}$ [3]. Exploring the biophysical parameter space, we find that KLT parameters improve ITD sensitivity most efficiently with respect to energetic cost. Morphological parameters, in contrast, are key for minimizing costs, while having little effect on ITD sensitivity. For an energy-efficient ITD sensitivity we find optimal parameter ranges for dendritic diameter and KLT density, activation function, and activation time constant, matching with experimentally observed values. We conclude that the neural design of MSO cells is indeed compatible with functional and energetic constraints, and limited energetic resources may have played a substantial role in the evolution of these cells.
title: Function and energy consumption constrain biophysical properties of neurons - an example from the auditory brainstem

text:
Understanding communication and information processing in cortical networks requires the development of acquisition technologies which allow for minimally interfering, robust, and chronic recordings and/or electrical stimulation. For this purpose, we developed a novel type of multi-channel, freely floating probe that penetrates the cortical tissue perpendicular to the cortical surface (similar to state-of-the-art "Michigan-type" probes) and allows for the simultaneous recording of 16 channels up to a depth of about 1.4mm [1,2] (Fig.1a left). The advantage of our design is the direct connection of the silicon shaft to the cable without a rigid basement, thus allowing an implantation where the probe can freely float with the tissue which minimizes relative movement and avoids injury to the neural tissue.
We present results from chronic recordings in motor cortex of anesthetized rats to characterize the capabilities of the new recording technology. We analyzed 4 sessions of spontaneous activity (400-1000s each) made in one week, ca. 30 days after implantation. After low-pass filtering the raw signals (1-300Hz), we obtained local field potentials whose power spectra show a peak in the theta range (~7-10Hz) across most channels and weak gamma activity around 40Hz at channels 5-8 and 13-15.
With the spike-sorting tool WaveClus [3], we extracted spikes from the high-pass filtered signal (>300Hz) with mean rates up to 90Hz. The number of clusters per channel ranges from 0-4, with a mean of 1.4. There is evidence for slowly varying network (up and down) states, with periods of high activity separated by almost silent periods. We also observe high peaks at zero delay in spike cross-correlation (CC) functions between neighboring channels (Fig.1b). This might indicate that signals from one neuron can be picked up by multiple contacts or that two neurons pick up common input and fire at the same time. To investigate this further, we will use algorithms developed for multi-contact probes [4]. Cross-correlations also show that pairs of neurons tend to fire with a consistent delay between 5 and 21 ms, indicating that these sites are part of two subpopulations in a cortical column which become engaged in a particular temporal sequence during spontaneous activation (Fig.1c/1d). Most importantly, we showed that the quality of recordings is stable over time (Fig.1a right), demonstrating that high-quality, stable, chronic recordings are possible with the novel technology.
title: Analysis of neural signals from chronically implanted, novel multi-channel floating probes

text:
To understand neural coding it is crucial to understand how a neuron's spike generation is influenced by its own and the network's past activity. Here we explore information theoretic techniques to quantify memory in the spiking activity of a single neuron and use this analysis to compare memory effects of spike generation in vitro and in vivo (awake rat hippocampus).
We quantify memory as the mutual information (MI) between the future state (spike or no spike) and the past activity [1] that is represented as a pattern of binary spike counts (Fig. 1A). To make results comparable across neurons and recordings we study the relative information M=MI/H, i.e. we normalize by the Shannon information H of the spiking process without history. The memory M can be inferred from spiking data, either by fitting a statistical model, e.g. a generalized linear model (GLM), or in a model-free way by estimating directly the probabilities of past activity patterns. Though the latter approach is more generic, it is not applicable to arbitrarily long patterns as data are limited and consequently the analysis becomes corrupted by estimation bias. However, when reducing the number of past bins to avoid the bias, one might miss relevant information, and thus significantly underestimate M. Therefore, we use a Bayesian estimator (NSB [2]) with reduced bias and developed a criterion to detect the bias onset that was validated using a realistic model neuron [3] (Fig. 1B). This allows us to incorporate a maximum number of past bins while avoiding estimation bias. 
By systematically increasing the past time range (i.e. the number of past bins times the bin size), we found that in vivo and in vitro past activity of at least 50ms adds information about the neuron’s spiking probability (Fig. 1C,D). Conversely, considering less past, as it is commonly done in transfer entropy estimation, leads to considerable underestimation of M. In vitro, M is not only smaller but also becomes negligible in a GLM that additionally incorporates the past population activity (PPA), suggesting that the neuron's past serves only as a readout of the population activity and has no intrinsic memory contributions. In vivo, however, incorporating the PPA hardly decreased M. This indicates an interesting dynamic regime where the single neuron presents non-redundant information about the past, although being subject to inputs in a recurrent network.
title: Quantifying memory in the spike generation of single neurons in a neural population

text:
Synchronous neural activity is a typical activity in biological neural networks in-vivo and in-vitro. Spontaneous bursting activity plays an important role in the development of synaptic connections in dissociated cultured neural networks [1, 2]. In the brain, information processing capabilities like memory formation [3] and data coding [4] rely on controlled bursting dynamics. However, some brain disorders, like epilepsy and Parkinson’s Disease, are connected to pathological bursts and many treatment methods comprise stimulation of brain regions to intercept synchronous events [5]. 
While it is known that the burst of neural activities originate and terminate in distinct regions in epilepsy [6], it is, however, unclear what properties define the time and region of onset of such activity. In an attempt to investigate these properties, we have developed a computational neural network model that mimics essential properties of cortical networks in vitro, in which such bursting is ubiquitous, and it includes anisotropic connectivity, clustering of somata, and fasciculation of axons. These networks showed activity dynamics that in many respects were similar to cultured neural networks. We analyzed the spatial distribution and mesoscale structure of connectivity in relation to the participation of local subnetworks in different stages of extra- and intraburst activity. Our findings show that bursts usually start from areas with balanced excitation and inhibition or excess inhibition, while they ended in areas receiving excess excitation. The spatial distribution of initiation areas is non-random and associated with recurrent connectivity at network boundaries. These results are compatible with findings in seizure studies that observe an increase of inhibition in burst leading regions [7].
title: On the Structural Properties of Burst Origination and Termination Regions in Simulated Neural Networks

text: To understand how a neuron or a network responds to a stimulus it is necessary to compare spike trains with each other. This is often done by comparing first order statistics such as the firing rates. However, firing rate can remain the same across conditions even though the temporal structure of spike trains undergoes  a significant change. To understand and quantify this change it is necessary to compare not only firing rates but also all of neural temporal interaction structure. In this work we used the Hallinger and Kullback Leibler distances to quantify spike train differences. We find that small difference in time constants between two spike trains can result in disproportionately large differences in spike space, even for spike trains of the same rate.
title: Separating Spike Trains Using Information Theory

text:
A neuron's membrane voltage dynamics are shaped by a finite number of stochastic
elements: the voltage-gated ion channels. Consequently, neurons are intrinsically
noisy ``devices'' and timing of spikes is variable, even if the input is constant [1,2].

Some ion channel types exert a particularly large influence on spike time precision. For example, D-type K$^+$-channels have experimentally been shown to
increase spike time precision, and regulation of these channels
could either break or maintain synchrony in corresponding neuronal networks
[3]. Modulation of spike time variability has also been observed by channels such
as the persistent Na$^+$ and HCN channel [4]. Beyond the contribution of ion channels to conductance fluctuations (i.e., channel noise), however, they can also 
influence the (deterministic) susceptibility of spiking dynamics to noise from other sources (either external or from other ion channels).  

While many numerical simulation studies have previously analyzed the influence of channel dynamics on spike time precision [5,6],
an analytical perspective on dynamical systems theory can further deepen our understanding of this relation.
Here, we hence investigate the impact of channel stochasticity on spike time jitter across
three distinct dynamical regimes in the vicinity of a neuron's spike threshold. Based on
mathematical sensitivity analysis, we quantify how ion channel composion determines the net effect on spike timing from an the interplay between deterministic and stochatic channel dynamics.

We find that, in a mean-driven regime (i.e., a mean stimulation above threshold), the influence of a specific channel type on spike time jitter is determined by the overlap
between (i) the actual phase-dependent noise strength, and (ii) the
susceptibility of spiking to perturbations of that specific ion channel type.
The latter is given by the gating phase-response curves (PRCs). For a class 1
neuron (those with a firing onset via a saddle-node bifurcation), we demonstrate that the magnitude of the gating PRCs can be related
to the angle between the gating dimension and the eigenvector corresponding to
the strongly stable manifold of the saddle-node at firing onset. Consequently, if gating PRCs
and noise strength align, fluctuations in channel opening can maximally shift
spike times.

title: From fluctuations in ion channel gating to spike time precision

text:
Even in the absence of a particular sensory stimulus or behavioral task, mammalian cortex features complex dynamical behavior on multiple scales. On the single-cell level, neurons spike irregularly with increasing intrinsic time scales along the visual hierarchy [1]. Cortical layers and cell types show heterogeneous average firing rates. On a global scale, cortical areas form clusters with covarying activity, so-called resting-state networks [2]. These dynamics emerge on a substrate of complex connectivity on the level of cell types, layers and areas. With increasing knowledge on cortical structure, it is a growing challenge to integrate this information into a consistent picture of cortical connectivity.  

To jointly characterize the connectivity and spontaneous dynamics of cortex, we present a spiking multi-scale model of macaque visual cortex connected according to a new connectivity map based on multiple sources. It thus makes the nontrivial step from a population description [3] to a spiking description of this system. Visual cortex serves as an example system on which we develop the necessary tools to simulate spiking networks of this scale with realistic population-level connectivity, enabling analogous models of further cortical regions in future.

The network connectivity combines data from numerous tracing studies, collected in a new release of the CoCoMac database [4], with a recent quantitative dataset [5] and is refined using dynamical constraints [6]. The model for each area is an adaptation of a microcircuit model of early sensory cortex [7] to the specific laminar structure of the given area.
Simulations on the JUQUEEN supercomputer show that plausible dynamics emerge from the network, mimicking experimental findings on cortical dynamics on multiple scales, from single-cell spiking properties [1] to the large-scale interaction patterns of cortical areas [2]. Furthermore, cortico-cortical interactions propagate predominantly in the feedback direction, akin to experimental observations during sleep or visual imagery [8]. Our study demonstrates that such multi-scale dynamics can emerge from the connectivity on the level of areas and populations, thereby separating network effects from the influence of cell-type specific intrinsic dynamics. Our working model can easily be extended to other cortical areas, and it provides a substrate on which functional features at the spiking level can be added.
title: From single-cell spiking to large-scale interactions: A multi-scale spiking network model of macaque cortex

text:
A prominent property of visual cortical neurons is a selective response to specific orientations of a visual stimulus. Contributions to this orientation preference may come from both, recurrent connections as well as external inputs from the early visual pathway through the thalamus. Notably, the earliest scheme to explain orientation selectivity relies solely on a specific wiring scheme of the converging thalamic inputs without any recurrent contribution [1]. To causally test the relative contributions of recurrent vs. feed-forward inputs, one needs in principle the capability to control and potentially randomize specific parts of the wiring diagram in a functioning circuit. Such manipulation in-vivo is inconceivable with current technology. We instead propose to use hybrid synthetic neuronal circuits composed of simulated and living nerve cells, in which key features of the wiring diagram can be manipulated.

In a proof of concept application, we computed thalamocortical input currents to layer IV of cat for both simulated orientation specific and randomized projections in the early visual pathway. These input currents were then elicited optogenetically in a neuronal network in-vitro by digital phase-only holography [2]. The neurons are derived from the cortices of embryonic rats expressing the light-sensitive ionchannel ChRII. The typical cell density in these cultures is around $50000/\text{mm}^3$ with $90\%$ excitatory cells. We monitor neural responses both optically with a redshifted genetically encoded calcium indicator [3] and extracellularly with a multielectrode array.

We electrically recorded 515 units in 18 experiments. As expected, with orientation selective inputs, the neurons show substantial orientation selectivity. However, after randomizing the input wiring scheme, a significant orientation bias in the neuronal responses remained (mean OSI = 0.10, p<0.001), with the strongest units reaching an orientation selectivity index of OSI=0.61. Our results show that feature selectivity can be an emergent feature of random neuronal circuits.
title: Orientation selectivity in neural networks in-vitro

text: Auditory nerve fibers (ANFs) play a crucial role in hearing by encoding synaptic input from the inner hair cells into afferent spiking information for the higher stages of the auditory system. If the inner hair cells are degenerated, hearing can be restored with cochlear implants (CIs) that stimulate the ANFs directly with electrical pulses. However, several characteristics of the ANF and the stimulus affect whether and how the ANF responds to a particular stimulation pulse sequence. Such information is vital for optimizing CI processing but can be acquired only by recording single-fiber responses with other mammals or extracting it from compound responses of human listeners. The optimization process could benefit from computational models being able to predict peripheral responses evoked by a given stimulation. To that end, we have developed a phenomenological model for the ANF response to arbitrary pulse shapes and sequences. It is adapted from the stochastic leaky integrate-and-fire model by Horne et al. [1], where the ANF is thought to integrate incoming electrical current and to release an action potential if the membrane voltage exceeds a stochastic threshold and if the neuron is not hyperpolarized before being ready to spike.  A stochastic delay is introduced between the threshold crossing and the time of spiking to account for the latency and jitter of the ANF. The model can reproduce neurophysiological data from single pulse stimulations and it can account for inter-pulse interactions in pulse-train stimulation. Specifically, elements modeling the refractory behavior of ANFs have been added and the model has been extended to include two integrator units corresponding roughly to the peripheral and central part of the neuron. Here, we show that our revised model can account for neurophysiological data of the refractoriness phenomenon and that it demonstrates aspects of facilitation and spike-rate adaptation phenomena.
title: Phenomenological modeling of pulse train stimulation of auditory nerve fibers

text:
The hypothalamic neuropeptide oxytocin (OT) exerts prominent pro-social effects [3] and hence considered as potential drug for treatmen of psychosocial diseases in human patients [5]. Despite numerous publications focused on pro-social effects of OT, it is still unknown how social interaction affects electrical activity of OT neurons. 

Recent development of cell-type specific opto- [4] and pharmacogenetic [2] viral vectors allows us to identify and manipulate OT neurons in freely moving rats. Using these vectors combined with optoelectrode technique [1, 2] we recorded single OT neuron activity in the paraventricular (PVN) and supraoptic (SON) nuclei in rat hypothalamus during rest, exploration, and social interaction with unfamiliar conspecifics. Simultaneously we monitored animal behavior by an automated video tracking system (Noldus EthoVision® XT) coupled to recording of ultrasound vocalizations (Avisoft® Bioacoustics). Our preliminary results show that social interactions induce an increase in firing rate of individual OT neurons which correlates with the distance between interacting rats and their location in the arena. 

To analyze how selective responses of OT neurons can emerge from the network dynamics, we built a computational model to draw prediction on how silencing of specific OT modules changes the OT network output, and thus the social behavior, in response to a given input. These predictions are experimentally tested using genetic tagging of OT neurons combined with pharmacogenetic neuronal silencers to inhibit neuronal activity in specific modules of the OT network and to examine the consequent effects in the various social paradigms.

In conclusion, the evaluation of intrinsic properties of OT neurons during social interaction might help to dissect sensory pathways controlling OT neuron activity and opens perspectives for translational studies of human psychosocial diseases.
title: Probing oxytocin neurons activity in socially interacting rats

text:
Dendrite morphology varies greatly between different cell types and is known to influence neuronal function. The Horton-Strahler order or Strahler order (SO) is a centripetal branch ordering system originally developed for the classification and description of river networks [1,2] that has become popular to study the tree-like structures of neuronal dendrites and axons (e.g. [3]). In contrast to the classical centrifugal branch ordering, Strahler order assignments increase from the terminal branches with order 1 towards the root of the tree. When two branches of the same order meet, the order of the parent branch is increased by 1. However, when two branches of differing orders meet, the higher order is passed on [2]. We used this scheme to examine the general properties of SO-sorted branching statistics in reconstructed dendrites and in synthetically generated model dendrites. 
We find that branch and segment number distributions sorted by SO exhibit a typical exponential decay, a universal feature of binary trees. The distribution of number of segments follows $2^{-k}$ for SO value $k$ and can serve as a measure of how closely a dendrite approaches the structure of a binary tree that is completely filled with nodes on all levels. The distribution of number of branches that connect continuous segments with the same SO values converges to $4^{1-k}$, which is a known asymptotic property for random binary trees [4]. 
Furthermore, dendritic cable length as a function of SO depends on how planar the neuron is. Also, mean branch length and mean segment length distributions seem to be cell type-specific. These SO-sorted branching measures might therefore be useful to categorise dendritic tree structures. Finally, branch diameters correlate faithfully with SO but not with centrifugal branch ordering, indicating a functional importance of SO for dendritic morphology.
title: Properties of dendritic trees under centripetal branch ordering

text:
Many neural systems that exhibit high trial-to-trial variability respond to time-dependent external signals by a linear modulation of their firing rate. On the other hand, ensembles of neurons with low intrinsic noise and highly oscillatory activity of the single cells tend to become synchronized by a common external time-dependent signal and respond with precise spike timing. Here, we approach the question of how to capture the rate-response of an ensemble of neurons for which neither precise spike timing nor a linear modulation of the rate is observed.

First, we study a leaky integrate-and-fire neuron in response to a weak cosine signal and demonstrate the following weakly nonlinear effects: i) A pronounced nonlinear rate-modulation by cosine signals even for weak signal amplitudes. ii) A change of the mean firing rate by a signal with zero mean. iii) A pronounced nonlinear response to the sum of two signals.

We proceed with a numerical verification of the weakly nonlinear effects for a more biologically plausible neuron model, the Na-K model by Izhikevich, which hints that the weakly nonlinear response may be a rather general feature of neural oscillators.

Finally, we show that under certain conditions the rate-response of ensembles of neural oscillators with different levels of intrinsic noise can be faithfully described by either a linear rate-modulation, a weakly nonlinear rate-modulation, or by precise spike timing. Consequently, we argue that a weakly nonlinear theory can provide a link between linear rate-coding and coding via precise spike timing.
title: Nonlinear response of noisy neurons

text:
Optimising neuronal systems for efficient processing and representation of information is a key principle for both understanding and designing neuronal circuits, but recognising that a particular neuronal phenomena reflects an optimisation process is often difficult. Grid cells in the medial entorhinal cortex have been suggested to optimally represent spatial location by their spatially periodic firing fields (Burak06b, Fiete08, Mathis12, Mathis12b). However, it remained controversial whether the robustness and efficiency of the grid cell code is the result of careful tuning of the grid parameters (like the grid scale, Wei15, Stemmler15) or the performance of the system is not very sensitive to the actual parameter settings (Mathis12, Mathis12b, Towse14). This might be because there are very few analytical studies exploring the efficiency of realistic grid codes, where, contrary to nested coding (Mathis12b, Wei15), the spatial scale of the different grid modules are on the same order of magnitude.

Here we develop a novel approach to study the efficiency of grid code based on Diophantine approximations widely used in number theory to approximate real numbers with rationals. We demonstrate analytically that in the case of only a few grid cell modules, the performance of the code is extremely sensitive to the choice of the scale parameter of the modules, therefore optimization is required to achieve efficient spatial representations. However, including more modules not only increases the capacity of the coding, but also decreases the sensitivity of the code to the choice of the parameters - mitigating the need for optimization. In fact, local optimization is harmful in this case, since it leads to one of those few local optima that are globally very inefficient. We also show, that in the limit of large number of modules asymptotically optimal efficiency is reached for almost all scale size setting and demonstrate by simulations that this limit is already approached at $\sim 10$ modules. Thus the scale parameters of the entorhinal grid cell representation is unlikely to be optimised to improve coding efficiency. Our work highlights the importance of studying the basic computational principles underlying a particular form of representation to recognise optimization processes in nervous systems.
title: NO NEED TO OPTIMISE: ALL GRID SCALES ARE EQUALLY EFFICIENT

text: Neurons sharing similar features are often selectively connected with a higher probability and should be located in close vicinity in order to save wiring. Selective connectivity has therefore been proposed to be the cause for spatial organization in cortical maps [1]. Interestingly, orientation preference (OP) maps in the visual cortex are found in carnivores and primates [2,3] but not in rodents [4], indicating fundamental differences in selective connectivity [5] that seem unexpected for such homologous systems. Here, we investigate this finding by introducing a novel method to model neural placement that minimizes wiring costs for any given connectivity. Our model shows a transition from an unstructured salt-and-pepper organization to a pinwheel arrangement when increasing the density of neurons even without changing the selectivity of the connections. Increasing neuronal density also switches unstructured maps to layers, retinotopy or ocular dominance columns for the respective selective connectivity corresponding to each arrangement. A difference in neuronal density was indeed found between rodents and primates [6] which could explain the difference in OP maps between these species consistent with our model data.
title: A universal transition from unstructured to structured neural maps

text:
Collective spiking dynamics can reflect the functional properties of neuronal networks (NN). However, to date two contradictory hypotheses prevail: The first proposed an asynchronous irregular (AI) state [1], which minimizes redundancy [2] and promotes fast network responses. The second proposed a critical state [3], which is characterized by long range correlations in space and time, because it optimizes performance in tasks that profit from long reverberation of the network activity in models. Distinguishing between these two states is straight forward when the activity of all neurons is known. However under subsampling [4,5], classic approaches can mistake a network close to critical as AI: We showed that single neurons exhibit exponential inter-spike-interval distributions, and the Fano factor of single neurons is always close to unity.

Using the framework of branching networks (BN), we derived a novel estimator, which can infer the dynamical state even under strong subsampling, in principle from the activity of a single neuron (Fig. A). In this framework, the dynamical state is characterized by the number $m$ of postsynaptic spikes triggered by one presynaptic spike on average. In contrast to previous estimators [6], the novel estimator is unbiased, i.e. it is invariant under subsampling.

We applied this novel estimator to spiking activity in monkey prefrontal cortex, cat visual cortex, and rat hippocampus. Consistently, in vivo dynamics is situated in a narrow regime (median $\hat{m}=0.984$)  between AI ($m=0$) and critical ($m=1$). A model with the same  $m$ as in vivo (in vivo-like BN) could predict both, the bin size dependent spike count cross correlations between neurons (Fig. B) and the avalanche size distributions of the in vivo recordings (Fig. C) . The latter clearly differed from power-laws, which have been used as marker of criticality.

Our results offer a parsimonious solution to the competing hypotheses: activity appeared AI-like, as under subsampling correlations are underestimated. In contrast, coarse measures potentially overestimated correlations, making a network appear critical. Instead, in vivo spiking dynamics reflects a specific regime around m=0.984. This regime may combine the computational benefits of both states by allowing integration of information without the risk of instability or slowing down associated with criticality.
title: Branching into the unknown: inferring collective dynamics from the activity of few neurons

text:
The architecture of iso-orientation domains in the primary visual cortex (V1) of primates and carnivores apparently follows species invariant quantitative laws([1],[2]). The emergence of this common design has been explained by an abstract class of mathematical models for neural circuit self-organization([1],[3]). So far no biologically detailed model has been shown to conform with all features of this common design. Recently,[4]made available a biologically mechanistic model which mimics visual pathway and can be trained by natural stimuli. We examine and characterize this biologically mechanistic model in order to understand whether detailed models of Hebbian learning for the formation of nerve cell networks quantitatively match the common design in the visual cortex or not.

Our results show that, when covering a substantial fraction of the period of juvenile plasticity([5]), the statistics of pinwheel layouts including average pinwheel densities generated by the model are time-dependent and typically drop below experimentally observed values.

We find that, maps in the simulation typically become ordered and crystal-like over time. This process is driven by pinwheel annihilation and creation events. During the time course the ordered and a banded geometry of orientation domain start from the boundary of V1 increasingly dominates the whole simulation area. This indicates that boundary effects strongly influence pinwheel layouts in this model.

We conclude that common design is highly informative and can be used to assess all the validity of biologically detailed model.
title: Can the biologically mechanistic model generate pinwheel layouts with common design features ?

text:
During network oscillations the hippocampus receives a plethora of synchronized inputs. The effective integration of these inputs is crucial for proper function in tasks such as spatial navigation or memory formation.

AMPA mediated conductances are the main excitatory inputs in the central nervous system. Since their decay time constant ($\sim 3\, ms$) is small compared with the membrane time constant of neurons ($\sim 30\,ms$), voltage clamp (VC) whole cell recordings are best suited to study their kinetics. Voltage clamp consists of setting the membrane potential to a fixed value and hence recording the corresponding current. This poses two problems: Firstly, as the voltage is set in the patch location and the synaptic input may be received far away from it, there is some spatial distortion (space clamp); secondly, as the voltage is fixed, it is not possible to see how conductance changes interact with synaptic integration.

Synaptic inputs change the overall conductance of the neuron, thus changing the membrane constant. As the time constant rules how fast the cell depolarizes to the target membrane potential, its reduction may enhance integration.  We propose a method to measure this conductance change in current clamp (CC). We patch a neuron and inject a small sinusoidal current while triggering synaptic input at different phases of the sinusoidal wave. At any time point of the the synaptic event we have a set of (I, V, dV/dt) points to fit into a simplified equation of the membrane and thus obtain the instantaneous value of the membrane time constant ($\tau\star$).

Experimental patch clamp recordings of CA1 pyramidal neurons show that $\tau\star$ variations present faster kinetics than excitatory post synaptic currents (EPSCs) recorded in VC, suggesting that space clamp affects $\tau\star$ recorded in CC less than EPSCs recorded in VC as a readout of synaptic conductances. 

In conclusion, $\tau\star$ is a measure of excitatory conductance due synaptic input. It is less affected by space clamp than EPSCs and it does not require to have the membrane potential fixed, it may be used to analyze the effect of conductance changes, i.e., passive properties, in synaptic integration.
title: Instantaneous time constant as a measure of excitatory conductance changes in current clamp recordings

text: It has been discovered that cortical neurons can realize fast population encoding[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. The underlying biophysical mechanisms however are not well understood. Although it has been shown that reducing action potential onset rapidness can impair encoding bandwidth[5], it is not clear whether onset rapidness and encoding bandwidth are tightly connected with each other. Several biophysical hypotheses have been proposed[6, 7, 8]. One hypothesis states that rapid action potential onset is caused by the separation of the action potential initiation site and the soma[7]. And this separation causes the fast population encoding.  Here we examine this hypothesis with the firing rate linear response function. We found that the initiation site separation hypothesis alone is not sufficient to reproduce the high cutoff frequency observed in cortical neurons[2, 4, 5]. Also, the linear response functions at high frequencies are insensitive to the temporal correlations of the inputs. This disagrees with previous experiments as well[4]. By tuning the slope of the sodium current activation function, we also examine the cooperative gating hypothesis under this multi-compartment framework[6]. The cooperative gating hypothesis proposes that when emitting spikes, sodium channels are more likely to open together. The sodium current activation function is like a step function. When the cooperative gating of the sodium channels is introduced, both discrepancies above are resolved. We further compare the action potential dynamics under these two hypotheses, and propose an explanation for these discrepancies. We examine a simplified model of the multi-compartment model with cooperative gating. With some approximations, we obtain the linear response function for this model analytically. The analytic result indicates that decreasing the  soma size can help to improve the encoding bandwidth, and the encoding bandwidth is insensitive to the separation distance between the soma and the action potential initiation site.  In summary, our study shows that the separation of the action potential initiation site from the soma alone is not sufficient to realize fast population encoding. Adding cooperative gating of the sodium channels to the model can reproduce this property. In the cooperative gating model, the separation of the action potential initiation site from the soma plays a limited role in determining high cutoff frequency.
title: The impact of action potential initiation site separation on fast population encoding

text: In clinical studies or neuro-rehabilitation treatment involving patients with special needs, such as children, elderly, or individuals suffering from behavioral or developmental disorders, special care and attention is required when choosing measurement instrumentation [1]. In this regard, electroencephalography (EEG) is often delicate for its invasive looks, long preparation times, and rather complicated handling. We present the development and validation of a prototype for a simple and practical electroencephalography (EEG) device tuned to the special requirements of a clinical study on sensorimotor disabilities. We merged consumer EEG hardware with an unobtrusive headphones design to yield a device which has non-obtrusive looks that is not immediately associated with a clinical examination device. 13 semi-dry EEG channels were embedded in a flexible sheet mounted between the headphone earpieces and covering the majority of sensorimotor areas. In addition, the prototype features one EOG channel optionally attachable e.g. to the patient’s cheek for online or post-hoc EOG artifact correction. The prototype can be easily adapted to different head-sizes (approx. 50-60 cm diameter) and was validated both on children and adults. Furthermore, preparation times are very short (approx. 5 minutes) and comfortable wearing is provided for up to 30 minutes. Data quality was validated using a standard motor imagery task protocol. Our results indicate that the expected sensorimotor effects (mu- and beta- desynchronization) can successfully be captured [2]. An analysis on signal discriminability suggested that our device would be applicable in sensorimotor brain-computer interface (BCI) applications [3] or neuro-rehabilitation treatment [4]. Both researchers / experimenters as well as probands provided very positive feedback on usability and wearing comfort.
title: A simple and practical prototype of a sensorimotor EEG device

text:
Chip-based arrays, which facilitate parallel stimulation and recording of chemical and electrical cell-network activity, provide high-throughput methods for investigating neuronal communication. For example, we have recently shown that real-time electrochemical detection at microelectrode arrays can be used for monitoring vesicular dopamine release from many individual cells in parallel 1. Yet, to study specific network arrangements in vitro and to establish disease model systems, which mimic neuronal pathways in the brain, functional interfaces have to be combined with methods that can precisely control the layout and polarity of cellular networks. In this respect, microfluidic cell-culture techniques for guiding cell growth in defined patterns have gained increasing attention 2–4. Here, we report on rapid-prototyping approaches for establishing organized cell culture systems and combining them with functional stimulation and sensor elements. As opposed to classical clean-room fabrication, our approach relies on printing technologies. While being restricted to low-resolution patterning in the range of several micrometers, the flexibility and speed of the fabrication process makes it possible to quickly adapt the sensor and network architectures to arbitrary designs. We show how printed sensor arrays can be used for the detection of action potentials in cell culture systems. We believe that the design flexibility of this technology is interesting for investigating geometry-dependent cell-model systems.

text:
Myoelectric prosthetics are devices that substitute and replace lost human limbs for amputees with significant active research efforts. We designed an upper-limb myoelectric prosthetic controlled by surface electromyography signals (sEMG). First, we designed electronic sensor circuits for non-invasive EMG signals recording and acquisition. After preprocessing data, we decomposed EMG signals using discrete wavelet transform (DWT), time and frequency analyses in order to extract relevant information from recording data. After that, we implemented a multilayer perceptron (MLP) algorithm to classify four standard movements (Flexion, extension and prono-supination). Finally, a prototype of the myoelectric prosthetic has been used to demonstrate the capabilities and the performance of the proposed control system. As preliminary study, successful control has been achieved for one test subject. However, the current control system is incapable to adapt itself to various changes such as EMG signals distortion, electrode misplacement and drifts. Moreover, the developed control system requires high power, and provides low controllability and limited degrees of freedom (DoFs). To extend the current system, we aim to develop an advanced controller based on an embedded, small and energy efficient neuromorphic algorithm. Using neuromorphic computing devices expect real-time and low power consumption. We plan to incorporate two biosignals (EMG for control and EEG for error correction) and we will develop adaptive neural decoding algorithms to become robust to changes.

Key words: Myoelectric prosthetic, EMG signals, EEG signals, embedded neuromorphic controller, adaptive neural decoding algorithm
title: An embedded neuromorphic controller for a neuro-prosthetic hand

text:
Dopamine (DA) plays an important role for reward related learning, motor control and action selection. Consistent with this, the death of DA neurons in Parkinson's disease leads to severe motor and cognitive symptoms.

While the single unit activity of DA neurons matches reward prediction error responses, direct measurements of DA concentration in the striatum have indicated a more complex picture of the DA signal. For example, it is unclear how the ramping DA concentration in the striatum during the approach of a goal is connected to spiking of DA neurons. Therefore, the spatio-temporal DA concentration in the striatum does not seem to be a straightforward result of the activity of DA neurons. To better understand how DA cell firing relates to changes of the DA concentration we created a model of the spatio-temporal distribution of the striatal DA caused by different spiking patterns of DA neurons. Our model is based on a restricted diffusion model taking into account that free diffusion of DA in the striatum is hindered by obstacles like neurons and glia cells. To obtain a biological realistic model, we incorporate non-homogeneous DA uptake, DA axonal tree morphologies, detailed DA receptor kinetics, and spike trains based on rat DA cell recordings.

We find that the resulting DA maps have complex temporal and spatial dynamics that cannot simply be classified as "high" or "low" average DA concentration. Furthermore, we simulated Parkinson's disease by removing DA-releasing axons. We find, in agreement with experimental studies, that the average DA concentration does not change until a large fraction (>80%) of the DA neurons have died. Importantly, in the model this effect can be explained by the reduced DA re-uptake due to reduced number of axons. Thus our model provides an alternate explanation for the maintenance of DA levels in Parkinson's disease without invoking any compensatory mechanisms. Finally, we generate maps for D1 and D2 receptor activation for healthy and pathological states based on different D1 and D2 receptor affinities.

Overall, our simulations provide a detailed description of how DA cell activity translates into spatio-temporal activation of DA receptors which is an important component for understanding functional contributions of DA to information processing in normal and pathological behavior.
title: Title: Beyond "high" and "low" dopamine: complex spatio-temporal concentration maps in the striatum

text: Reversal learning has been extensively studied across species as a task that indexes the ability to flexibly make and reverse deterministic stimulus–reward associations. Although various brain lesions have been found to affect performance on this task, the behavioral processes affected by these lesions have not yet been determined. This task includes at least two kinds of learning. First, subjects have to learn and reverse stimulus–reward associations in each block of trials. Second, subjects become more proficient at reversing choice preferences as they experience more reversals. We have developed a Bayesian approach to separately characterize these two learning processes. Reversal of choice behavior within each block is driven by a combination of evidence that a reversal has occurred, and a prior belief in reversals that evolves with experience across blocks. We applied the approach to behavior obtained from 89 macaques, comprising 12 lesion groups and a control group. We found that animals from all of the groups reversed more quickly as they experienced more reversals, and correspondingly they updated their prior beliefs about reversals at the same rate. However, the initial values of the priors that the various groups of animals brought to the task differed significantly, and it was these initial priors that led to the differences in behavior. Thus, by taking a Bayesian approach we find that variability in reversal-learning performance attributable to different neural systems is primarily driven by different prior beliefs about reversals that each group brings to the task.
title: Effects of prefrontal and medial-temporal brain lesions on learning a Bayesian prior belief on reversals

text: Behavioral and neuroimaging studies have investigated control processes during task switching. Behavioral findings indicate a cost of switching such that reaction times are higher on switch compared to stay (repeat) trials. Functional MRI studies have suggested that a fronto-parietal network (FPN) is involved in task switching and in cognitive control in general. Multivoxel pattern analysis (MVPA) studies have revealed that specific task representations are encoded in the FPN. However, it has remained unclear whether task switching affects the neural representations of tasks in this network. One possibility could be that behavioral switch costs are due to a failure to fully implement a task representation in the FPN on switch trials. Here, we thus used MVPA to investigate task representations during task switching. On each trial participants were cued to perform one of two similar tasks (stimulus-response-mappings), with the task being repeated or switched between successive trials.  MVPA was used to assess encoding of the specific task on a given trial, which revealed task information in the known fronto-parietal network. However, the task-related information in FPN did not differ between switch and repeat trials. Using cross-classification we found that tasks are encoded using a similar spatial topography in switch and repeat trials in FPN. Thus, task representations in FPN are largely switch-independent. We thus found no evidence that neural information about task representations in FPN can explain the known behavioral costs associated with task switching.
title: Task representations in the fronto-parietal network are not modulated by switching

text:
Epilepsy is a chronic neurological disorder that is characterized by recurrent seizures. In around one third of cases, epilepsy is not controlled by drugs, and these patients are potential candidates for surgery. The current paradigm for surgery is to remove as completely as possible the “epileptogenic zone” [1], i.e., the brain tissue responsible for generating seizures. This zone is hypothetical, currently inferred using qualitative analysis of patient data, and assumed to correspond to a localized abnormality. However, epilepsy surgery does not always lead to seizure freedom, with remission after surgery achieved in approximately 60-70% cases, and more than a half of patients no longer seizure-free 10 years after surgery [2]. A confounding factor that may explain these poor success rates is that seizures are now acknowledged to arise in large-scale brain networks, and consequently localized abnormalities are neither a necessary nor sufficient condition for the development of seizures [3]. However, it remains unclear how different network structures cause emergent seizures, and whether certain network structures would be more or less amenable to a surgical approach. 

To address this, we use mathematical models of seizure generation in brain networks and evaluate the emergent dynamics in different synthetic networks such as random, small-world, scale-free, and rich-club networks. In each case we quantify the contribution of each node to the propensity of the network to seize (ictogenicity) and study how this correlates with node properties and network topology. We find that nodes with highest eigenvector centrality are the most responsible for seizure generation. Also, the ictogenicity of a network depends on its structure, and in particular networks incorporating rich-clubs are more likely to contain highly ictogenic nodes. Finally, we analyze functional networks derived from ECoG recordings from refractory epileptic patients. These were patients who, with few exceptions, received surgery, and accordingly we find the presence of rich-clubs in their functional networks. Thus, we show that this mathematical framework can be applied to clinical data, and may provide valuable aid to presurgical assessment of epileptic patients.
title: An optimal strategy for epilepsy surgery: Target the rich club?
topic: Brain disease, network dysfunction and intervention

text: The basal ganglia are considered essential for action selection and reinforcement learning. In combination with its connections from and to cortex and thalamus, the basal ganglia form a distributed and intricately connected network that is difficult to fully capture with electrophysiological recordings. Computational modelling could therefore be highly valuable in studying the functional roles of the direct, indirect and hyper-direct pathways. Here, we take the approach of dynamic causal modelling (DCM) where each structure in the network is represented as a neural mass and model parameters are estimated from EEG/MEG or LFP recordings using Bayesian inversion. Neural dynamics are described with second order convolution based equations. To complement the existing suite of DCMs in SPM, we implemented a separate basal ganglia ‘node’ (consisting of striatum, GPe, STN, GPi, and thalamus) [1,2] that can be combined with the conventional cortical network models in DCM. We used the combined cortical-basal ganglia model to estimate power and cross-spectral densities obtained from simultaneously recorded magneto-encephalography (from cortex) and local field potentials from the subthalamic nucleus in 11 Parkinson’s disease patients who received deep brain stimulation treatment. Beta oscillations were more pronounced in the OFF compared to ON dopaminergic medication states. The model provides support for both the striatal filtering hypothesis and recurrent connections between GPe and STN as generator sites for beta oscillations.
title: Dynamic causal modelling of cortical – basal ganglia interactions
topic: Brain disease, network dysfunction and intervention

text:
Reinforcement learning is an adaptive process where previous experience is utilized to improve the outcomes of future choices. This process involves the representation and processing of prediction errors which, in the brain, is closely linked to the dopaminergic system. In humans, modifications of the dopaminergic system are evident in neuro-degenerative diseases (e.g. Parkinson's and Huntington's disease), addiction or psychiatric disorders, and go along with alternated performance in reinforcement learning tasks in patients compared to healthy controls.

In obesity research, empirical studies suggest an inverted U-shaped relationship of dopamine-type2-receptor binding potential (BP) and measures of obesity, implying a higher BP for  overweight/mild obesity and a lower BP for severe obesity. In addition, behavioral and neuroimaging studies show differences between lean and obese individuals in reinforcement learning tasks.

In the present work, we develop forward models to investigate how different manipulations of the dopaminergic system draw distinct signaling signatures in target brain areas, such as the striatum. Manipulations of dopamine transmission are implemented in a model of basal ganglia functioning, a biologically plausible learning machine that is capable of solving reinforcement learning tasks based on prediction error processing. We compare model behavior to experimental data from individuals with obesity, in order to assess how much of the observed behavioral alterations are characterized by dopamine transmission-induced deficits in prediction error processing.
title: Forward models of reinforcement learning in obesity
topic: Brain disease, network dysfunction and intervention

text:
Learning to adapt behavior in order to optimize positive while avoiding negative feedback is essential for survival. To this end, humans and animals are constantly seeking to predict the causal structure of their environment and the consequences of their actions. However, inferring the optimal course of action may not always be immediately tractable and it has been observed that in uncertain situations animals may rely on ecologically sensible behavioral strategies such as win-stay, lose-shift, or alternate, with these behaviors also being more readily acquired depending on the environmental context.
Here, we investigate learning behavior on a two-choice operant cue discrimination task in two groups of mice, genetically modified mice associated with a severe learning deficit, i.e. a selective knockout of the $\textit{CACNA1C}$ gene coding for the $Ca_{v}1.2$ subunit of the L-type high-voltage dependent calcium channels ($Ca_{v}1.2^{NesCre}$), and matched controls $Ca_{v}1.2^{fl/fl}$. L-type calcium channels are crucial for synaptic plasticity which underlies instrumental learning, and less functional variants of $\textit{CACNA1C}$ have been associated with psychiatric disease such as schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, depression, and autism, rendering it an important target for understanding learning mechanisms in psychiatric conditions. By studying the detailed pattern of behavioral responses and rewards received across the learning process, combined with analyses based on behavioral (reinforcement) learning models, we show that $Ca_{v}1.2^{NesCre}$ mice specifically fail to learn the operant rule, while learning in the form of behavioral adaptation of more elementary strategies such as win-stay and lose-shift remains intact.
title: CACNA1C gene regulates behavioral strategies in operant rule learning

text:
Optimal synaptic plasticity rules are typically described as gradient rules. In reinforcement learning, optimal plasticity follows the reward gradient [Williams, 1992], in supervised learning, it follows the negative error gradient. Various parameters can be adapted within a synapse such as the amplitude of the postsynaptic potential at the sub-synaptic site, the postsynaptic receptor density, or e.g. the number of presynaptic release sites. While changing these parameters in the direction of their local gradient, the synaptic contribution to the somatic potential also changes. These somatic potential contributions eventually determine the firing behavior, and one may directly derive the gradient rule for these postsynaptic potentials (PSP) produced by the individual synapses. For the theory to be consistent, it should not matter whether the optimal PSP changes originate in an optimal change of the number of presynaptic release sites, the postsynaptic receptor densities, or the local potential amplitudes. Yet, the local gradients induce different PSP changes, and hence the theory lacks consistency. To resolve the issue, the standard `Euclidean' gradient calculations need to be replaced by the natural gradient (Amari, 1998). 

We derive the natural gradient learning rule for spiking neurons. Instead of the Euclidean metric, this rule calculates the gradient with respect to a local metric on the synaptic weight space that is given intrinsically by the neuron's input-output distribution. As compared to the Euclidean gradient, the natural gradient shows a scaling by the total synaptic strength on the dendritic tree, and an additional hetero-synaptic term. In addition, it is coordinate invariant and hence independent of which specific synaptic parameters are adapted during plasticity.
title: Natural Gradient for Spiking Neurons

text:
Neuronal networks in the brain display a wide variety of plasticity mechanisms, some of which have been interpreted as homeostatic regulators of neural activity. This includes synaptic mechanisms such as activity-dependent scaling and GABAergic plasticity, as well as plasticity of glutamatergic synapses onto inhibitory interneurons [1]. While the first two have been adopted in computational models [2,3], the last has attracted less attention.

Here, we investigate how excitatory synapses onto interneurons can function as a homeostatic regulator of excitatory activity. To this end, we simulate locally connected recurrent networks with a variety of excitatory-to-inhibitory plasticity rules, all of which have a fixed point where the presynaptic rate for each cell equals a homeostatic target.

We show that for a Hebbian rule (analogous to [3]), excitatory cells compete to control inhibition, driving most of the network into a quiescent state. The competition arises from the fanout in recurrent connectivity that produces de-localized inhibition when local inhibition is asked for. This problem is only overcome when a) the post-synaptic rate dependence in the rule is removed, b) the presynaptic rate is replaced by a local population average, and c) the region over which it is averaged is sufficiently large compared to the connectivity range. Such a rule is conceptualized as plasticity mediated by a diffusing agent released by active excitatory cells. The diffusion-mediated rule successfully controls the local population rate, while leaving local variability uncompensated, in contrast to homeostatic plasticity on GABAergic synapses which compensates each excitatory cell in a fine-grained manner [3].

These results predict that manipulating the activity of small groups of principal cells should produce homeostatic changes to glutamatergic synapses onto inhibitory interneurons in neighbouring principle cells. Furthermore, any plasticity observed at these synapses that is not mediated by a diffusive agent is unlikely to homeostatically regulate excitatory firing rates.
title: Functional requirements for homeostatic inhibitory plasticity in recurrent networks
