text:
We first assess the problem of detecting a multi-neuron spike sequence with duration L with a single leaky-integrate-and-fire (LIF) neuron equipped with instantaneous synapses. To do so, several strategies are possible: Strategy #n consists in connecting the neuron to all afferents that emit at least n spike(s) during a certain time window Δt≤L of the sequence (Fig. 1a shows Strategy 1; the selected afferents emit red spikes). We want to optimize the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the resulting detector, defined as SNR = (E(Vmax)-E(Vnoise))/σ(Vnoise) where E(Vmax) is the expected maximal potential reached during the sequence (ignoring the threshold), and E(Vnoise) is the expected potential elsewhere (Fig. 1b). Assuming a Poisson process with rate f for all afferents, both inside and outside the sequence, we could compute the SNR analytically. E.g. for Strategy 1, $$SNR = \sqrt{\frac{2 \tau N f}{1-e^{- f \Delta t }}} e^{-f \Delta t } (1-e^{-\Delta t/\tau}),$$where τ is the membrane time constant and N is the number of afferents. It turns out that Strategy 1 is usually the best for f and τ in the biological range (Fig. 1c, solid lines), and that in that case the optimal Δt is only slightly greater than τ (Fig. 1d), even if the sequence is much longer. Shorter τ are also better (but a small jitter would then impair recognition, a problem that we do not address here).
Next, using simulations, we investigated if spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) could drive the LIF towards this optimum. We used additive all-to-all-spike STDP[1], with homeostasis[2]. The afferents fired continuously according to a Poisson process. From time to time, an arbitrary sequence, initially generated with the same Poisson process, was repeated (frozen noise), like in ref. [3]. Starting from random values, the weights rapidly ended up binarized. Reinforced synapses corresponded to the afferents that emitted at least one spike during a certain time window of the sequence (i.e. Strategy 1), whose duration, using certain STDP parameters, could indeed roughly match the optimal Δt.
Taken together, these results may explain how we can learn repeating visual[4] or auditory[5] sequences. Long sequences could be recognized thanks to coincidence detectors working at a much shorter timescale. This is consistent with the fact that recognition is still possible if a sound sequence is compressed of played backward[5], or scrambled using 10-ms bins[6].
title: STDP allows close-to-optimal multi-neuron spike sequence detection by single coincidence detector neurons

text: Understanding the structure and dynamics of cortical connectivity is vital to understanding cortical function. Experimental data strongly suggest that local recurrent connectivity in the cortex is significantly non-random, exhibiting, for example, above-chance bidirectionality and an overrepresentation of certain triangular motifs (Song et al. 2005). Additional evidence suggests particular patterns of synaptic turnover dynamics, including a heavy-tailed distribution of synaptic efficacies, a tendency for stronger synapses to be more stable over time, and a power law distribution of synaptic lifetimes (Song et al. 2005, Yasumatsu et al. 2008, Loewenstein et al. 2015). Understanding how such features simultaneously arise would provide valuable insights into the development and function of the cortex. A recently developed spiking, point-neuron-based, structurally and synaptically plastic model has been demonstrated to reproduce all of these features at once (Miner and Triesch 2016). In this poster, we focus on the long-tailed, seemingly power-law distribution of synaptic lifetimes. This was first predicted in the precursor work to this model (Zheng et al. 2013), and was experimentally observed for the first time shortly before the publication of the most recent model variant (Loewenstein et al. 2015, Miner and Triesch 2016). Using this model, we examine what factors may contribute to the slope of the power law distribution. In particular, we note that said slope depends primarily on the effective structural pruning rate, which depends primarily on the effective balance between potentiation and depression in the network, and is independent of various other network factors, such as the structural growth rate and the network size. We investigate other network features and parameters as well and observe their effect, and speculate on the theoretical origins of this phenomenon.
title: An Investigation of the Self-Organization of Synaptic Lifetime Distributions

text:
We propose a learning rule for grid cell formation based on the
individual spike timing of place cells by means of spike-timing
dependent synaptic plasticity (STDP). In our model we take into account
the precise timing of spike trains exhibited by place cells, including
theta phase precession, to arrive at an analytical approximation of the
cross-correlation function and
its dependence on the place fields' spatial properties. In turn, this
allows us to explore the internal
dynamics of learning the synaptic weights from place cells projecting to
deeper layers of the MEC, and the subsequent formation of the
characteristic hexagonal patterns. We show that the weight dynamics follows a structure formation mechanism similar to
the Swift-Hohenberg class of spatial patterns comprising stripe or grid like patterns depending on the parameter regime.
title: Hippocampal phase precession leads to grid cells via STDP learning

text: In the mammalian brain, spatial maps of the environment are thought to be represented by place cells, representing locations in the environment by one or few firing fields, and grid cells, which tesselate the environment with firing fields arranged in a periodic hexagonal pattern. In natural environments, the spatial map of a grid cell may be anchored to different features of the environment but the mechanisms for generating transitions between differentially anchored spatial maps have not yet been established. To search for these mechanisms, we trained rats in two rectangular compartments A and B (each 1x2m) separated by a wall while recording the activity of grid cells. After training, each grid cell displayed two distinct grid maps, one for each environment. These two patterns, although similar in scale, rarely formed a continuous hexagonal pattern in the full 2x2m environment, but had a discontinuity where the partition wall was located. Next, we removed the partition wall and allowed the rat to explore the merged open square box (2x2m). Exploration in the large environment was not accompanied by de novo grid formation. Instead, the original grid patterns of the rectangular boxes were largely retained, but with decreasing similarity along an axis from the outer walls towards the centre. Centrally in the box, where A and B environments merged, individual grid fields changed location, resulting in increased local spatial periodicity and the creation of local continuity between the two original maps. The grid pattern was rarely a simple extension of the A map or the B map. The reorganization of the grid maps was expressed already during the first exposure to the merged environment, suggesting that it takes place on a fast time scale. Taken together, the data suggest that when environments are merged, differentially anchored grid maps fuse very rapidly, with reorganization of the grid field locations in the centre, in a direction that causes local periodicity to be established throughout the environment.
title: Integration of independently anchored grid maps in merged environments

text: Natural scenes are represented at multiple hierarchical levels, though typically more global levels are processed with priority over more local levels. It remains unknown whether such structured representations depend on task demands. Here, we applied standard visual-working-memory (vWM) tasks with novel hierarchical stimuli (a global ellipse composed of local line orientations) to probe the structure of vWM under varying task demands. Observers were required to remember a set of hierarchically oriented ellipses over a short retention interval. In Experiment 1, observers detected whether an orientation change (large or small) occurred either at an item’s global or local object level. Next in Experiment 2, observers reproduced a probed item's global or local orientation. We observed an influence of task demands on the global/local structure of vWM representations – global precedence was reduced with small, relatively to large changes. When precision is further emphasized by task demands (reproduction of the exact global or local orientation), we observed a reversal of global precedence into local-precedence, suggesting that a local bias can occur when detailed information is to be retained. These results indicate that the structure of vWM is under voluntary control and can be adjusted for varying task demands, thus, challenging accounts that assume fixed representations in vWM.
title: The structure of visual working memory adapts to task demands

text: We investigated the structural development of superficial-layers of medial entorhinal cortex and parasubiculum in rats. The grid-layout and cholinergic innervation of calbindin-positive pyramidal cells in layer 2 emerged around birth while reelin-positive stellate cells were scattered throughout development. Layer 3 and parasubiculum neurons had a transient calbindin-expression, which declined with age. Early postnatally, layer 2 pyramidal but not stellate cells co-localized with doublecortin – a marker of immature neurons. This suggested delayed functional maturation of pyramidal cells compared to stellate cells and mirrored the dichotomy of functional maturation of grid and border cells respectively. Three observations indicated a dorsal to ventral maturation of entorhinal cortex and parasubiculum: (i) calbindin-expression in layer-3 neurons decreased progressively from dorsal to ventral, (ii) doublecortin in layer-2 calbindin-positive patches disappeared dorsally before ventrally, and (iii) wolframin expression emerged earlier in dorsal than ventral parasubiculum. The early appearance of calbindin pyramidal grid organization in layer 2 indicates that this pattern is instructed by genetic information rather than experience. Superficial layer microcircuits mature earlier in dorsal entorhinal cortex, where smaller spatial scales are represented while microcircuits in the ventral entorhinal cortex – representing larger spatial-scales – mature later around the onset of spatial exploratory behavior.
title: Dorsoventral development of the Medial Entorhinal Cortex

text:
The action potentials of neurons in the hippocampal formation gradually shift their firing phases from late to early with respect to the LFP's theta oscillation (O'Keefe and Recce, 1993). This phenomenon is called 'phase precession'. It was previously hypothesized that phase precession can allow the temporal compression of behavioral sequences, down to the time scale of the induction of spike-timing dependent synaptic plasticity (Skaggs et al., 1996). This idea works well if different cells - that represent different behavioral events - show similar parameters of phase precession. However, the parameters found in experimental data vary over a wide range. From cell-type specific differences (Reifenstein et al., 2016, Ebbesen et al., 2016) to single-trial differences for a given cell (e.g. Reifenstein et al., 2014). It is currently unclear what effect the variability in phase-precession parameters has on the temporal-compression scenario. 
Simulating multiple phase-precessing cells, we systematically vary the different phase-precession parameters of those cells and measure whether the sequence of events is correctly compressed. We find multiple regions of parameter combinations for correct compression. We compare these parameter combinations to experimentally obtained values and investigate how the single-trial variability of individual cells influences sequence learning in the temporal-compression framework. 
Taken together, we quantitatively test the temporal-compression hypothesis and evaluate its robustness to variability of the underlying single-cell phase precession. Therefore, our results have wide implications for the understanding and interpretation of the phase-precession phenomenon.
title: Phase precession and the temporal compression of sequences - what could possibly go wrong?

text:
One of the functional consequences of short-term synaptic depression in neuronal transmission is the modulation of the synaptic information transfer rate [1-4]. To quantify the effect of synaptic depression on the information rate, we model a release site by a binary asymmetric channel (BAC) with a memory of length $L$ (Fig. 1A). The BAC model distinguishes between spike-evoked and spontaneous releases, both of which depend on the history of the site’s activity: the release probabilities depress whenever a vesicle is released and recover back during quiescent intervals. We model the state transitions of the release site by a Markov chain with $2^L$ states (Fig. 1B) and investigate the information conveyed by the release site about Poisson inputs. We prove that the mutual information rate of the release site, $R_D$, is equal to the statistical average over the information rates of its constituent states. If $R_j$ and $\pi_j$ represent the mutual information rate and the stationary probability of the state $j$, then 
$$R_D= \sum_{j=1}^{n} R_j \pi_j.$$
Only short-term depression, but not short-term facilitation, leads to such a linear summation of information rates [5]. 
In addition, we consider the energy cost of information transfer and calculate the energy-normalized information rate by dividing the mutual information rate by the amount of energy consumed per vesicle release. We show that the optimal energy-normalized information rate occurs at lower spike rate than for the mutual information rate (Fig. 1C). Moreover, the input spike rate that elicits the maximum energy-normalized information rate is robust to the variations of depression level. Therefore, regardless of how strongly synaptic transmission depresses in different neurons, all neurons should receive nearly the same rate of input spikes. 
In assessing the impact of depression on the information efficacy of the release site, we demonstrate that the relative level of depression for spontaneous and spike-evoked release plays a crucial role. Specifically, depression can enhance the information rate at a release site if vesicle release depresses subsequent spontaneous releases more strongly than spike-evoked releases.
title: Information rate of a release site under short-term synaptic depression

references.text: Urbanczik & Senn (Neuron 2014): Learning by the Dendritic Prediction of Somatic Spiking

text: Models of synaptic plasticity typically follow either a top-down approach, where the optimization of some mathematical function leads to a normative weight update, or a bottom-up approach, where experimental findings suggest biophysical parameters that influence learning. Here we try to bring these two approaches together by studying a model suggested by Senn and Urbanczik, where, in a two-compartment model neuron, synaptic plasticity in the dendrite serves to minimize a dendritic prediction error of somatic spiking. While the learning rule minimizes a specific cost function, i.e. is constructed in a top-down manner, we show that a version of the model suitably adjusted for more biological plausibility, manages to reproduce many characteristics observed in spike-timing dependent plasticity experiments. Among these are frequency dependence and the influence of the distance of the synapse to the soma. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the specific learning paradigm the learning rule implements depends on the wiring of the local circuit. Thus, dependent on the local connections, dendritic prediction errors can implement supervised, unsupervised or reinforcement learning.
title: Functional STDP-like Plasticity under Somato-Dendritic Prediction Error Learning

text:
Individuals often learn by trial and error to predict reward from relevant cues. For adaptive behavior, the rules connecting actions with their consequences need to be updated whenever reward contingencies change. Rule switching and cognitive flexibility is impaired in major neuropsychiatric disorders. Both medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) and the neuromodulator dopamine (DA) have repeatedly been implicated in behavioral flexibility but the underlying mechanisms have remained elusive. On the one hand, contemporary learning theories posit that reward prediction errors are passed on to mPFC via DAergic projections (reward prediction error theory). On the other hand, prefrontal levels of DA appear to stabilize or weaken attractor states, and impede or facilitate transitions between them, thereby decreasing or enhancing cognitive shifting and flexibility (dual-state theory).

The present study employs DAergic pharmacological manipulations and mPFC single-unit recordings during two versions of an operant rule switching paradigm (deterministic and probabilistic extradimensional set shift) to understand mechanisms controlling behavioral flexibility in rats. More specifically, we use a novel method for change point detection and ideal Bayesian learner models to determine how different doses of systemic amphetamine regulate flexibility at the behavioral level and test whether these effects are better captured by predictions of the reward prediction error theory or the dual-state theory. In addition, the prefrontal contribution to behavioral flexibility is examined using model-based analyses of mPFC single-unit recordings. Preliminary data show that mPFC single-unit time series mirror abrupt changes found at the behavioral level and provide evidence with respect to the computational significance of sudden neural transitions.
title: Model-based analysis of DA-dependent rule switching behavior and associated neural representations in rats

text:
Neurons in the hippocampal formation exhibit a variety of spatially tuned firing patterns. The mechanisms by which these different patterns emerge are not fully resolved, although competing computational models exist for several of them. Strikingly, many spatially tuned cells display invariances along other spatial dimensions. The tuning of “classical” place cells and grid cells is invariant to head direction and that of head direction cells invariant to location. Using a computational model, we suggest that all of the observed firing patterns emerge from the same underlying mechanism that can generate both the observed spatial selectivities as well as invariances along other dimensions.
The model consists of a feedforward network with a single output neuron. Its essential ingredients are i) spatially modulated excitatory and inhibitory inputs [e.g., 1] and ii) interacting excitatory and inhibitory Hebbian plasticity. The inhibitory plasticity homeostatically controls the output firing rate by balancing excitation and inhibition [2]. We show in simulations and by a mathematical analysis that, depending on the relative spatial autocorrelation length of the excitatory and inhibitory inputs, the output neuron rapidly develops a single place field, a periodic arrangement of firing fields -- akin to grid cells or band cell [3] -- or a spatial invariance. For inputs with combined spatial and head direction tuning, the same mechanism leads to output firing patterns reminiscent of head direction cells, “classical’ grid cells (without head direction tuning) and conjunctive cells (neurons that fire like grid cells in space but only at a particular head direction). Which activity pattern emerges is determined by the spatial correlation structure of the inputs.
A linear stability analysis of the homogeneous steady state accurately predicts the spatial periodicity obtained from simulations. In contrast to attractor models [4], our model predicts that the spatial scale of grid cells should be robust to global modifications in inhibitory synaptic strength.
Our model transfers the robust pattern formation of attractor models [e.g., 5] from the neural to the spatial domain, and increases the speed of self-organization of plasticity-based mechanisms [6] to time scales on which the spatial tuning of neurons is typically measured.
title: A model for invariance, selectivity and periodicity of spatial representations in the hippocampal formation

text: Dendritic inhibition influences forward- and backward signaling in dendrites. By selectively blocking backpropagating action potentials in pyramidal neurons [1], inhibitory interneurons can act as switches for excitatory synaptic plasticity and the so-called BAC firing mode [2,3]. However, such a modulation of backward signaling can interfere with the forward flow from dendritic synapses to the soma. To preserve information processing and integration of neuronal inputs, inhibition has to be precisely timed to not hinder the excitatory postsynaptic potential and hence the initiation of the postsynaptic action potential. Here, we propose that spike-timing dependent plasticity of inhibitory synapses in feedforward inhibitory circuits can achieve the required timing of inhibition by selecting appropriately-timed inhibitory synapses. Based on physiologically-constrained multi-compartmental neuron modeling, we first demonstrate the essential properties of an appropriate learning rule and then show that a simple spike-timing dependent rule with anti-Hebbian shape (similar to those observed experimentally) can also establish the appropriate timing of inhibition. We find that the proposed learning mechanism can terminate itself, because the learning process preferentially recruits those inhibitory inputs that eliminate the plasticity rule's own coincidence signal, i.e. the backpropagating action potential. Importantly, the established control of backward signals can be reversed by disinhibition, i.e. removal of dendritic inhibition from principal neurons via another interneuron. Taken together, the proposed learning rule could be an essential ingredient of disinhibitory circuits that provide dynamical switches of plasticity and firing modes for principal neurons (for a review on disinhibitory circuits see [4]).
title: Learning to gate backpropagating action potentials via spike-timing dependent inhibitory plasticity

text:
An important question in working memory is how objects with multiple features are retained. While some suggest an object-based representation with all features bound together; others argue for separate stores for different feature dimensions. A third alternative is the mixture of the object-based model and the feature-based model.
To reconcile this controversy, we study binding of different visual features in a working memory experiment. We contrast the binding task with the unbound task, in which different feature domain are memorized separately, regardless of their pairing during presentation. In addition the recall of single features is also tested as a baseline. We also investigate varying numbers of recalled items and varying change magnitude of features. Assuming a feature-based model, capacity estimates for bound and unbound conditions should be equal. Under the assumption of an object-based model binding features together should give an advantage allowing subjects to retain more in bound condition.
Furthermore, We use a fixed-capacity model to estimate subjects’ capacity in different tasks. We also employ a variable precision model to fit our data, in order to understand how the precision of recall changes between bound and unbound task.
title: Objects and features in working memory: The interaction of binding and storage precision

text:
The need to study how different levels of brain organization interact has led to an ever growing use of concurrent measures of neural signals with different recordings modalities [1, 2]. However, statistical methods that take full advantage of the great differences in multi-modal statistics and their intricate dependencies are currently lacking.
We developed a framework based on vine copulas [3, 4] with mixed margins to model multivariate data that are partly discrete such as neural spike counts and partly continuous such as local field potentials. The vine copula approach allowed us to derive efficient methods for likelihood calculation, inference and sampling with quadratic complexity in the number of modeled elements. We combined these methods by means of Monte-Carlo integration to obtain unbiased estimates of entropy and mutual information. To test our methods, we generated artificial data from parametric multivariate models. We also generated artificial spike counts and local field potentials from biologically realistic network models using the VERTEX simulator [5].
We applied our methods to these data and show that our new approach provides a model fit that is significantly better than that of corresponding independent models. Moreover, we demonstrate that mutual information estimates of fully continuous and mixed independent models can strongly differ from our proposed model which is faithful to the statistics of the margins and their dependencies.
Our framework presents the prospect of an improved analysis of neural data recorded simultaneously at different scales and from different modalities. Our models can also be used to construct Bayes-optimal decoders in brain-machine interfaces that benefit from concurrent recordings of various modalities.
title: Concurrent Analysis of Neural Activity at Multiple Scales Using Mixed Vine Copulas

text:
Cell assemblies [1] exhibiting neuronal interactions at the millisecond time scale were suggested as building blocks of information processing in the brain [2,3]. Significant patterns of synchronous spikes in electrophysiological recordings are considered as a signature of an active assembly. We recently developed a statistical method - the Spike Pattern Detection and Evaluation (SPADE) analysis [4] - to detect synchronous spike patterns in massively parallel spike data (MPST) on the order of 100 or more neurons. The method deals with a) the combinatorial explosion of the number of patterns to consider by employing a variant of the frequent item set mining technique [5, 6], and with b) the challenge of statistically assessing these patterns due to the multiple testing problem by using Monte-Carlo techniques.

We applied the SPADE analysis to electrophysiological data recorded from the motor cortex of two monkeys while they executed a delayed reach-to-grasp task. Monkeys were trained to reach and grasp, pull and hold an object by using either a side grip or a precision grip and with high or low force. To allow the monkey to prepare the upcoming movement, the animal is instructed about the grip type at the beginning of a delay period of 1s preceding the GO signal. MPST were recorded by using a 100-electrode Utah array chronically implanted at the MI/PMd border [7]. We hypothesized that different classes of spike patterns occur depending on the behavioral conditions and periods in the trial. To investigate this, we analyzed and compared data from the same set of neurons recorded during the 4 different behavioral conditions (combinations of object load and grip type), and during 6 time epochs of different stages of the task protocol.

We found [8] a variety of significant patterns in specific time epochs and behavioral conditions in both monkeys. We then analyzed the spatial organization of these patterns on the recording array with respect to its cortical location, and found that pairs of neurons involved in synchronous patterns were preferentially aligned along the medio-lateral orientation. We also assessed the specificity of the neuronal composition of patterns to different behavioral contexts and found a strong specificity to the grip type and the specfic behavioral epoch. These findings provide evidence for the existence of higher-order spike patterns occurring in relation to behavior.
title: Behavior specific spike patterns in macaque motor cortex during an instructed-delay reach-to-grasp task

text:
Electroencephalography (EEG) is a popular method to record voltage fluctuations on the surface of the brain. EEG is often used to assess brain dysfunction like epileptic seizures in clinical contexts, but the biophysical origins of the EEG signal are still poorly understood. Therefore only very few generative models (see e.g. [1]) of EEG exist. Here we introduce Conditional Probability Neural Networks (CPNN) as a new means of modeling EEG and similar highly variable neurophysiological data. We train the CPNN to predict EEG time series recorded from epileptic dogs [2] and demonstrate that the trained CPNN outperforms standard time series models, such as the autoregressive process or multilayer perceptron regression in generating  signals that match the power spectrum and other statistics of the recorded EEG.
By our adapted and extended method, which was initially developed to analyze particle physics experiments [3], a neural network is trained to represent the conditional probability density function of the future values of a stochastic process, given a set of samples from its past. Once the CPNN is trained it can be used as a generative model if predicted samples are presented as inputs to the CPNN iteratively. Such a model may then be used for forecasting and classification of time-series [4,5], in order to analyze brain dysfunctions like epileptic seizures or other neurological events.
In contrast to common machine learning approaches which learn to predict the most likely future value of a time series from samples of its past, the CPNN provides an estimate of the entire conditional probability density function (or posterior distribution), and thus has an intrinsic representation of the process' stochasticity. This aspect might be crucial for modeling highly variable neurophysiological time series such as EEG.
title: Modeling of EEG time-series by conditional probability neural networks.

text:
Introduction: Recently, deep learning approaches (in particular convolutional networks) have been extremely successful in solving supervised learning problems such as pattern recognition. Here, we use convolutional networks for classification of structural magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and multiple sclerosis (MS). 
Methods: A pre-trained convolutional neural network (namely the Caffe reference net provided by the Berkeley Vision and Learning Center) was applied on two-dimensional MRI slices of (1) 50 AD patients and 49 elderly controls and (2) 41 MS patients and 26 healthy controls. Features from ﬁve convolutional layers (conv1-conv5), one pooling layer (pool5) and three fully-connected layers (fc6-fc8) were extracted (Figure a, dimensions of layers: conv1: 290400, conv2: 186624, conv3: 64896, conv4: 64896, conv5: 43264, pool5: 16896, fc6: 4096, fc7: 4096, fc8: 1000. ). To assess the clinical relevance of different network layers, layer-specific features were fed into a linear support vector machine (SVM) and then used for classification between the clinical groups. Results were cross-validated for each layer. 
Results: Classification accuracies are depicted in Figure (b,c). Notably, the classification accuracies do not only vary between the different clinical groups, but also across the different network layers. For the classiﬁcation of MS patients, low-level features extracted from the ﬁrst layers (presumably corresponding to lesion borders) were in particular important. For AD classification, high accuracies have been additionally found for fully-connected layers. Importantly, the classiﬁcation accuracies of all layers were higher than for hippocampal volume, one of the key biomarkers of AD. 
Discussion: These ﬁrst very promising results show the great potential that deep learning approaches might have for neuroimaging-based disease decoding. Whereas previous disease decoding approaches mostly relied on the expert-based extraction of features in combination with standard classiﬁcation algorithms and thus strongly depend on the choice of data representation, convolutional networks are capable of learning hierarchical information directly from raw imaging data. By this, they have a great potential for ﬁnding unexpected and latent data characteristics and might perform as a real “second reader”.
title: Neuroimaging-based disease decoding using deep learning

text: Hebb's idea of a cell assembly as the fundamental unit of neural information processing has dominated neuroscience like no other theoretical concept within the past 60 years. A range of different physiological phenomena, from precisely synchronized spiking to broadly simultaneous rate increases, has been subsumed under this term. Yet progress in this area is hampered by the lack of statistical tools that would enable to extract assemblies with arbitrary constellations of time lags, and at multiple temporal scales, partly due to the severe computational burden. Here we present such a unifying methodological and conceptual framework which detects assembly structure at many different time scales, levels of precision, and with arbitrary internal organization. Applying this methodology to multiple single unit recordings from various cortical areas, we find that there is no universal cortical coding scheme, but that assembly structure and precision significantly depends on brain area recorded and ongoing task demands.
title: Detecting cell assemblies in multiple single unit recordings

text:
Dynamical Causal Modeling (DCM) is a promising method to investigate the effective connectivity among brain regions. It uses a Bayesian framework to deduce the hidden neuronal states from the time series of observed data measured by neuroimaging tools such as fMRI and provides posterior estimates of intrinsic synaptic coupling strengths among neuronal populations and also the inputs that modulate those couplings besides the extrinsic inputs on the neuronal states [1]. 
Here we have generalized the routinely used bilinear equation in DCM to the Wilson-Cowan type equations [2], which describes the evolution of excitatory and inhibitory activity in a population of neurons. This opens to possibility to use the results from the macroscopic model (e.g. the model fitted to the fMRI data) to constrain parameters of a detailed network model of a single brain region [3]. In the Wilson-Cowan model, one can interpret the sigmoid transfer function as an averaged f-I curve of many neurons in a single region. 
We used fMRI data that was measured by our group from 20 participants while they were imitating emotional faces, which revealed the activation of brain regions involved in the mirror neuron system [4], namely the Brodmann Area 44 (BA44), the Superior Temporal Sulcus (STS) and the Inferior Parietal Lobule (IPL) for the right hemisphere. The global connectivity pattern between the regions was determined by the DCM. The network structure of our best model consists of one driving input into STS and feed-forward connections from STS to IPL, from IPL to BA44, and back to STS from BA44.  These feed-forward connections are also modulated by imitation as a contextual input. Bayesian Model Comparison showed that the Wilson-Cowan based models have greater evidence than the original bilinear equation models, both for single state and two-state DCM. Thus, we have shown that DCM with a more complex neuronal model work better than a simple linear model, allowing us to make predictions about the local circuits.

text:
For many clinical applications as well as in basic research, inference of brain connectivity is of great importance. We are proposing and using a method to estimate effective connectivity from measured fast BOLD-fMRI signals. Among other things, we are looking for causal relations among nodes that is reflected in the non-invasively recorded activity of the whole brain.
We assume a linear interaction model, where a non-symmetric matrix of interaction kernels describes the directed influence exerted by nodes onto each other.
Our method uses only the information contained in the symmetric covariance matrix of the measured activity. This overcomes the problem of the relatively low temporal resolution inherent in fMRI data. For the inference of the direction of connections our method relies on the presence of so called "collider" structures in the network. These produce specific entries in the inverse covariance matrix of the measured activity [1,2].
As there are many network topologies that induce the same covariance structure, a disambiguation of the underlying causal structure is performed via L1 minimization which is known to prefer sparse solutions under certain conditions [3-5].
We applied this method on several data sets of high temporal resolution resting-state fMRI signals and compared the resulting estimates of effective connectivity across hemispheres and across individuals. As we have no access to the ground truth, we also compared the resulting networks with structural connectivity derived by diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) [6].
title: Inferring directed whole-brain connectivity from fast BOLD-fMRI signals

text:
Attention is a cognitive mechanism modulating receptive fields by changing the height of their response as well as their overall shape. For example, it has been shown that attention has variable effects on the receptive fields of neurons in area MT [1,2]. We therefore designed a neuro-computational model mimicking the electrophysiologically measured changes of responses in these neurons in the macaque brain. We show that a previous quantitative model [3] can be derived as a special case of our more general model but also that it has been simplified too much.
The receptive fields of our model are constructed by elongated two-dimensional Gaussian curves. Attention is implemented in the model MT-layer with center-symmetric Gaussian shape. We modeled the influence of the target stimulus (random dot pattern, moving in the preferred direction of the neuron) as well as two other distractor stimuli moving in the anti-preferred direction of the measured cell which were presented in the receptive field. Finally, the concept of divisive self-inhibition has been included in the model. The final model describes effects of attentional inhibition and excitation as well as receptive field size changes such as shift, shrinkage, and expansion. For each of the model variants we describe a goodness-of-fit measure which enables us to perform quantitative comparisons among different models.
Comparing our divisive-inhibition model to the previous Gaussian model of attention [3], we show that the simplifications of the Gaussian model result in a loss of several properties, and thereby fail to explain all attentional effects that could be ascertained in the data. Those effects include perception of unattended objects and split attention. We conclude, that an attentional model which explicitly models the influences of distractor- and self-inhibition in a divisive manner obtains not only the best fit but also leads to effects beyond the shift and shrinkage of receptive fields as modeled previously.
title: The unified divisive-inhibition model: A neuro-computational model for attentional scaling of receptive field size in middle-temporal area

text:
Introduction: In functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI), data are commonly analyzed using general linear models (GLMs) [1]. In these models, correlated nuisance regressors can interact with regressors of interest and lead to biased parameter estimates as well as invalid statistical tests [2]. Following our previous work on cross-validated Bayesian model selection (cvBMS) [6,7,8], we present cross-validated Bayesian model averaging (cvBMA) to improve parameter estimates and enhance statistical tests based on GLMs for fMRI.

Methods: In GLMs, fMRI data ($y$) are modelled as a linear combination ($\beta$) of experimental conditions ($X$) with normally distributed errors ($\varepsilon$): $y=X\beta+\varepsilon,\;\varepsilon\sim\text{N}(0,\sigma^2V)$ [3,4]. For model averaging, GLMs are inverted using maximum likelihood (ML) estimation [1,2] and quantified by cross-validated log model evidences (cvLME) [6,7,8]. BMA estimates are then obtained by weighting ML estimates with posterior probabilities (PP) calculated from cvLMEs [5].

Results: We investigate situations in which regressors of interest (e.g. representing targets) overlap with regressors of no interest (e.g. cues and feedbacks), so that including or omitting the latter has an influence on estimates for the former. Using simulated data, we show that BMA estimates have significantly lower mean-squared errors (MSE) than parameter estimates of even the best model as identified by maximal cvLME. Using empirical data from a conflict adaption paradigm [9], we find that different GLMs lead to different conclusions regarding experimental effects and that the most complex model is not necessarily the best choice. However, cvBMS can prevent from not detecting empirically plausible effects and cvBMA can increase sensitivity as compared to just using the subject-wise best models.

Discussion: In this work, we have introduced a method of model averaging for GLMs for fMRI to be employed when regressors of interest are contained in all models. Our findings indicate that cvBMA yields parameter estimates that are closer to their true values and provides statistical tests with lower false positive and higher true positive rates. We therefore envisage application for methodological control of models in cognitive neuroscience as well as inference on neural processing in computational neuroscience.
title: Cross-Validated Bayesian Model Averaging for General Linear Models in fMRI Data Analysis

text:
Models that incorporate the spatial extent of neocortex and axon transmission delays between neural populations are called neural field theories.  These models predict oscillations over the surface of the cortex that can exhibit high spatial coherence and have wave-like properties that depend primarily on the transmission delays between cortical populations; that is, on axon propagation speeds and length (Nunez and Srinivasan 2006; 2014). The dominant modes of these spatially distributed oscillations are often predicted to lie below about 15-20 Hz, i.e., in the theta and alpha bands of the human EEG. In contrast, in local networks models the dynamics are determined primarily by excitatory and inhibitory PSP delays and strengths of excitatory and inhibitory synaptic connections, and are usually expressed as a set of nonlinear differential equations that capture the interactions between excitatory and inhibitory neurons.  Local theories usually predict EEG signals and local field potentials with frequencies above 20 Hz. 
In this study, we make use of a neural field theory that uses a linear approximation to local network interactions to derive a constrained vector auto-regressive model that can be used to model functional connectivity from EEG data.  By placing realistic physiological constraints on the structure of delays, we can estimate the delays and connection strengths between brain areas.    Critically, this approach incorporates the interaction between brain areas with finite transmission speeds into a generative model of the EEG dynamics.  This model fits both the location and functional connectivity that gives rise to the observed synchronous sources of the EEG.   In contrast, most EEG modeling emphasizes localization of sources, and implicitly assumes a local model of the generation of the EEG time series across all frequency ranges.    We first present results that confirm the performance of the model on synthetic data, and then apply it to real EEG data.  This approach has significant potential to enhance the information on functional connectivity in cognitive and clinical EEG studies.
title: Neural field theory to infer functional connectivity

text:
This work introduces a pre-training technique for learning discriminative features from electroencephalography (EEG) recordings using deep artificial neural networks. EEG data are generally only available in small quantities, they are high-dimensional with a poor signal-to-noise ratio, and there is considerable variability between individual subjects and recording sessions. Similarity-constraint encoders as introduced here specifically address these challenges for feature learning. They learn features that allow to distinguish between classes by demanding that encodings of two trials from the same class are more similar to each other than to encoded trials from other classes. This tuple-based training approach is especially suitable for small datasets. 

The proposed technique is evaluated using the publicly available OpenMIIR dataset [1] of EEG recordings taken while 9 subjects listened to 12 short music pieces. For this dataset, a simple convolutional filter can be learned that is stable across subjects and significantly improves the signal-to-noise ratio while aggregating the 64 EEG channels into a single waveform. With this filter, a neural network classifier can be trained that is simple enough to allow for interpretation of the learned parameters by domain experts and facilitate findings about the cognitive processes. Further, a cross-subject classification accuracy of 27% is obtained with values above 40% for individual subjects.
title: Learning Discriminative Features from Electroencephalography Recordings by Encoding Similarity Constraints

text:
In the primary visual cortex cross-correlation (CC) peaks of neuronal spike trains can show stimulus specific near-zero phase delays. These can be measured with high precision in the CC, but are often invisible in the raw spike trains. 

Here we investigate the impact of small and imprecise phase delays in a stochastic spiking model that corresponds closely to experimental data. We derive optimal conditions on phase and rate parameters and on their combinations which maximize the probability to detect the correct stimulus. First, we find that pure rate, pure phase or mixed codes can be considered optimal depending on the chosen parameter range. Second, the increase in detection probability caused by the phase parameter increases with the number of stimuli and is usually relevant for at least $2^n$ stimuli, where $n$ denotes the number of neurons. With a Bayesian online change point detection algorithm we investigate the contribution of the phase to detecting changes in the stimulus. Here the phase reduces the required time horizon and the number of erroneous decisions.
title: Imprecise phases in stimulus recognition and change detection in a stochastic spiking neuron model

text:
There is strong evidence for the involvement of serotonin (5-HT) in psychiatric disorders (e.g. major depression, schizophrenia) that are associated with abnormal prefrontal cortex (PFC) activity. Treatments that target the serotonergic systems (e.g. SSRI, deep brain stimulation) show simultaneously improvement in behavioural symptoms and normalization of PFC activity. Besides that, the existence of bilateral projections between the PFC and the 5-HT production nucleus at the dorsal raphe (DRN) together with abundant expression of 5-HT receptors at the PFC output layers are indicatives of the importance of the PFC – DR loop for behavioral control.

Despite the vast literature on the theme, the underlying mechanisms that govern the PFC – DR loop remain poorly understood. We present our recent efforts to characterize the joint activity of these circuits, specially breaking down the contributions of the prelimbic and infralimbic subregions of the mPFC. By means of electrical stimulation of the DR in rats, we provoke an acute release of 5-HT and record the activity simultaneously in both PreL and InfL subregions. We scrutinize the response to perturbation of different classes of neurons for each subregion. Next we investigate, with a conductance-based leaky integrate-and-fire model, the theoretical contribution of different 5-HT receptors to the observed short term dynamics.
title: A conductance-based model for the serotonergic modulation of mPFC subnetworks

text:
Natural image generation is currently one of the most actively explored fields in Deep Learning. A surprising recent result has been that feature representations from networks trained on a purely discriminative task can be used for state-of-the-art image synthesis (Gatys et al., 2015). However, it is still unclear what aspects of the pre-trained network are critical for high generative performance. It could be, for example, the architecture of the convolutional neural network (CNN) in terms of the number of layers, specific pooling techniques, the connection between filter complexity and filter scale (larger filters are more non-linear), the training task and the network’s performance on that task or the data it was trained on.

To explore the importance of learnt filters and deep architectures, we here consider the task of synthesising natural textures using only a single-layer CNN with completely random filters. Our surprising finding is that we can synthesise natural textures of high perceptual quality that sometimes even rival current state-of-the-art methods (Gatys et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2016) which rely on deep, supervisedly trained multi-layer representations. We hence conclude that neither the supervised training nor the depth of the architecture is indispensable for natural texture generation.

Furthermore, we evaluate the importance of other architectural aspects of random CNNs for natural texture synthesis. For that we introduce a new quantitative measure of texture quality based on the state-of-the-art parametric texture model by Gatys et al. This measure allows us to objectively quantify the performance of each architecture and perform a large-scale grid-search over CNNs with random filters and different architectures (in terms of numbers of layers, sizes of convolutional filters, non-linearities, pooling layers, numbers of feature maps within each layer). The main result is that larger filters and more layers help synthesising textures that are perceptually more similar to the original one, however, at the cost of less variability.
title: Texture synthesis using random shallow neural networks

text:
In Parkinson’s disease (PD) the STN plays an important role in the formation of pathological oscillatory activity within the basal ganglia-cortex loop. The primary measure to reveal such oscillations is the local field potential (LFP). While it is assumed that the LFP reflects synaptic input to groups of neurons, the relationship between this population signal and the single neuron activity is still a matter of debate [1, 2]. Our long-term goals are to investigate the spike-LFP relationship in STN recordings obtained during deep brain stimulation surgery, as well as to assess the amount of synchrony between individual neurons in order to elucidate how oscillations on the population level translate to neuronal synchrony.
A critical step to achieve this goal is to correctly isolate the spiking activity of single units in extracellular STN recordings from Parkinson patients measured with a Ben Gun five channel micro-marcro-electrode holder. We employed a number of spike sorting algorithms [e.g., 3] and found that different spike sorting methods yield inconsistent results. We quantify these differences by the number of detected single units and the individual assignment of spikes to the detected units. Our long-term goal critically depends on the spike sorting quality [4], as, e.g., spike synchrony evaluation depends on the percentage of correctly identified spikes [5]. Hence, we introduced two additional approaches. Firstly, we developed a set of tools that estimates the isolation quality of single units [6]. These tools calculate the similarity of the spike shapes within one unit compared to other units. Secondly, we generated synthetic ground truth spike data of mixed units with the statistical features of the STN recordings: We selected the two most different spike shapes which we combined linearly to obtain pairs of spikes with  a controlled dissimilarity. Assuming Poisson spike rates we generated spike trains by inserting such spike pairs into a noisy background obtained by phase shifting the original noise. These data enable us to calibrate and verify our spike sorting results, i.e., to check if the number of extracted units and the spike-to-unit assignment is correct. By use of these two approaches, we compare and evaluate various spike sorting methods to finally select and apply the most appropriate one for the analysis of our STN recordings.
title: Evaluation of spike sorting results

reasonForTalk: Spike sorting for large scale electrode arrays is a large problem in the neuroscience community, and we propose a proper and validated solution that can scale for thousands of channels.
text:
Understanding how assemblies of neurons encode information requires recording of large populations of cells in the brain. In recent years, multi-electrode arrays and large silicon probes have been developed to record simultaneously from thousands of electrodes packed with a high density. However, these new devices challenge the classical way to do spike sorting. First, the large number of electrodes preclude approaches based on manual clustering. Even automatic approaches need to be fast enough to handle the amount of extracellular data. Second, the density of the electrodes is high enough so that a single spike will be detected on many electrodes. So the different channels must be processed simultaneously. Third, within a large and dense array of electrodes, overlapping spikes are rather the rule than the exception, and it is known that classical clustering methods cannot easily capture the synchronous occurrence of two spikes from two different cells [1].
	Here we developed a new software to solve all these aforementioned issues, and show that this algorithm reached near optimal performance  both in vitro and in vivo. The algorithm is composed of two main steps: 1) a “template-finding” phase to extract the cell templates, i.e. the pattern of activity evoked over many electrodes when one neuron fires an action potential; 2) a “template-matching” phase where the templates are matched onto the raw data to find the location of the spikes. The manual intervention by the user is reduced to the minimal. For the template-finding phase, we start by detecting all the possible times in the raw data that could contain a spike. Spikes are then clustered into groups using a density-based clustering derived from [1], and we then extract the template corresponding to each group. In the fitting phase, we match the templates onto the raw data with a method that allows amplitude variation for each template [2]. The algorithm is entirely parallelized such that it can handle large amount of data. It also provides  a graphical user interface so that the output of the algorithm can be checked, and to refine the sorting. 
	We tested our algorithm with large-scale data from in vitro and in vivo recordings, from 32 and up to 4225 electrodes. In all cases, we estimated its performance on data with ground truth, i.e. cases where the solution to the sorting problem is at least partially known. The performance was always close to the maximal expected performance.
title: Fast and scalable spike sorting for large and dense  multi-electrodes recordings

text:
Linking of experimental results to spatial and temporal reference points is needed for comparative analysis of multiple heterogeneous data sets of brain structure and activity, obtained from different sources, with different resolutions and in different coordinate systems. Evaluation of automatic labeling detection is investigated in [1], with proposal of a new workflow for spatial analysis of labeling in microscopic sections.
Anatomical reference points (landmarks) are based on the topological properties of the brain such as the shapes of sulci, gyri and fissures. In studies of the shape of sulcus authors present measuring brain variability via sulcus [2] and using of sulci as landmarks [3]. Functional reference points of brain activity are calculated from robust and similar values of measured parameters.
The characteristics of data mapping with different dimensions by reference points allow to perform defining of coordinate systems and scales. Standardized set of anatomical landmarks for registration and integration is proposed in [4]. Algorithms for automatically detection and matching of landmark curves on cortical surfaces to get an optimized brain conformal parametrization are presented in [5]. In [6] authors discuss multiple testing problems in brain imaging and propose single framework with using non-parametric combination methodology.
Setting the scale by reference points determines the detalization level. This level in practice is limited due to resolution of measurements, and can be specially impaired for noise reduction. Highly resolved four-dimensional maps of human cortical processing of nonpainful somatosensory stimuli was generated in [7] as combination anatomical and functional data from intracerebral recordings.
Time scales can be used to point out the characteristic times of events and intervals of the period of measurements. Concept of time scales is closely related to concept of synchronization.
Intended purpose of scales and landmarks is to create of templates for pattern recognition and to highlight POIs and ROIs. Invariant combinations of reference points can be used as templates for brain sectors. 
The present study illustrates the use of scales and landmarks for matching of MRI and CT data from different periods, describes the use of aggregated tomography data for mapping with detailed data from other sources. Also this paper considers biological significance of reference points as local places of impacts on nearby surroundings.
title: Scales and reference points in multiple pattern recognition
